PARA.TAB: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Kerry Sibraa) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that on 31 January 1992 I received a letter from Senator Josephine Vallentine resigning her place as a senator for the State of Western Australia. Pursuant to the provisions of section 21 of the Constitution, I notified the Governor of Western Australia of the vacancy in the representation of that State caused by the resignation, and I table the documents.

—by leave—I note that, while Senator Vallentine gave notice of her intention to resign, the Western Australian Parliament was sitting at the relevant time and, therefore, could not make a further appointment. Nonetheless, the Western Australian Government has failed to make the appointment of Christabel Chamarette, who has been duly nominated by the party that had formerly nominated Senator Jo Vallentine. There are other mechanisms which are available to the Western Australian Government for the filling of that casual vacancy.

PARA.TAB: I am personally rather dismayed that the Western Australian Government should essentially be thumbing its nose at this chamber. This chamber is comprised of 76 senators, not 75 senators. It requires the representation of senators from every State and this Senate is, therefore, deficient at the present time as a consequence of the Western Australian Government failing to make the proper appointment of a person who has been duly recommended by the party which obtained the necessary votes at the previous election—the one which elected Jo Vallentine. I will be giving notice of a motion later that this Senate should condemn the Government of Western Australia for failing to carry through with the appointment of a replacement senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is about time we condemned them.

—I would remind Senator Kemp, who obviously knows very little history, that Senator Greenwood, on a previous occasion when the New South Wales Government failed to make an appointment, was very vociferous in his condemnation of the New South Wales Government for doing precisely what the Government of Western Australia is doing. I would remind members of the Government that at the same time, in 1970, Senator Murphy was also very outspoken in his criticism of the Government of New South Wales over its failure to appoint a replacement senator at that time.

PARA.TAB: I believe that the Senate needs to take account of this failure and, as I will be moving shortly, to deprecate the actions of the Western Australian Government in thumbing its nose at this Senate and not, with some expedition, carrying out its function and filling that casual vacancy so that this Senate has its full complement of 76 senators.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I wish to make a very brief comment on the matter that has just been raised. I do so to indicate the difficulty that arises in some respects, not the least of which is the appointment of a senator to the vacancy that now occurs in the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. I had indicated my intention some time ago to nominate for that position.
—Now is the time.

—I suppose it is the time. I would automatically be appointed because the motion establishing that Committee indicates that there will be a representative from the independents or minor parties. Whilst I intend to nominate, and nominate now, it will be necessary for me, in fairness to Senator Vallentine's replacement, to resign when she comes into this chamber.

—Honourable senators will by now have noticed the new loudspeakers in the chamber. They represent the culmination of 12 months work by the Sound and Vision Office of the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff and sound engineering consultants, assisted by the Joint House Department, to improve the quality of the chamber's sound reinforcement system.

PARA.TAB: The new system encompasses both the new loudspeakers as well as new microphones. The whole system has been exhaustively tested during the summer adjournment and today will be its first test under working conditions. The microphones are considerably more effective. However, I am advised that speech notes or other papers held in front of the microphones will noticeably reduce the quality of the sound output, and I suggest to honourable senators that they be conscious of this while becoming familiar with the new system.

The system will be fine-tuned over the next few weeks as everyone concerned becomes more experienced in its operation. I ask that honourable senators bear with the sound engineers during this time. Any comments honourable senators may have on the level and quality of speech reinforcement will greatly assist the engineers with this fine-tuning. Such comments should be made to the Usher of the Black Rod, who will compile a report to the engineers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Richardson, will represent the Minister for Social Security, the Minister for Family Support and the Minister for Land Transport in the Senate. I also inform the Senate that the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, will represent the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and the Minister for Resources in the Senate.

PARA.TAB: I further inform the Senate that the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, Senator Collins, will represent the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, the Minister for the Arts and Territories, including the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women, and the Minister for Tourism in the Senate. Senator Collins will continue to represent the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to yesterday's report by Access Economics that the Commonwealth Budget this year is expected to blow out dramatically to a $9 billion deficit and that the net public sector financing requirement is forecast to increase to about $17 1/2 billion. Does the Minister agree with these forecasts? If not, what are the Treasury's forecasts?

—I always anticipate a question about the size of the deficit from the members of the Opposition because, after all, they are experts at it. They left us the largest deficit in the history of this country and lied about it. I further say to Senator Short that the Government's forecasts will be available tomorrow night.

PARA.TAB: In the Government's view, there is a need and scope for the fiscal stimulus which the Government intends to provide. Fiscal stimulus will directly add to demand in the short run and get the economy moving again. Commentators and sections of the business community have almost unanimously called for such a stimulus and few of them are wedded, I suspect, to an ideology of excessive fiscal caution.

I make the point to Senator Short that the OECD Economic Outlook recently noted the sustainability of Australia's fiscal position in maintaining its public sector debt to GDP ratio. As I hinted earlier, our Budget surpluses have earned us the ability to make tomorrow's statement and that statement will, of course, include some forecasts which Senator Short is now seeking that I make. If he waits until tomorrow, he will get the answer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's answer and, in so doing, I point out to him that Access Economics has a far better track record on forecasting over recent years than has the Treasury. I also note the confirmation in the Minister's answer that tomorrow night's package will be stimulatory in the sense of further increasing the Budget deficit and that there will therefore be a very significant public sector deficit this year. If the deficit is being funded by increased sales of government bonds, what is the impact of that demand for funds on domestic interest rates and on inflation? If it is going to be funded by overseas borrowings rather than government borrowings, what will the impact be on the exchange rate and our foreign debt?

—I congratulate Senator Short on his astute reading of the newspapers. I did not think it needed me to confirm that the contents of the statement tomorrow will be stimulatory in one way or another. I thought Senator Short would have understood that. The matter of how any additional deficit is to be financed is a question which Senator Short will also hopefully obtain an answer to tomorrow.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Shipping and Aviation. I draw the Minister's attention to the importance of the Australian tourism industry, which presently employs 450,000 people, or 5.8 per cent of the Australian work force and is the largest export earner in this country. What steps has the Government taken to recognise the importance of the tourism industry to the Australian economy?

—The Minister for Tourism, Mr Griffiths, has provided me with the following information. As all honourable senators would know, the Australian tourism industry is now Australia's largest export earner, contributing in excess of $7 billion—I think it is $7.3 billion—in the last financial year to our export earning growth. This is fully 10 per cent of Australia's total export earnings. It is now beating coal, wool or wheat in terms of our export earnings.

PARA.TAB: Of course, as we also all know, it is a great industry for creating employment. I do not think there is an industry better than the service industry at investing dollars in infrastructure. In excess of 450,000 people are employed in the tourism industry. It is anticipated that between 12 and 16 per cent of all new jobs in the 1990s in Australia will be created in the tourism and hospitality sectors of our economy. The Government has recently acknowledged, in a very substantial way, the status of tourism as an industry with the creation of a separate department of tourism and, of course, the elevation of the portfolio of tourism to the Cabinet. Even before this, however, the Government recognised the potential of the tourism industry. Under this Government there has been a sixfold increase in funds available for tourism promotion.

In December 1990 the Government allocated an additional $22.6m to the Australian Tourist Commission to enable it to carry out a worldwide television campaign promoting Australia as a tourist destination. This campaign has paid significant dividends. Tourism in Australia increased by 7 per cent in the first 11 months of last year. In key target markets the growth has been even more pronounced: a 10 per cent increase from the United States, an 18 per cent increase from New Zealand and a 9 per cent increase from Japan.

Since his appointment, in the lead-up to this week's statement, the Minister for Tourism has been consulting widely with the tourism industry to determine the priorities of the industry for reform. It is essential that we create the type of environment in which the tourism industry can flourish. It has the potential to respond rapidly to additional stimulus and, therefore, lead to greater foreign exchange earnings and job growth.

During the 1990s, the tourism industry is expected to create 200,000 additional jobs. The major threat to this job growth, of course, as I have said in the Senate many times, would be the imposition of a goods and services tax: it would kill the industry. In conclusion, in addition to the points that I have already made, there will be some positive news in the aviation sector tomorrow night. Aviation is the engine which successfully drives the growth of tourism in Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the explosion of foreign debt from 11 per cent of GDP when the Hawke-Keating Government came into office in 1983 to the current massive 35 per cent of GDP. I also refer him to the crippling servicing costs of those foreign liabilities and, of course, the consequent erosion of our living standards. What measures is the Government proposing to take to reduce our foreign debt?

—As I said in answer to Senator Short a minute or two ago, the stabilisation of Australia's foreign debt—which has been talked about for many years—will be one of the major results of the continuing economic reform program to make Australia more outward looking and internationally competitive. Over the last 3 years the net foreign debt ratio has been stable at around 34 per cent to 35 per cent of GDP. Most of the net overseas debt is owed by the private sector, particularly consequent upon the behaviour of the 1980s. As of 30 September 1991, 68 per cent of the debt was owed by the private sector; the State governments owed 17 per cent; and public enterprises, financial and trading enterprises, owed 20 per cent.
—You are illiterate. You just don't understand.

—I saw Senator Baume stunting in the electorate of Wills, being a litterbug. It is no good him stunting up here in Question Time because people will give him some special treatment here that he did not get down there. The Government was a net foreign creditor, making a—
—I prompted you lot into telling some fibs.

—They prompted some letters in newspapers in Melbourne, too. Before I was vulgarly interrupted, I was saying that the Government was a net foreign creditor, making a negative 5 per cent contribution, or $7.2 billion, reflecting four successive Budget surpluses. Earlier, Senator Short pointed out by way of interjection that there was one surplus.

PARA.TAB: In the last year the increase in net overseas debt was much less than in previous years. The debt servicing burden actually fell, with interest payments on the net debt in 1990-91 equivalent to 19.6 per cent of the value of the export of goods and services, compared with 21.4 per cent in the previous year. We have to continue to make progress on that issue, which I think we are doing. I would not in any way denigrate the progress which is being made, and I do not think the honourable senator should either.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. Can the Minister inform the Senate when the film Turtle Beach will be publicly released? Has the Minister seen the film? Will the Minister dissociate the Government from the film, as was foreshadowed as a possibility following Mr Hawke's meeting with the Malaysian Prime Minister, Dr Mahathir, at CHOGM in Harare last October?

—The producers of the film Turtle Beach have advised my Department that it will be released in Australia on 19 March and in the United States the following day. A number of preview showings have already occurred, generating quite a deal of newspaper discussion. I have seen a preview print of the film, as have a number of officers of my Department. I want to make clear on behalf of the Australian Government our understanding that the film is manifestly a work of fiction. It is not and does not purport to be a documentary account of historical events in Malaysia.

PARA.TAB: Although the film is a fictional drama, it is set in Malaysia during a particular, identified historical period—for the most part in the late 1970s, at the time when substantial numbers of Indo-Chinese boat people began arriving in that country. This could leave an uncritical viewer with the impression that the major events depicted in it had actually occurred.

But, as a number of published commentaries on the film have already acknowledged, the film's depiction of extreme violence against boat people, its portrayals of Malaysian official attitudes and actions with respect to the refugees, and its presentation of aspects of Malaysian life and cultural values are—whatever their claims to artistic justification—simply not accurate historical representations.

The film was produced by an Australian company which received part funding for the project from the Australian Film Finance Corporation, an independent publicly funded company which provides finance on commercial criteria to assist Australian film makers. The film was produced with the intention of commercial sale.

The Australian Government cannot and does not seek to control either media reports or fictional portrayals of this kind in this country. The Government has acknowledged, however, that there will be times when inaccurate or distorted reports or fictional portrayals are of such a kind that it is proper for governments to dissociate themselves from them. In the Government's judgment, the release of the film Turtle Beach is such an occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Does the Minister remember giving an answer to an earlier question of mine in which he said that no Government money would be expended on the MFP and that the total project would be driven by private investment? How much money has the Government already spent on the MFP? Is the Minister aware of the report of a recent high level Japanese economic delegation which has essentially said that the MFP is not a viable development without a great deal of prior Government expenditure? Will the Government spend more money on the MFP which, as the Sydney Morning Herald said this morning, is driven by `a combination of political opportunism and the pervasive influence of the consultancy industry' to support foreign industry rather than spend what little resources are available on support for industries of a home grown variety?

—I certainly do not recall saying that no Government money will be given to the MFP for the simple reason that last year in the Budget we did give money to it, and I think the year before as well. That has always been made clear. But in terms of investment in the MFP, that has to be private sector led. That has always been the Government's position and in respect of anything which the South Australian Government may wish to do in relation to the site, that is predominantly a matter for it under programs of the Commonwealth and State governments.

PARA.TAB: I have not read any report published in Japan and I am told no report has been published. Maybe it will be in the not too distant future, but I do not believe it has been published at the present time.

I skipped through the Sydney Morning Herald leader this morning on this issue. I do not recall it saying anything about support for Australian companies rather than foreign ones. Perhaps I do not recall it correctly or perhaps it is something that Senator Coulter intruded into his question in pursuit of his traditional biases on this topic.

In answer to the question, we have been allocating some money to the MFP under a program which was announced in the Budget. The South Australian Government is doing likewise. The allegation of its being driven by political opportunism is easily and cheaply made. The development site in Adelaide is probably one of the best sites within any urban conglomerate in Australia and it is very important to the people of Adelaide, as they continually attest.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Minister has failed completely to answer the fourth part of my question, which was whether the Government is anticipating the expenditure of more money on the MFP.

—More money could be spent on the MFP but only in the context of it being money generally available under government programs—government programs which are available for a wide range of things, including urban development, research and development, and infrastructure of one kind or another. Government programs exist for those sorts of things, but there will be no allocation to MFP which is special and distinct from government programs and agreed government expenditure priorities between the Commonwealth and the States.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Transport and Communications. It refers to the decision of Telecom to buy 11,000 tonnes of directory paper from Finland, thus turning its back on APPM in favour of the short term gain which a currency devalued spot market offers. Is it a fact that under the Australian Overseas Telecommunications Corporation Act the Minister has power, after consultation with the board of Telecom, to give it such written instructions as appear to the Minister to be necessary in the public interest? Is it not a fact that it is detrimental to the public interest for many workers to lose their jobs in an area of high unemployment, for company tax and income tax revenue to fall and for Australia's trade balance on forest based products, already unacceptably high, to go even higher? Will the Minister therefore instruct AOTC to reverse its decision and to remind it that the Australian community and Australian taxpayers have been very generous to it by waiving the $1 billion merger fee and converting from debt to equity a sum of $2 billion?

—Senator Harradine should be aware that the basic instruction from the Government to AOTC is to act commercially. That has to be the basis of any business operation of that kind, particularly one that is to be opened up to competition. It should be noted that this decision was taken by Telecom late last year prior to the merger with OTC on 1 February. I have inquired into the details of the calling of tenders and I am satisfied that a proper tender process was entered into. It is now a matter of regret that APPM has said a number of people may lose their jobs as a result of the decision.

PARA.TAB: In terms of price, there is no question that the correct decision was taken. There is also no question that APPM has been consulted by Telecom about price a number of times over the last couple of years. However, I am disappointed in the method of communicating the eventual decisions to APPM, and I am always concerned when any Australian loses his or her job because of the purchase from overseas of something such as paper.

I had a talk to APPM and there has been one further conversation between APPM and AOTC. I intend to pursue that matter over the next week or so to see whether anything can be done to save those jobs. It may well be, for example, that some extra stock can be bought. I know that Telecom is presently looking at those possibilities. I shall keep Senator Harradine and the Senate informed on those deliberations over the next few days.

As a matter of general principle, while I am prepared to give policy directions, I am not certain that it will be a very good precedent for Ministers to give instructions to bodies such as AOTC on individual management decisions. If we start to lift out each tender we do not like or each direction the management might take, I worry whether Telecom, or AOTC as it now is, can perform as a government business enterprise in a competitive market. Not too many businesses have someone sitting over them who can just turn over decisions. Nonetheless, I will keep Senator Harradine informed of those deliberations.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Would the Minister agree that this is not a question simply of a commercial decision against a commercial background, in view of the fact that the Government waived the $1 billion merger fee and is converting AOTC's $2 billion debt into equity? In view of that, is it not a fact that therefore the taxpayer is owed something by Telecom and that it is in the public interest for the Minister to ask Telecom to reverse its decision?

—Senator Harradine has to distinguish the macro from the micro. Whilst all that he said about equity and the rest is certainly true, members of the public will also expect that, for their money, the return they will get is that Telecom will take the best commercial decision. Telecom believes that it has done that.

PARA.TAB: We can weigh that up against all sorts of criteria. One would imagine that APPM, which is part of a much bigger conglomerate, may well decide that Optus is a better way to go. Every time Telecom makes the kind of decision it has made, that is something it has to weigh up. It could well be that on this occasion it has made a decision which will in the end cost it more than it saves. That is something Telecom management, reporting to its board, decides for itself.

As I have already said to Senator Harradine, I will pursue the matter—I am not letting it rest; but I will be very reluctant to set a precedent that involves me in trying to undo management decisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. I trust that he has a better run and answers questions better than his predecessor in this area, Senator Bolkus. I refer the Minister to the claim by his ministerial colleague, Mr Baldwin, that the official seasonally adjusted Australian Bureau of Statistics full time unemployment rate of 30 per cent for young Australians aged 15 to 19 is misleading and that, and I quote Mr Baldwin, `the real percentage of young people genuinely seeking full time work who are unable to find it is 8.8 per cent'. How did the Minister arrive at this phoney figure?

—I do not accept that the figure is phoney and I do not accept Senator Baume's editorialising on considered statements by Minister Baldwin. I do not have Mr Baldwin's statement in front of me, but I will obtain it and provide Senator Baume with that information.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his assurance that it was a considered statement by the Minister. Since he is going to pursue the matter of this considered statement by the Minister, I ask: as it appears that the Minister has arrived at this phoney unemployment figure for young Australians by taking it as a proportion of the total youth population—by the way, he even got it wrong then—why does the Government use in its considered statements a totally different criterion to measure the total number of Australians out of work of 10.3 per cent as a proportion of the labour force? Why is the full time youth unemployment rate, using the same criteria as the Government uses for the total unemployment rate, somehow wrong and somehow misleading?

—The chamber would have been served had Senator Michael Baume chosen actually to ask his full question at the beginning. With the greatest respect to Senator Michael Baume, I have noticed in many of his earlier presentations some creative use of statistics, so excuse me if I now do not take as gospel the presentation that he has just made. I will reply to it once I have consulted the Minister.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. The South African President, Mr de Klerk, has moved to implement an all white referendum about the future of South Africa. Can the Minister say what the Government's response is to this move and what action, if any, the Government will take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —From one point of view, the announcement by President de Klerk that a whites only referendum will be held on 17 March to determine the future of the political reform process is very unfortunate. Given the progress so far towards the dismantling of apartheid, one might have hoped that the days of white South Africans alone determining the future of their country were over. In this context, the negative reaction of the ANC to the referendum is perfectly understandable.

PARA.TAB: The situation is, however, a little more complicated than that. President de Klerk's decision to seek a fresh mandate for reform from whites must obviously be seen in the context of the very emotional reaction to the reform process still evident in significant sections of the white community, reflected most recently, of course, in the outcome of the Potchefstroom by-election. While there is every reason to believe that cooler heads will prevail if white South Africans are confronted with a stark choice between going forward or going backwards, it is understandable, against the background of Potchefstroom, that the National Party Government should have felt the need to take some dramatic action to stop emotional anti-reform momentum from further developing. Certainly the question being put to the white community in South Africa is very stark in its simplicity. As announced last night, it is in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: Do you support continuation of the reform process which the State President began on 2 February 1990 and which is aimed at a new Constitution through negotiations?

This does present the white electorate with a very simple choice: to continue into the future with its mixture of hopes and uncertainties or to retreat into the past, which, particularly in the light of the expectations for change which have obviously been generated since February 1990, would be a sure recipe for an absolute maelstrom of disaster.

PARA.TAB: So I am sure that all senators will join me in hoping that the outcome of the referendum is positive, as most preliminary opinion analysis in fact suggests it will be. If it is, the referendum may in fact prove to be a major milestone on the road to a new democratic South Africa, with the potential not only to give new momentum to the reform process as far as the white community is concerned but also perhaps to speed it up, if it is accepted following the referendum that there is no need for any further reference to racially defined electorates in endorsing the constitution now in the process of negotiation.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I refer the Minister to the unceremonious dismissal, reportedly without staff consultation or offer of voluntary redundancy, of seven senior New South Wales Labour Council staff, including two female members with approved maternity leave. Does the Minister support the actions of his senior Labor colleague Michael Easson as an example of effective industrial relations?

—I myself have only read of that report; I do not know whether the facts of the report are accurate. I assume they are. Senator Tierney can hold up the newspaper—I have said that I have read the report. All I am saying is that I do not know whether the terms of the report are accurate—I assume they are.

PARA.TAB: The question addressed to me, however, is: do I support what the report alleges as being an example of good conduct? Assuming the report is right—and that is an assumption that may not be true—I imagine that in the circumstances there ought to have been more consultation with the staff concerned, but I do not know for a fact that the report is right. I make the point that if Senator Tierney is saying that what the report contends is an example of bad practice, there is a host of employers out there he should be concerned about before he raises the question of the New South Wales Labour Council.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. If the Minister is not totally certain that the report is correct, I will quote the ALP's Parliamentary Secretary for Women's Affairs in New South Wales, Sandra Nori, who expressed her outrage at this decision in the following way:

QUESTION.PARA: It's pretty sad when the peak union body of the State sacks two women like that—it leaves the way open for other employers to do the same thing.

Does the Minister agree with Sandra Nori's assessment? Does he think—on his concluding point—that the officers of the peak ALP body are setting a good example in industrial relations to employers in private industry?

TALK.START.PARA: —Some details of the New South Wales Labour Council redundancy were drawn to my attention while Senator Tierney was taking the opportunity of posing during Question Time by quoting the reports of other people.

PARA.TAB: I am now advised that the New South Wales Labour Council did undertake a responsible management approach in consulting with staff over some time to resolve what were its restructuring difficulties and some financial pain it was suffering in view of the levels of unemployment affecting union membership. The Council regretted in the end the need to retrench staff and, being a responsible employer, has provided retrenchment benefits to ameliorate the effects of its decision.

One does not pretend that that means that all staff are 100 per cent satisfied. Certainly, being faced with the prospect of unemployment is not an edifying spectacle for anyone. This Government, of course, is constantly on the record as sympathising with those people who are in that situation. Therefore, I do not expect people, despite what actions may have been taken by the New South Wales Labour Council—and, as I say, I am advised that it has done it properly—to be happy with their lot.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: Garuda Airlines Flights to North Queensland

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Shipping and Aviation whether he can advise whether he has received any communication from the Indonesian Government in response to the Australian Government's offer to allow Garuda Airlines to begin flights in and out of north Queensland?

—I thank Senator Reynolds for her question and for the representations which she has been making to me for some time in respect of Garuda flights into Townsville. I gave an indication to the Mayor of Townsville and other interested people in Townsville that I would make every effort that I could, so far as the Commonwealth Government is concerned, to reinstate the international services since Qantas, for commercial reasons, discontinued them in March last year.

PARA.TAB: I stress, of course, that the fundamental requirement for providing international services or, indeed, domestic services into any port is a proper commercial base for those services. In that respect I am pleased to advise Senator Reynolds and the Senate that Townsville will once again soon have a new international airline service into Townsville.

TALK.START.PARA: —We knew that ages ago.
—In response to that idiot interjection opposite, we did not know that some time ago.
—Mr President, on a point of order: if I remember correctly, last year I had to withdraw the word `idiot', and I suggest you get the Minister to do the same.
—Order! I think it would be better if Senator Collins withdrew.

—I withdraw, Mr President. I point out to the honourable senator from Western Australia that we do, in fact, now have an extremely sensitive sound system in the Senate and there is no longer any need to shout. Mr President, as a matter of fact, I received the communication from the Indonesian Directorate General of Air Communications advising of the acceptance of the Australian offer only yesterday. So I am taking the first opportunity to advise the Senate that this matter has been dealt with successfully. Our offer has been made on an interim basis because it involves an increase in capacity beyond that negotiated in the last round of bilateral talks between the two countries. I point out that it is important that Australia's rights and the agreements that we reach with other aviation nations around the world—
—Why didn't you welcome Garuda to Cairns?
—As a matter of fact, Senator Macdonald, I did.
—Order!

—Mr President, that is on the public record. I point out that it is important that the reciprocal rights of Australia and Australian carriers remain an important consideration when providing these rights. I point that out because of what I have no difficulty in describing as the ratbag proposal by the coalition, contained in the one paragraph that passes for an aviation policy in its Fightback package, to make these rights available to the 35 international carriers that currently service Australia with no reciprocal rights being negotiated for Australian carriers. That is why it took some time to negotiate. Garuda planned to link Townsville and Cairns on a twice a week service to Jakarta and Bali. Instead of complaining about it, Senator Macdonald should welcome this.
—I didn't complain about it. Don't tell lies. You are a liar.
—I am advised that Garuda plans to introduce this new service from June—
—Order! I ask Senator Macdonald to withdraw.
—I withdraw calling Senator Collins a liar.

—Mr President, I know that good news always upsets the Opposition and Senator Macdonald in particular. He will have to choke on this next bit because I am also going to talk about Britannia Airways, and I must say that the news about Britannia Airways is particularly welcome to north Queensland.
—Mr Jull released it last week in Alice Springs.
—I am delighted with these interjections.
—Order! This is becoming a very long answer because of repeated interjections. I would ask the honourable senators on my left to cease interjecting.

—Mr Jull publicly stated that Britannia Airways had withdrawn one-third of its projected charters to Australia. That statement is utterly incorrect. I am pleased also to advise the Senate that, in addition to the new services provided by Garuda which will be very welcome to most of the people in Townsville, Britannia has had all of its proposed charters to Australia approved. There will be 109 flights. Those charters will bring to Australia more than 25,000 seats. The reason the very amicable and cooperative negotiations with Britannia took some time to achieve is that I was concerned that, instead of simply servicing Sydney, Britannia should service some regional airports in Australia as well. I am delighted that we have succeeded in doing that. The bulk of the tourists, as a result of these negotiations, will fly to north Queensland, the Northern Territory, central Australia and, I might add, Perth as well, giving the local tourism and hospitality industries a major boost during their traditionally quiet wet season. This is in line with the Government's policy of encouraging these charter flights to service the smaller centres outside of Sydney and Melbourne.

—Mr President, my question is addressed to Senator Button in his capacity as Leader of the Government in the Senate and also as the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I ask: in view of the referendum in Queensland at the weekend in which more than 54 per cent of Queenslanders rejected daylight saving, will Senator Button give the Senate an undertaking that the Government will not proceed with the National Measurement (Standard Time) Amendment Bill 1991 which would, of course, impose uniform daylight saving across Australia?
—I understand that Senator McMullan, on behalf of the Government, has already given a public undertaking to that effect.

—I preface my question to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade by drawing attention to the obvious reluctance of the United States and the European Community to adopt the GATT proposals for phasing out their subsidies. Is the Minister aware of the statements by Mr Rattigan and Mr Carmichael, reported in the Australian newspaper yesterday, drawing attention to the limited success that we can expect from such negotiations and pointing to the multitude of tariff and non-tariff barriers used by other countries which keep out Australian products and produce? What action is the Government proposing to take to reduce or remove these barriers or to assist Australian industries and farmers to overcome them?

—I have seen the reported criticisms of Messrs Rattigan and Carmichael in the press, although I have not seen yet the full text of their submission to the Industry Commission, which is the subject of those reports. But from the reports it appears that they have three criticisms interrelated, which have been picked up in Senator Spindler's question: first, that the Federal Government is not supporting industry efforts to become more competitive and is robbing Australia of the economic benefits of structural adjustment; secondly, that we are too committed to pursuing only trade reform on agriculture and defending the trade policy status quo; and thirdly, that not sufficient emphasis or focus is being given by the Government to domestic policy practices elsewhere which distort world trade. That may be an unfair summary of the full paper but that is the way it has been reported.

PARA.TAB: The Government's response to each of these criticisms—and this will answer Senator Spindler—is as follows: strong support is being provided by the Federal Government to efforts by Australian industry to become more competitive through the Uruguay Round negotiations. The Round fundamentally is about international competitiveness, about creating an environment in which Australian industry, like industry internationally generally, can flourish without the kinds of distortions and impediments of all kinds which litter the landscape at the moment.

The Uruguay Round is about not only reductions in tariff barriers but also about the whole range of non-tariff barriers as well as subsidies and things such as that which are inhibiting trade at the moment. To suggest that there is something one dimensional about the Uruguay Round itself is to misread—if that is, indeed, what is being said by these two gentlemen—the nature of the enterprise on which we are all embarked. Moreover, it addresses new areas such as services and intellectual property, which are also themselves extremely important in advancing Australian economic interests. Australian industry will be able to benefit really across the board from the more liberal trading environment that we do hope, and to some extent still expect, will follow the conclusion of the present negotiations.

As to the alleged overemphasis on agriculture, it is, of course, the case that agriculture remains extremely important for Australia and the Uruguay Round, addressing this for the first time in GATT history, does hold the promise of delivering more substantive benefits than any previous multilateral negotiation. But we are not only focusing on agriculture. It just happens to be that that is where we have had the highest profile because of our initiation and leadership of the Cairns Group. We have been very active participants in all other areas of those negotiations, especially services trade and intellectual property, which I have already mentioned, where we do stand to be major beneficiaries.

Finally, again I would respond negatively to the criticism about not pressing for a focus internationally on the impact that domestic industry policy can have. As part of the interim results of the Uruguay Round in 1989, the GATT established a trade policy review mechanism which was designed to keep the internal policies of GATT participants under regular review. We, in fact, exposed ourselves to that process as an early candidate for review in order to give a momentum to it—a demonstration effect. We believe that that is exactly the kind of thing that these negotiations and the machinery associated with them should be trying to put focus on. That mechanism, together with the anticipated outcome from the substantive negotiations themselves, will certainly continue to give a very strong international focus to the impact that domestic policies can have on world trade.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. The Australian Democrats certainly support the emphasis on agricultural products in the Uruguay Round of the GATT negotiations. Our problem is that there is little likelihood of these becoming successful and actually providing some relief to our farmers and, for that matter, to our manufacturers. The burden of the question to the Minister was—and, in a sense, I and one million unemployed will regret that he has missed the import of the question—what additional effective action is the Government going to take to ensure that our industries are not faced with barriers when other countries' products can enter our market unhindered, in the Government's projection of its tariff reductions? I put to the Minister two specific initiatives that we suggest the Government should continue: firstly, to defer further tariff cuts; and, secondly, to join an Asian trading bloc which potentially could exclude the United States and the European Community so that we have some leverage for our products entering Asian markets.
—That is really another question, Senator Spindler.

—I do not really think I missed the point of Senator Spindler's question. I was proceeding on the assumption that he had some understanding of the economic dynamics of world trade and our place in it, but I am afraid that his supplementary question suggests that that is rather lacking.

PARA.TAB: It is too big an issue to go into any elaborate detail here, except to say that all our eggs are not just in the basket of the Uruguay Round. In addition to creating the kind of international environment I was referring to before—which will be important in reducing a whole range of barriers elsewhere—we are pursuing regional strategies and bilateral strategies to improve the access of Australian goods and Australian services. We are, in the regional sense, through the mechanism of APEC, very actively trying to produce accelerated consideration of the whole question of non-discriminatory regional trade liberalisation in a whole variety of product areas which are crucially important to Australian industry.

The notion that there is some quick fix to be obtained by hitching a ride with some putative or emerging trade bloc in our own region is to quite misunderstand the nature of the complementarities that are working in the region and the kind of benefits that we could expect to derive from that. Overwhelmingly, we will derive benefits by non-discriminatory worldwide trade liberalisation. Within that framework it is possible to accelerate the liberalisation that occurs in a regional context. We are doing that in APEC.

To talk about trade blocs erecting new defensive barriers, or blocs with new aggressive mechanisms to wage trade warfare with other blocs around the world, is very much a worse case scenario and one that we are all hoping can be avoided. Equally, on top of all that, we have a whole variety of bilateral trade strategies for access to, particularly, our regional neighbours where trade is underdeveloped at the moment in terms of its potential.

I will table very shortly a North East Asia policy review which will be followed, I am announcing today, by a South East Asia economic opportunity policy review. We are actively pursuing, both in a regional and bilateral context, the whole range of issues which are exercising Senator Spindler and a lot of other people.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs. I refer to the 56 boat people who landed undetected on the northern coast of Western Australia in January and who walked inland for several days before they were found. What is the Government's explanation for this serious lapse of Australia's coastal surveillance? Secondly, what is the Government's explanation for this serious undermining of the integrity of Australia's immigration program? Where are these persons now? Have any made applications for refugee status? How long will it take for the applications to be determined? Finally, is it true that since November 1989, a little over two years ago, eight boats have landed on Australia's northern coasts carrying 382 illegal immigrants and, of these, only 19 have since left Australia? Why has the Government in this whole matter been so indecisive and why has there been so much delay?

—In respect of the first three parts of Senator Teague's question, if he were to ask the right Minister, he might get an answer. In respect of the 56 Chinese boat people who arrived on board the Isabella on 31 December 1991, negotiations with independent legal advisers to assist those people with any claims they may have to refugee status are nearing completion. A team of DORS officers is expected to be in Port Hedland to commence interviews on 3 March and the processing of those applications for refugee status will follow the new procedure which was announced on 12 February 1992. I will obtain full details relating to the last part of Senator Teague's question and provide those to him.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I infer that the Minister says that these 56 persons are now in Port Hedland. Are they all there? Where are they? Will the Minister refer that part of my question which speaks of the incompetence of this Government in the area of northern surveillance to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, who is responsible for the Customs Service, which in turn is supposed to be responsible for the surveillance of Australia's northern coast? Will he refer that question to the Minister?
—It is rather strange for someone to allege incompetence when he himself is not competent enough to work out to which Minister he should direct a question.
—He couldn't track an elephant through snow if it had a blood nose.

—I accept that comment from Senator Ray. Senator Teague might do some basic training in understanding who represents whom in this place. Customs has not changed. In respect of that same allegation of incompetence, if Senator Teague had listened to my first answer, he would not have had to ask the second part of his question. In respect of the third part of his question, that information will be passed on.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. Is the Minister aware of an editorial in today's Sydney Morning Herald concerning the national procurement development program? Does he regard the program as a success and does he support its continuance?

—This is an excellent question. Senator Sherry takes an astute interest in these matters, which is more than I can say for some of the honourable senators opposite who are interjecting. In fact, I am aware of two editorials in this morning's Sydney Morning Herald. I am sad that the Sydney Morning Herald, in pursuit of an article which appeared in that paper a week or so ago, has let its normally excellent editorial standards slip. The editorial is based on the draft report from the Industry Commission relating to the national procurement development program which recommends that the scheme not be extended beyond June 1992—something the Government will have to examine when it gets a final report.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that the Commission, and now the Sydney Morning Herald, has come to this view in spite of a passage in the summary of the Industry Commission's report which says that, `It is not possible to reach a view on whether the program is effective in enhancing the international competitiveness of recipient firms'. The Industry Commission said that it is not possible to reach a view about that issue, but then it went on to say that it was against it in any event. Having reached a non-conclusion on this matter, the Commission then sought to justify its report by debating whether government intervention is justified at all in achieving economic and social benefits by supporting the development and commercialisation of technology. That is a legitimate debate which takes place within Australia and within the Liberal Party and in all public forums.

I make the point, however, that the scheme was established following Sir Brian Inglis's inquiry into the government purchasing of technological equipment. In that report, which was commissioned and discussed by the Government and discussed in the Senate, the point was made that there was a lack of opportunity for Australian companies to commercialise technological products and services in domestic and international markets. The Inglis report, consistent with the views of the world of Michael Porter of Harvard, concluded at the time that there is a critical role for government agencies in contributing to industry development by encouraging government agencies to work with Australian companies in areas typically dominated by large overseas suppliers.

The scheme was about helping to change the culture of government procurement agencies. I profoundly believe—and I believe that most or all of my colleagues do too—that that is something which has to happen. Those who do not believe that are wallowing in a sea of ignorance. Indeed, there are many questions from Opposition senators from time to time along the lines of `Why does not this government agency support this government business?' and things of that kind. That is what the scheme was essentially about.

It is a draft report. In so far as the report makes comments about program administration, these and the major issue will be addressed when we receive the final report. There is a lazy tradition of journalism in this country. Certain journalists cry `hurrah' every time an Industry Commission report crosses their desk because it gives them something else to write about. It is sometimes lazy journalism when these sorts of articles are written on the basis of a draft report.

TALK.START.PARA: —And they are very sound!
—Senator Bishop, I am not debating the merits or otherwise of the Industry Commission. I have implemented more things said by the Industry Commission than her lot in government did in 30 years.

—Mr President, my question is directed to you. In order to put to rest rumours which affect the smooth running of the Senate, I ask: is it your intention to resign soon, as is speculated in the press? Is it true that Senator Aulich, who was promised the job, has now been dumped by the Prime Minister as well as his Party? Is it true that Senator Tate is now to get the job to provide a vacancy in order that Mr Keating can reward another one of his mates who helped to put him in the Lodge?

—I am aware of some of the rumours; in fact, I am suing one of the newspapers which printed one of them. I might remind honourable senators, having looked at the latest Bulletin poll in New South Wales, that the indications are that we will elect three senators. I intend to run and win.

—Can the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs inform the Senate what steps the Government has taken to ensure that the confidential credit information provided by Australian borrowers to banks and other financial institutions is handled in a manner which respects the legitimate privacy concerns of Australian consumers? In particular, can he assure the Senate that Australian consumers will never be faced with a situation, as presently occurs in the United States, where such information is widely made available to any organisation claiming a legitimate business need for that information?

—I am very happy to inform honourable senators, all of whom no doubt are borrowers—we live in a credit dependent society; a debt ridden society—that from today the ability of credit reference organisations to compile comprehensive dossiers on the financial profile of Australians will be utterly illegal. I believe that that is a very worthwhile achievement. I pay tribute to Senator Bolkus for initiating much of the legislation which comes into effect today.

PARA.TAB: In particular, the American practice of positive reporting, whereby dossiers can be compiled informing the holders of that dossier of the whole credit history of a particular person, is obnoxious to the idea of fair play in Australia. We do not intend that that should be able to be done.

More particularly, credit reference organisations were compiling what information they had and passing it to other persons in the community who claimed to have what they called a legitimate business interest. It is beyond the pale for real estate agents, insurance agents, direct marketeers perhaps in terms of the American model, employment agencies and prospective employers to get access to information on the credit history of a particular person and this Parliament has said so. That law comes into effect today and, as a result, such information cannot be passed to real estate agents, insurance agents, potential employers and so on.

The fact is, also, that it is most important that those credit files that are held are accurate, and that when people apply for credit they are not denied that credit because of an inaccurate history that has been compiled by a previous credit provider. To that extent, once again, Australians will be able to have guaranteed access to their credit files held by the Credit Reference Association of Australia, free of charge, for scrutiny, and if there is anything to be corrected in those credit records then it is to be corrected very promptly. I believe that this is extremely important to all Australians because, as I say, we are all borrowers dependent on the credit system to sustain the way in which we live.

This is a very important day for those involved in obtaining credit in our society. Once again, I pay tribute to Senator Bolkus. I believe that even the Credit Reference Association of Australia has come to terms with this particular legislation. It will work well, particularly with the cooperation of the Privacy Commissioner, Mr Kevin O'Connor, who is supervising its implementation.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.
—I seek leave pursuant to standing order 190 to make a personal explanation.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Collins, in answering the dorothy dix put to him by Senator Reynolds—and I do not have his words exactly—indicated that I should stop whingeing about Garuda coming into north Queensland to Townsville and Cairns and do something positive about it. I called him a liar for saying that, and I was rightly made to withdraw that comment.

PARA.TAB: I do wish to make it clear to the Senate that never have I whinged about Garuda coming into Townsville and Cairns. I have always supported Garuda coming into Townsville and Cairns. In fact, ever since I have been in the Senate it has been an aim I have been working towards. We have certainly done what we can, and I have done what little I can do—and I admit it has been only little, speaking as a member of the Opposition—to encourage Garuda into Townsville and Cairns. For Senator Collins to suggest that I have whinged about it or opposed it is despicable on his part.

It was on 22 March 1991 that Senator Collins first mentioned Garuda coming into Townsville, and it has been a matter of much comment since then. Senator Collins keeps trying to announce it to get some cheap political points for himself and his Party, which, of course, they desperately need up there.
I wonder whether I might also, by leave, take the opportunity of correcting something else that I said which turned out to be wrong.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Some time ago, after the upheaval, I did write personally to Senator Collins congratulating him on his appointment to the Cabinet, and my congratulations were sincere and still stand. What I want to correct, though, is that just before we left the Parliament last year I interjected on several occasions saying that Senator Collins would not get a job in the new Ministry. I was quite wrong in saying that, because when I was interjecting in that way I thought that Senator Collins was still a Hawke supporter and I did not realise that he had jumped ship and changed his allegiances just to keep his ministerial position.

—I raise a point of order. I think Senator Macdonald has finished. Personal explanations are not a vehicle for making speeches which are more appropriately made during the adjournment debate, and Senator Macdonald erred considerably in that regard.
—I think I was very lenient.

QWN.TITLE: ADDITIONAL RESPONSES TO QUESTIONS WITHOUT NOTICE

TALK.START.PARA: —On 10 September 1991 Senator MacGibbon asked me a question regarding air traffic control systems. I now provide the following answer, and I apologise for the delay. Senator MacGibbon asked about the steps taken by me in relation to the CAA control systems. The answer is that the various steps taken by me and officers of my Department were a number of discussions with Senator Collins—which, I might say, have continued over a lengthy period—and meetings with various local industry representatives.

PARA.TAB: The officers of my Department arranged a workshop at Parliament House, primarily to provide representatives of Australian industry with possible areas for participation in the Australian advanced air traffic system and, secondly, to allow local firms to make contacts with the potential primes.

Officers of the Department gave presentations on the Government and industry purchasing policy objectives to the CAA management and members of the CAA board. The Department has had ongoing discussions with the primes on how they can improve their bids and the long term opportunities arising from those bids. Departmental officers provided advice to the CAA on the long term benefits for local industry incorporated in the proposals put forward by the primes.

Secondly, the honourable senator is right in that a group of local companies, AWA and others, formed a consortium and made an approach to CAA. They gave a presentation to the CAA outlining their proposal. However, they were unsuccessful in being accepted as a prime by the CAA. The actions taken by me and officers of my Department are a clear indication of our strong commitment to supporting and promoting Australian industry. I am still taking an active interest in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call on condolences, I inform the Senate that I shall have to leave the chamber on two occasions this afternoon, the second being to farewell Her Majesty the Queen on her departure from Australia in Adelaide. Normally I would not leave the chair during condolences, but I am sure the Senate will excuse me and Senator Hill, who will be accompanying me on this occasion.
—It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death on 7 January 1992 of former Senator Ian Alexander Christie Wood, Senator for the State of Queensland from 1949 to 1978.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death on Tuesday 7 January 1992 of Ian Alexander Christie Wood, Senator for the State of Queensland from 1949 to 1978, and places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service.

SPEECH.PARA: Ian Wood, who was known to me personally in my earlier days in the Senate, was born on 31 January 1901 in Mackay, Queensland. He was a remarkable gentleman in many ways and devoted over 50 years of his life to public service in both local and Federal government. If I may be permitted a personal observation, Ian Wood was very much a Mackay man—in the Menzies phrase, Mackay to his bootstraps. Even after he retired from the Senate, those of us who visited Mackay would see him around the place. I think he was still taking an interest in local government issues and still riding his bike. He was very much a person who was profoundly committed to his local community.

PARA.TAB: Ian Wood's career in government began in his late twenties when he became an alderman. He then went on to become Mayor of Mackay and purported to be the youngest mayor in Australia at that time. He was elected Mayor of Mackay no fewer than five times and served for 15 years in that capacity. Other achievements in the area of local government included his being President of the Australian Council of Local Government and President of the Queensland Local Government Association.

His election in 1949 as a Liberal senator for Queensland began a career in Federal politics which was to last almost 29 years until his retirement in 1978. During that time he served on a number of committees, the most notable being his chairmanship of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. People such as Senator Durack and I remember that Ian chaired that Committee for over 20 years. His enormous contribution to the Committee remains a feature of his time in Federal Parliament. He also served as Temporary Chairman of Committees for some 25 years and acted as President of the Senate on several occasions in the unavoidable absence of the elected President.

Ian Wood will be remembered as a hard working and principled man who worked unstintingly for the people of his home State of Queensland and, of course, Mackay, as I said earlier, and the people of Australia. He had a capacity to talk with people at all levels, and his obvious honesty and integrity made him a popular choice. His re-election at every poll until his retirement was evidence of this.

I might say from my personal observations that Ian Wood was not a person without eccentric qualities. His time in this place was not always smooth sailing. He was known for his independence and outspokenness. He and Senator Wright were sort of a double in respect of much of that. I am sure that he caused his Party colleagues more than a few anxious moments as a result. Nevertheless, he pursued what he believed to be right and was a great and worthy representative of the State of Queensland. In his last speech to the Senate, Ian Wood said:

SPEECH.PARA: When all is said and done, it is the people whom we represent. If we understand what the people need, we will be successful.
In that sense, and in his own words, Ian Wood was a success. On behalf of the Government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his loved ones in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of Opposition senators, I join with the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) in expressing our regret at the death early in January of former Liberal senator for Queensland Ian Wood at the age of 90. Ian Wood left school at the age of 12 and, despite his lack of formal education, became a successful businessman in Mackay. As has been said, in 1949 he was elected to the Senate where he served for in excess of 28 years until his retirement in 1978. Mr President, I am pleased that at least two Opposition senators were able to attend his funeral, although I regret that neither was given the opportunity to formally represent this Senate.

PARA.TAB: During his time in the Senate, Ian Wood was outspoken and independent. As the Leader of the Government, Senator Button, said, he was seen by some as eccentric—particularly, it is put to me, in his refusal to use car transport both in Canberra and Mackay, preferring instead to ride a bicycle. These days it might simply be said that he was health conscious.

Speaking to one of Ian Wood's colleagues, former South Australian Senator Gordon Davidson, who was a close friend and colleague, he told me of the commitment of former Senator Wood to this institution, particularly his priority to the Senate as a States House. I understand that Ian Wood's loyalty and devotion to the Senate as a parliamentary institution frequently put him at odds with his Party. But always he seemed to choose the Senate first.

Throughout Ian Wood's time in the Senate he was a strong supporter of the examination of legislation by Senate committees. One of his great contributions to the role of the Senate within the parliamentary system was as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I understand that he presided over its deliberations for an astonishing period of 25 years. His commitment has been put to me in terms of his fierce defence of the Committee's terms of reference and, in particular, the matters of safeguarding the freedom of the individual and the prevention of additional costs to the taxpayer. Despite the fact that his Party was in government during the period of his chairmanship, he never spared Ministers or the departments as he presided over the Committee's deliberations. Senator Wood was also Temporary Chairman of Committees for eight years from 1958 to 1966.

Ian Wood made no apology for the fact that one of his most significant areas of interest was the development of the tourist industry in north Queensland, particularly Mackay. He was a proud citizen of Mackay and I understand was generous to those of his colleagues who visited him there. His list of services to the city is legion, including 15 years as mayor, so it is not surprising that the citation for his Order of Australia award was for services to the State of Queensland.

Ian Wood held fast to a number of strict political and personal principles and gave full effect to these in his role as a senator. We remember gratefully his strong endorsement of the Senate as an essential element of the Australian parliamentary system and his use of it to benefit his beloved State of Queensland, and overall his major contribution to public life in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the National Party in the Senate, I wish to express our condolences on the death of former Queensland senator Ian Wood. Ian Wood was a greater Queenslander and a promoter of the State that I am also proud to represent. He spent many years of his life in service to the public, both as Mayor of Mackay and as a Queensland senator—sometimes holding the positions simultaneously. He was a senator for 29 years from 1949 to 1978. In one of his successful campaigns for Mayor of Mackay in 1967, whilst also a Liberal senator for Queensland, he led to victory a mayoral team consisting of my National Party colleague Ray Braithwaite, the State member for Mackay, Mr Ed Casey, now Minister for Primary Industries in the Goss Labor Government and the vice-president of the local branch of the ALP.

PARA.TAB: Although I did not know Ian Wood very well, he was often described as a rebel and a real individual. He was well known for getting to know his constituents by travelling through his local area by bicycle. At the same time, he was never afraid to cross the floor on matters of principle. Importantly, he was a tireless advocate for the development of northern Australia and the economic contribution it could make to both Queensland and the whole of Australia.

He lived a long life of 91 years and must have received great satisfaction in his later years in seeing his vision and hard work for north Queensland rewarded with the blooming of the tourism industry in that area. Known to have called Mackay `the sweetest city in Australia', his persistent faith in the future of north Queensland was illustrated in a speech he gave in 1964, when he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The sugar industry and the tourist industry have shown what can be done to develop the north. Opportunities exist for further development. If they are accepted I believe we can make the northern part of the continent a really great asset to Australia.

Those words have proved to be very true. Former senator Ian Wood set a precedent for all Queensland senators to follow through his tireless dedication to the well-being of Queensland and, in turn, Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with my colleagues in the Senate in supporting this motion of condolence on the death of former senator Ian Alexander Christie Wood. None of the present Democrat senators were present in the Senate at the time of Senator Wood's very long service in this place and, as far as I can ascertain, no Democrat senators even knew Senator Wood. However, having listened to the other speakers—Senator Button, Senator Hill and Senator Boswell—it is quite clear that former Senator Wood came over as somebody well loved in this place who served the institution of the Senate extremely well, and who, according to the three accounts we have heard, was delightfully eccentric. I would not say that riding a pushbike is in any sense eccentric; perhaps he was given to fitness. Nonetheless, it is a delightful characteristic.

PARA.TAB: Quite clearly, the world and the Senate have been made the richer by his work in this place over so many years, and also by his work in local government and the other areas in which he obviously served with great diligence over a very long period. Accordingly, the Democrats join with other senators in supporting this motion of condolence and expressions of regret to the surviving members of his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion of condolence for Ian Wood that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button. I do that because I knew Ian quite well and I had the pleasure of following him when he retired from the Senate nearly 14 years ago.

PARA.TAB: Ian was born in Mackay on 31 January 1901 and he died in his ninety-first year. He came from very poor circumstances. He had to leave school at a very early age to support his mother and his younger sister. Those two people had a very central role in his life. His mother died years ago; his sister predeceased him a few years back.

Very early in his life he demonstrated his great interest in public affairs—first of all, as has been mentioned, by becoming an alderman for the city of Mackay in 1927. He maintained that association with local government right up until 1970, when he finished his fifth term as Mayor of Mackay. It is claimed, I think, that he introduced the first town plan in Queensland for the planning of Mackay. He was a very generous benefactor both to the city and to organisations within that city.

He was a canny Scot in some ways. I suspect his addiction to riding pushbikes was related more to saving money and not having to buy a car than to ecological or environmental concerns, and least of all to his health. He was a person who never gave a moment's thought to his own health. Despite his personal canniness, he was an extremely generous individual to the community around him. I think one of his final acts was the contribution of a music room to one of the church schools in the city of Mackay.

Ian Wood was one of the great senators in this chamber. Only three senators since Federation have served longer than Ian Wood. He entered the Senate with the victorious Menzies Government in 1949 and he did not contest the 1977 election. He therefore retired on 30 June 1978. Only three senators have served longer. Mr President, you would have known former senator Justin O'Byrne, who was here when I entered the Senate; Senator Crawford and Senator Foll also served longer, but only by a matter of months, than Ian Wood's 28 1/2 years.

He was elected Acting President of this chamber on one occasion in 1962 in the absence of the President and he served for 25 years as a Temporary Chairman of Committees. He was one of those people who eternally deplored the academic approach to politics, particularly in relation to polls. Ian Wood just would not be bothered reading a poll. He knew what was going on because he actively talked to people at all levels of society. He used to call it his political nous, but in reality it was his willingness and his ability to talk to people in all strata of society that gave him a good feeling as to where community interests lay. He would never follow polls, in the way so many inhabitants of this and the other chamber do, before coming to an opinion on what people were thinking or deciding what he should do.

Ian Wood was endowed with a strong sense of what was right and what was wrong in the community and on social issues. As has been mentioned, he was very independent in his point of view. If he varied from the judgment of his colleagues in the Liberal party room, Ian would tell them what he was doing and would follow the dictates of his conscience. Probably for that reason he never became a Minister, although he had the ability to become a Minister. I suppose that no great senators ever become Ministers because of this character of greatness in their souls, Senator Hill.

TALK.START.PARA: —You can all smile over there—

—When I look at Senator Button, I realise that Ian Wood was his equal or superior. However, his great claim to fame was as Chairman of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, which was set up in 1932. It was not the first one in the world, but certainly it was the prototype for other democratic parliaments to follow. Ian's continuous service as Chairman of that Committee for 25 years, except for the few years when the Whitlam Government was in power in the early 1970s, has never been equalled. He was certainly the creative driving force on the Committee. I think his service to that Committee is his most fitting memorial.

—I would very much like to be associated with the condolence motion for our former Senate colleague, Ian Wood. Only a handful of current senators served here at the same time as former Senator Wood. Ian Wood was in the Senate when I arrived in 1975 so I knew him as a fellow senator between that time and his retirement in 1977. I had met him before being elected to the Senate and met him on numerous occasions after his retirement.

PARA.TAB: I first became aware of former Senator Wood some time in the early 1960s. He and another honourable senator in the Menzies Government rebelled against an increase in sales tax on motor vehicles. For some time it appeared that the legislation would not pass the Senate and during this time former Senator Wood gained a great deal of publicity in Queensland. As was mentioned earlier, he was renowned in Mackay for shunning the use of motor vehicles and using a bicycle instead. I recall that, during the period when a sales tax Bill was stalled in the Senate, Ian Wood was asked on television what he would do if sales tax on bicycles were increased. The interviewer was obviously trying to embarrass Ian Wood but I recall that his reply was such that the interviewer himself was embarrassed. The sales tax Bill, incidentally, was eventually passed after the then Prime Minister had some words with his reluctant colleagues.

In his long period of service, ex-Senator Wood made significant contributions to the Senate. As has been mentioned earlier, perhaps his greatest energies were expended towards the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. It was not until I became a member of that Committee that I realised its importance to the parliamentary process. Ian Wood's long chairmanship of that Committee, no doubt, helped it to operate in the effective manner that it did and since has done.

It was a matter of some regret to me, having served in the Senate with Ian Wood, that I was not able to attend his funeral in Mackay. I was, at that time, in hospital for a brief period and it was suggested to me that my treatment would be interrupted if I went to Mackay even if only for the day. I extend to all of those who were close to Ian Wood my sympathy during the time of their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with this condolence motion for the late Senator Ian Wood. He was a man who had a profound effect on me as a young person. I did not know him personally, but I knew him by reputation and by the way in which he fought for his principles and for north Queensland. In my maiden speech, in making special mention of Ian Wood, I indicated that he was, as far as I was aware, the only Liberal senator from north Queensland prior to my coming to the Senate.
