PARA.TAB: He was a legend in his own time. He was mayor of Mackay for some 15 years. He had a very long and distinguished involvement in local government and, as my colleague Senator MacGibbon has mentioned, he introduced the first town planning scheme that operated in Australia. Indeed, he had a distinguished career as the President of the Queensland Local Government Association representing all local government authorities in Queensland and later as well as President of the Australian Local Government Association.

Ian Wood was always in the news fighting for his constituents whether or not it suited the party. He crossed the floor often—the most notable occasion being, as the previous speaker, Senator Colston, has mentioned, on the Government's sales tax on motor vehicles legislation; an event which I thought was even more remarkable when we remember that he only ever rode a bicycle.

He assisted me in the campaign when I came to this place and often recounted the heady times when he stood alone in the cause of his constituents. I was impressed by the way that Ian Wood, as a member of the Liberal Party, could cross the floor so readily when the interests of his constituents transcended the interests of the Liberal Party. That is one of the things that attracted me to the Liberal Party, and attracted many other people in this nation.

He had a long and distinguished career as a member of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, becoming a member the day after he entered Parliament and being Chairman of it for a very long period, broken only by the time that our side of politics was out of government. His career spanned those years from 22 February 1950 to 30 June 1978—a total of 28 1/2 years of very dedicated service to this nation, to this Parliament and to Queensland.

Before the late Senator Wood entered Parliament he was a member of the north Queensland Country Party and also a former Vice President of the Queensland branch of the Country Party before joining the Liberal Party in 1949. It is not inappropriate at this time of honouring this great Queenslander to raise the issue of unity of the progressive forces that are so essential to lead this nation into the next century. I again raise with my friends and colleagues in the National Party in Queensland the question which Ian Wood considered in his day of having the Country Party join the Liberal Party as the unified non-Labor party in Australia, for the good of all Australians and for the good of Australia as a whole.

It was a question for Ian Wood in the days when Robert Menzies was joining and gathering the non-Labor forces into the Liberal Party for the benefit of Australia, and to form that mighty organisation which has governed Australia so well and so long. It was the time for Ian Wood to make that decision and he considered the decision and decided that it was in the interests of his constituents that he join with the Liberal Party—a Party which he served so very loyally, subject only to the overriding loyalty of his constituents, for so many years.

I remember Ian Wood in recent years when I got to know him very well. In those recent years of his life he was still, at the age he was, a very active member of the Mackay branch of the Liberal Party and would attend most meetings that he was well enough to attend. He would often speak and he would often obtain a very interested audience whenever he spoke of those days and even of current issues. Even then he was called by his friends and colleagues `Senator' in recognition of his very long and distinguished career in this Parliament.

I last saw Senator Wood, if I may call him that, on 5 August last year following the annual general meeting of the Mackay branch of the Liberal Party when I drove him home from that meeting. We sat for almost three-quarters of an hour outside his house in Mackay talking about the old days, he giving me some advice on the Regulations and Ordinances Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he tell you to cross the floor?

—He did say to cross the floor where it was appropriate and where the interests of north Queensland diverged from those of my Party. I am sure that will never happen because the interests of my Party will always be for supporting north Queensland. Certainly Senator Wood did talk about those days and did give me advice along those lines, but particularly, and in a very serious way, about the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. I fondly remember helping him up the high steps of his house and farewelling him, as it turned out, for the very last time.

PARA.TAB: He certainly was a great Queenslander, a great person for the Mackay region. He was very instrumental in opening up the Barrier Reef to the ordinary Australian, if one might say that. He made it possible, through his interest in the tourist industry, for Australians all over to enjoy the wonders and the beauty that is the Barrier Reef and he will long be remembered in the Mackay area for his contribution to tourism.

I know Senator Wood did not have any close relatives, but I should extend my sympathies to the people of Mackay and the people of Australia on the passing of a very great Australian, a very great Queenslander.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Wood was a member of the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances for more than 28 years and was Chair of that Committee for a total of 22 years. I speak today as the present Chair of the Committee, with a mere six years of membership of the Committee behind me but with a deep consciousness of the tradition established by Senator Wood. Senator Wood made a tremendous contribution to the present reputation of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee, and not only a national reputation but also, as has already been said, an international reputation.

PARA.TAB: Many of the safeguards which the Australian people now enjoy and take for granted were initiated by the Committee under his leadership, and were only established against opposition from those whose commitment to these freedoms was less than that of Senator Wood. It is a tribute to Senator Wood that a person who left school at 12, as he did, to go to work to help his mother support the household, should play such an important role in the content and form of Commonwealth legislation. It is also a tribute to the Senate as an institution that he should be able to do so.

As Senator Hill has described, Senator Wood was particularly concerned that delegated legislation did not breach personal rights and liberties. I will briefly describe his considerable contribution in this area. Instruments of delegated legislation often include offence provisions, the penalties for breach of which are no less real than penalties imposed by Acts. Under Senator Wood the Committee ensured that offence provisions contained appropriate safeguards for those affected. Many instruments which came before the Committee were defective in relation to such safeguards.

In one case, individuals were required to give to an inspector such information as they possessed about an offence or a suspected offence. This was a violation of normal standards of personal freedom. A person is generally not required to give such information to anyone, even if arrested. Another instrument provided that the prosecution could amend its statement alleging an offence without giving the accused an opportunity to prepare to meet the new charge. Another replaced objective defences to a prosecution, which could be argued before an independent court, with the subjective opinion of a public official. All these provisions were the subject of caustic comment by Ian Wood.

Today it is commonplace that all important discretions vested in public officials, whether Ministers, statutory officers or public servants, should be subject to independent, external review of the merits of each exercise of the power. Present delegated legislation, due largely to the efforts of the Committee during Senator Wood's time, now usually provides for such review, normally to a specialist body such as the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. This ensures that individual rights and liberties are not subject to arbitrary or improper interference, however remote that possibility may be.

However, things were considerably different when Senator Wood was on the Committee. There were many examples of wide discretions not subject to review. With Senator Wood as Chair, these deficiencies were exposed. In one case, regulations totally prohibited an important area of economic activity unless the Minister granted a licence. These licences could be subject to conditions which could be varied or added to at any time and which could, and did, relate to matters occurring both before and years after the initial transaction. There were no criteria to guide the Minister in the exercise of the power which could be different for, and discriminate against, individuals in the same position.

The Minister could revoke a licence at any time. A licensing officer who was not the Minister could demand any sum of money that he or she thought fit as security for compliance with the conditions. The Minister could delegate his or her powers—there were not many women Ministers in those days. There was no provision for review of any decision and access to the ordinary courts was denied, apparently even where the Minister refused to consider an application or where there was unjust treatment or delay.

In another case there was no legal redress from a decision by an official which, effectively, resulted in a confiscation of property. Other instruments provided for people to be taken into custody and detained with no proper safeguards. There were many similar cases, usually with no provision for a right to be heard, no right of review and no redress to the ordinary courts unless an official acted wholly unreasonably or from corrupt or improper motives. Ian Wood took active steps to correct all these defects.

In conclusion, I remind the Senate of one of the best known deficiencies revealed by the Committee under Senator Wood. There was a Telecom by-law which had the admirable purpose of dealing with hoax calls to emergency services, but the unintended result of the actual drafting was to make it an offence to tell a lie over the telephone. There may have been times in the past when, in responding to an unwelcome invitation over the telephone, I, like countless other people, have been guilty of a small deception. Senator Wood's vigilance saved many of us from breaching Commonwealth law.

On behalf of the members of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee I extend our sympathies to Ian Wood's family and to his friends and well-wishers, of whom there are many on both sides of the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support my colleagues in paying respects to the late former senator Ian Wood. His reputation in the Mackay district and beyond was one of considerable significance. My own involvement in Mackay goes back some 22 years, so I am well aware of the work Senator Wood did in his earlier days in his local government capacity.

PARA.TAB: His career in the Senate spanned 28 years, and for many of those years he served as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, of which, as Senator Giles said, he was Chairman for 20 years. He built the Committee into a powerful parliamentary force and never hesitated to use its capacity if he believed it was warranted.

Talking to Senator Wood in latter years I discovered that, fearing that the influence and prestige of the Senate chamber would be damaged if the 1967 referendum to break the two to one constitutional nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate were carried, he helped prepare the No case. Success, he believed, would have meant that the number of members of the House of Representatives would be increased without increasing the number of senators. As honourable senators would know, the referendum failed in every State but New South Wales by a margin of more than one million votes. On many occasions Ian Wood indicated to me how proud he was to be involved in the preparation of the No case.

He was, as indicated by Senator Button and others, a political maverick. He will best be remembered for his devotion to the State of Queensland and his beloved Mackay. I am sure that at times many of his colleagues must have been exasperated by his strengths: his independence and his non-conformist principles.

I first got to know Ian Wood well in late 1984 and made a habit of calling to see him on my many visits to Mackay. He attended political meetings until towards the end of last year, as Senator Macdonald said. His gift for speaking out was not in any way diminished when he retired from the Senate. He retained his interest in tourism, Mackay and Queensland to the date of his death. He ran a very successful travel agency called Wood's Travel Agency in, appropriately, Wood Street, Mackay, which I am sure was named after him. He never owned a motor car, and he was a non-drinker and a non-smoker. He travelled to and from work and around Mackay on his well-known bike.

Ian Wood was a great Australian, he was a great Queenslander, and he was a champion of Mackay and its environs. As Senator Macdonald said, he was ahead of his time in promoting the Great Barrier Reef. I can recall that 20 years ago no-one expected the growth in tourism to the Barrier Reef north and south of Cairns that has occurred. Ian Wood always had great optimism about the potential of the Barrier Reef. Although it was Captain Cook who named the Whitsunday Islands, the promotion of the area came from Ian Wood. To some degree he had an interest in it, I suppose, because of his major interest in the travel agency he had for most of his life.

As my colleague Senator Macdonald said, Ian Wood never married; he lived with his sister until she died a few years ago. I therefore offer my condolences to the people of Mackay, to whom he made such a massive contribution over nearly 90 years of his life.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased that Senator Parer raised the matter of the nexus referendum in 1966. This was one of the occasions when Ian Wood was in a minority in this place but was proven right. The majority of people in all the States except New South Wales said so. It was not the first or the only occasion Ian Wood was in the minority. I acknowledge the work done by other senators in 1966 in preparing the No case for the nexus referendum, although it was before my time.

PARA.TAB: When I came to this place I knew of Ian Wood by reputation. As Senator Button said, he and Reg Wright were quite a formidable pair. I used to have regular conversations with both of them about matters of common interest. Being an independent by nature and name, I was able to learn a few of the old tricks from Ian Wood, the lanky Queenslander, and from Reg Wright, the rotund Tasmanian. I am sure a lot of their influence rubbed off not only on me but also on other honourable senators who came in at that time, including Senator Walters.

We understood clearly that this was a chamber that was originally designed to uphold the rights of the States so that the smaller, less populated States particularly would not be swamped by the numbers in the House of Representatives. That lesson was clearly imparted by Ian Wood, both by what he had to say and by what he did. That was a service not only to the people of his State but also to the people in all of the States, particularly the less populous States, and it was a service to the Senate.

I am concerned, however, that I did not know of Ian Wood's death, nor of former senator Geoff McLaren's death, until I read it on the Notice Paper today. I have stood here before and made that point: nothing has been done about it. I have asked whether some system could be arranged in this place so that honourable senators are informed of the death of colleagues. I am sorry that that did not transpire on this occasion.

I ask again, Madam Acting Deputy President, whether you would ask the President to ensure that in future members of the Senate are informed of the death of former senators and former members of the House of Representatives. I am not asking that he necessarily inform us beforehand. I would like to know whether persons are close to death. Last year I heard that Ian Wood was not well. I ask you, Madam Acting Deputy President, to inform the President of my wish to be informed of the death of former colleagues.
I have much pleasure in supporting this motion of condolence.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the present Deputy Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances, I would like to be associated with the condolence motion for former senator Ian Wood. Because I hold that position, I see daily examples of delegated legislation with high standards of drafting, content and accessibility. These standards are largely based on those established by Senator Wood during his 28 years on the Committee, with 22 of those years as Chairman. Of course, we also see daily examples of low quality delegated legislation, but this is because those basic principles established by the Committee under Senator Wood have been disregarded.

PARA.TAB: The contribution of Senator Wood to Commonwealth legislation was not limited to the technical quality of individual instruments. It had a general beneficial effect on public administration. Ian Wood was keenly aware of the actual effect of delegated legislation and was critical of any obvious administrative deficiencies.

The type of administrative procedure which Senator Wood deplored and largely remedied is illustrated by a set of regulations which allowed a statutory authority to make deductions from money owed by the Commonwealth to individuals. In this case the Committee found that the regulations were not authorised by the parent Act; that they made substantial alterations of the law which were appropriate only to an Act; and that they provided for deduction of unlimited funds without giving the person affected an opportunity to be heard or to present a case, and there was no right of review. In addition, the statutory authority could delegate its powers. In another case, regulations provided for compensation to building owners whose buildings were ordered to be removed or altered by a statutory authority, but did not provide for compensation to owners who were prevented from altering their buildings.
In those days it was also quite common for delegated legislation to provide for public

SPEECH.PARA: officials to waive fees and charges at their complete discretion, with no criteria to guide and limit this power, no requirement for a statement of reasons, and with no review. Under the chairmanship of Senator Wood, the Committee also found instances where Commonwealth money had been spent without authorisation. This is still not uncommon today.

PARA.TAB: The response of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee under Senator Wood to these forms of public administration was direct and practical. It was quite common for the Committee to ask senior public servants, such as the Parliamentary Draftsman, to appear before it to explain individual provisions. After one such session—not with the Parliamentary Draftsman—the Committee suggested that the Senate may wish to conduct an inquiry into the administration of individual sections of a particular department. In other cases, after scrutinising the delegated legislation, the Committee made practical suggestions about the operation of particular programs.

In short, Senator Wood contributed to a much fairer and more efficient public administration in Australia. His legacy will be remembered long and well. I accordingly extend my sympathies to those who personally remember him and by whom he will be missed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also express my regret at the death of former senator Ian Wood. As a new member in this chamber in 1987, I was appointed to the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills and the Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. I served on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee for my first parliamentary term; I am still a member of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee. One could not be a member of that Committee and not learn of the work of Senator Ian Wood. In fact, his name is one that I have heard more often than any other in my five years in this chamber. When I go to schools to talk about the role of the Senate and especially about the scrutiny of legislation, I talk about the importance of separating out one's role as a parliamentarian and one's role as a politician.

PARA.TAB: Today we have heard Senator Ian Wood described as a maverick and other such things. I would describe him, from the illustrations I have been given around this place, as an example of a parliamentarian, a person who could take off his political hat and put on his parliamentary hat in making the decisions that were made in regulations and ordinances in particular.

I appreciate the great contribution made by Senator Wood to Commonwealth legislation. That contribution has resulted in a permanent and beneficial improvement to personal rights and liberties and to parliamentary propriety. I do not think that was gained lightly or easily. Those on the other side of the chamber who have chaired the Regulations and Ordinances Committee will know that one does not win many pixie points for going to one's own Minister and telling him that subordinate legislation is not acceptable in the eyes of the Committee.

Senator Ian Wood and Senator Messner played a very important part in establishing the strength of that Committee. One of its former secretaries describes very clearly the role that both those people played, but in particular Senator Wood, in the development of the Committee. During his chairmanship, Senator Wood crossed the floor a number of times to ensure that the Committee's recommendations were adhered to. In fact, he established and set in concrete the tradition that when the Regulations and Ordinances Committee moves for disallowance of a regulation it almost always goes unquestioned in the Senate and the Committee wins.

As people have said, that Committee has been recognised overseas. When Senator Giles, Senator Crowley, Senator Bishop and I attended the last Commonwealth conference on delegated legislation, it was obvious that Australia was leading the Westminster world in the scrutiny of legislation and delegated legislation. That is in no small part due to the very significant influence Ian Wood had on that Committee and its role.

I shall give a couple of short examples of his concerns about parliamentary propriety. The very first report made by Senator Wood as Chairman drew attention to the considerable danger for parliamentary propriety of what is often called quasi-legislation. The report described an increasing tendency for Acts to provide for legislative instruments that are subject to neither tabling nor disallowance. Such instruments are really not quasi-legislation but legislation properly so-called. In recent years, there has been a general effort to formalise such instruments and bring them within parliamentary scrutiny.

Important developments in this area were the establishment of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in 1982 and the Administrative Review Council interim report last year on rule making by Commonwealth agencies. This is now much less of a problem than it was. However, it should be acknowledged that Senator Wood identified this danger almost 40 years ago. Indeed, the Committee at that time suggested the same course as the ARC now recommends, which is a statement of criteria to determine which instruments should be subject to tabling and disallowance.

Another area of parliamentary propriety that concerned Senator Wood was the tendency for delegated legislation to express policy rather than administrative detail. The Committee was particularly vigilant to ensure that regulations should not deal with substantive legislation. This is also a matter that has now been addressed by the ARC.

Many of the practices and procedures established under Senator Wood continue to the present as undertakings under which the Regulations and Ordinances Committee still operates. For instance, it is a breach of parliamentary propriety if delegated legislation is not in accordance with the parent Act. Under Senator Wood, the Committee decided that this would not be interpreted in a narrow, legalistic fashion to mean merely that an instrument was valid. Rather, the Committee adopted the view that an instrument may be valid but still breach its principles because of an unusual or unexpected use of the powers conferred by the Act. The Committee sensibly acknowledged that legal validity is a subject on which opinions differ and which can finally be decided only by a court. Therefore, decades later the Committee is still using the standards first established during Senator Wood's stewardship.

It is with great interest that I note that the two senators who contributed most to the development of the Regulations and Ordinances Committee have been Liberal senators, a tradition they have set that I hope will be followed by honourable senators on both sides of this chamber. I know, as a member of that Committee, that the tradition they set of enabling us to take off our political hats and put on our parliamentary hats and to discuss issues in that Committee without hindering it with issues of policy is a tradition Senator Wood set. I hope I can leave this chamber with the sort of record he had as a parliamentarian. I extend my condolences to those who cared for him and to the people of Mackay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the condolence motion for my late colleague Ian Wood, formerly a senator of this place for 28 years. I remember the first party meeting I attended back in 1976. I came here towards the end of the first year of the Fraser Government and I was a little concerned about some areas of dissent. We had such a majority in the Senate as well as in the House of Representatives that there seemed to be a bit of crossing the floor, and I did not approve of that very much. I made some reference to it in my preselection speech for my Party.

PARA.TAB: At my first party meeting three older gentlemen stood up and gave Malcolm Fraser one of the greatest serves I had ever heard about some issue that was before the meeting. I thought, `What on earth is going on here?' The first fellow was Sir Reginald Wright; I did recognise him. The second fellow was Bill Wentworth. The third person was a bloke I had never seen before, but it turned out to be Woody. They really did not mess around.

I recall coming into the chamber on many occasions thereafter and repeatedly seeing Senator Wood and Senator Wright crossing the floor over many issues. I might say, Mr Deputy President, that they were encouraged by members of your Party. The Labor Party seemed to take great delight in seeing these fellows cross the floor. All I can say to members of the Labor Party is that these fellows did not need any encouragement. They could cross the floor at the drop of a hat; they had been doing so for many years. After all, Senator Wood had been here since 1950.

When Senator Wood arrived in this place in 1950 probably the first job he was given was not just to join but to become chairman of the Senate Regulations and Ordinances Committee. He remained chairman for the whole of his parliamentary career when we were in government. The only time he was not chairman was when the Labor Party was in government from 1972 to 1975. He was on that Committee for 28 1/2 years, of which he had 25 1/2 years as chairman.

I was lucky enough to be his successor. I can assure the Senate that he gave me an enormous earbashing about what I had to do as chairman of that Committee in standing up to Ministers. His complaint was not so much that Ministers would sign regulations that ought to have been disallowed, but that clearly the Ministers were not really studying the regulations before they signed them. His main complaint was about the bureaucracy. For his whole parliamentary career he was extremely critical of it. He was critical about the way in which the bureaucracy put before Ministers for signature regulations which very frequently interfered with the fundamental rights of ordinary citizens.

Ian Wood and Reg Wright gave me advice about how to make a clear distinction between a parliamentarian and a politician. It is not a distinction which is recognised in the general world but it is recognised in this chamber, where people are acting as parliamentarians. Unfortunately, under the current rigours of the party system which we now have imposed upon us, probably from within as well as by the media, there is much less crossing of the floor than occurred in those days. Perhaps Senator Wood could be described as one of the last true parliamentarians. I believe that he crossed the floor well over 100 times in his career.

Senator Murphy referred to Senator Wood's reputation as an upholder of personal rights and the parliamentary institutions as probably being unsurpassed in this country. That is not a bad reference from Senator Murphy. Senator Wheeldon, another Labor senator, said that Senator Wood had been hailed as someone who `made a major contribution to democracy in this country'.

As I have mentioned, Senator Wood's major concern was about `the passing of the power of this Parliament into the hands of the civil service or the Executive' and the need to `fight to retain powers in the hands of Parliament'. He did this right throughout his career. In 1965, during the time of Menzies, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is surprising that the Menzies Government should be guilty of quite a long list of attempts at erosion of the powers of the parliament when we remember that before we came to office in 1949 we talked about bureaucrats and so on. I am afraid that this Government has done as much as anyone to build up the bureaucracy as against what we consider the basis of real democracy.

He was critical of Sir Robert Menzies as Prime Minister. If we look at his career, we will see that he was critical of every Liberal Prime Minister. Senator Withers once said of him that it was under Senator Wood that senators old and new `learnt that occasionally one should stay with principle and not with one's party'. There is no doubt that we certainly learned those sorts of views from Senator Wood. In 1973 Senator Withers said of him:

The quality of his service was not just in the fact that he was a good and active Chairman and that he enjoyed his work; the quality of service resided more in the fact that he had the courage to face his colleagues in government, to disagree with them and to come into this place and vote according to his conscience. No higher tribute could be paid to any senator.

As has been mentioned, Senator Wood was a self-educated man. He served for a long period as an alderman and a very long period as senator. There is no doubt that he made a great contribution to this nation.

PARA.TAB: One of the stories that I heard about him, which has never really been contradicted, relates to Sir Robert Menzies. At the first Party meeting in the old Parliament House after the Liberals had retained office after quite a fight, Sir Robert told old and new Party members that he hoped that they would vote with the Government, but that if anyone truly felt that the Government was wrong that person had no alternative but to vote according to his conscience. Ian Wood frequently said that he was the only one who carried out Sir Robert Menzies' direction in this regard.

As early as 1959, Ian Wood drew attention to the danger that he saw of the control of Parliament slipping from the hands of the parliamentarians and Parliament being run by the civil servants. In the same debate, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is no keener supporter of the Liberal-Country Party side of the Senate than I, but I am not so blind as to believe that every amendment suggested is an affront to the government. That is not my outlook on parliamentary life.
I would like to thank one of the Senate officers for looking up some of these quotes for me. In 1967, he said:

I did not come into this Parliament to be a yes man. I hold it to be my duty as a senator to make a decision on what is the right thing for this country. When a thing is right for the country it is my duty to vote for it. If a thing is not right for the country it is my duty to vote against it.
In 1970 he said:

I have represented Queensland since 1949 and I have done what lots of people in this chamber have not been prepared to do: I have voted according to my conscience, even if it meant that I was to be thrown out of the Parliament. It is to the credit of the Liberal Party that we have the freedom to express our conscience and it is to the credit of the Liberal Party that I have been re-endorsed time after time. Only about three months ago when it was last thought that I had been written off I was then endorsed for the forthcoming Senate election as No. 1 on the Queensland Senate ticket.
Senator Tate should have been voting according to his conscience; if he had, he might have ended up with a higher place than No. 4 on the Tasmanian Senate ticket. In 1971 Senator Wood said:
I understand that in this debate—
this related to a report of the Standing Orders Committee—

there is to be a free vote, but judging from the last division which took place, it is amazing how many senators on the one side of the chamber appeared to hold the same views. Of course it might be that they are unanimous in their opinions, but it seems rather strange to me that such a thing happened when we had what is termed a free vote. As far as I am concerned a free vote is one in which a person exercises his conscience. On this side of the chamber we are supposed to have freedom of conscience. Probably some senators consider that they exercised that freedom. I exercise my freedom of conscience at all times and therefore I do not require a special free vote. It is something that the Liberal Party is supposed to have but it is not always very evident.
One can see that he was inclined to give us a serve at the drop of a hat.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I would like to make reference to two things he said just prior to the end of his career. In 1977 he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It should be the aim of everyone who comes here—
meaning this Parliament—
to work in order to leave this Parliament a better place than he found it. That should be the ideal for all Parliamentarians.
Finally, in 1978 shortly before he retired from the Senate, he said:

I am now serving my 29th year in this Chamber. . . I have not been afraid to express an opposite view to the view of my party when in government or in opposition. I believe that if parliamentarians, in particular honourable Senators, generally follow that course the public would have a higher estimation of us as parliamentarians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I ask honourable senators to stand in silence to signify their assent to the motion.

PARA.TAB: Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with deep regret that I inform the Senate of the death, on 30 January 1992, of former Senator Geoffrey Thomas McLaren, Senator for the State of South Australia from 1971 to 1983. I call upon the Leader of the Government in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate expresses its deep regret at the death, on Thursday 30 January 1992, of Geoffrey Thomas McLaren, Senator for the State of South Australia from 1971 to 1988, places on record its appreciation of his long and meritorious public service and tenders its profound sympathy to his family in their bereavement.

SPEECH.PARA: Geoffrey McLaren was born on 1 February 1921 at Koroit in Victoria. He was educated at Koroit and Woolsthorpe State schools. Before entering Federal Parliament he worked for over 20 years as a shearer, then as a poultry farmer for several years, which earned him the nickname in this place of `Feathers'—an expression by which he was affectionately described by all, I think, on both sides of the Parliament.

PARA.TAB: He was elected to the Senate for South Australia in 1970, although he did not begin his term until 1971. During his time here he worked on several committees, amongst them the Industry and Trade Committee, the National Resources Committee and the Joint Committee on the Northern Territory. He was also a member of the House Committee for over eight years and served on nearly all the Estimates committees at some stage. He was a counsellor at the IPU meeting at Prague in 1976 and a member at the IPU conference at Caracas in 1979. In addition to that, he held the position in the Labor Party of Secretary of the Labor Party Resources Committee from 1976 to 1981, he was President of the Murray Bridge sub-branch of the ALP from 1957 and Chairman of the Murray District Assembly also from 1957. There was a memorial function for Geoff McLaren in Murray Bridge last Sunday and I understand that Senator Walsh and Senator Schacht attended in company with former Senator Bishop.

I think we all have our personal memories of Geoff McLaren. I always used to say, `I keep a black book, Geoff, and you're in it. You're the only person who's in it', because he was the most prodigious speaker in the adjournment debate. Almost every night when most of us were tired and wanted to go home, even if there were no other senators speaking, in the course of a week he was always speaking and I kept a black book about that. I must say that I held it against him and, if I might say so with respect, still do.

It was once, I think, said of Gordon Scholes when he was Speaker of the House of Representatives that he was the only Speaker who had attempted from the Chair to amend a question at Question Time, and Geoff was a bit like that too. He was a great taker of points of order and participated in a very lively fashion in the debates in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Don't forget the quorums.

—Of course, yes, I thank Senator MacGibbon, there was the calling of quorums. There used to be certain issues which inflamed Geoff's passions. I think we all used to fear in this place that somebody would touch on one of those issues because we could then be sure of a much longer and more virulent debate than otherwise would have occurred, but that I think is a tribute to him. He was a very involved, sincere, dedicated person and he believed in what he did and said here. I think we can all recall him with that degree of admiration for the time which he spent here.

PARA.TAB: His first speech in the chamber covered the issues about which he was most concerned. They were the Australian worker—particularly the rural worker—the plight of the people on the land and the rights of Aboriginals. He continued to fight for those issues and support good causes in respect of those people throughout his time in this place.
I think we all remember him with affection and, on behalf of the Government, I extend our sincere sympathy to his wife, Beryl, and his family in their bereavement.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Opposition, I join with Senator Button in expressing our regret at the recent death of Geoff McLaren, a former senator for South Australia. He took his place in the Senate at the same time as I took mine, on 1 July 1971, having been elected, as Senator Button has said, at the Senate elections which were held on their own in 1970.

PARA.TAB: His career before he came into the Senate was as a shearer and then, of course, he became a poultry farmer. I think he probably continued to maintain a very close interest in all matters relating to rural Australia and also, I understand, in poultry farming.

Despite the fact that I sat in the Senate for over 12 years with Geoff McLaren, I must confess that I never really got to know him particularly well. He was, however, a Senate character for most of the reasons Senator Button has already mentioned. Clearly, he was a self-made man with a tremendous vitality about his whole character and attitude to whatever issue he took up. He certainly was a most doughty fighter for those Australians in agricultural areas and had great interest in issues affecting them on a wide scale.

He obviously had very great sympathy as well for the ordinary man and woman on the land. He understood their trials and problems and felt them very deeply and emotionally. He sat on the National Resources Committee from March 1976 until I think he retired from the Senate, so he had a particular opportunity there to follow his interests. As a member of that Committee he would have worked in the same tireless way as he did in the Senate.

Geoff McLaren was dedicated to Senate Estimates committees. Indeed, he is not the only senator I have known who has been dedicated to Estimates committees and who has asked questions over many days. Senator McLaren also maintained that devotion to the examination of estimates in the Committee of the Whole as well, and continued the debate for a very long time in this chamber even after having explored those matters in the Estimates committee hearings themselves. That factor was not unique to Senator McLaren, as there are other senators who are in that category. However, for many of those years he was in government rather than in opposition. Indeed, he was the champion of champions in persisting with questions on the appropriations both in Estimate committees and in this chamber. It was a very good example of his capacity for hard work, dedication and determination to achieve whatever goal he had in mind.

I do not recall with the same strong feeling as does Senator Button the penchant of Senator McLaren for adjournment debates, but again there are many other senators with a similar penchant and Senator McLaren's role was not particularly outstanding in that sense. But in his persistence with Estimates, I believe that in the time that I have been in this chamber he was the champion estimator, if I may so term it.

He also achieved a certain fame for a short time in the Senate early in his career when he, in company with former Senators Keeffe and Poyser, decided there was a need for major dress reform in the Senate. I know that that theme has been taken up by other senators in this place.

TALK.START.PARA: —Hear, hear!

—Including Senator Schacht, who has just commended the idea. I can inform Senator Schacht that he is an old square compared with Senator McLaren and Senators Poyser and Keeffe. They all came into the Senate on one warm day in summer wearing their shorts, open-neck shirts and short sleeves and shook this place to its foundations. I was very pleased when that fashion did not take on, and indeed they themselves gave up on it. For a man of such determination as Geoff McLaren to have given up on his campaign for dress reform must be strong proof that it was not a successful idea. It was somewhat out of character for Geoff McLaren to be thought of or remembered as a reformer of dress in the Senate or, indeed, elsewhere.

PARA.TAB: Geoff McLaren was also a devoted family man; he was devoted to his wife and children. I always noticed the extent to which his wife supported him throughout his political career. Indeed, she spent a good deal of time in Canberra in her support of him. She supported him in this chamber and in this town as well as in his life generally away from his major interests in rural Australia. No doubt the support of his wife and family were of great assistance and comfort to him. I take this opportunity of extending on behalf of myself and my colleagues deep sympathy to Geoff McLaren's widow, children, grandchildren and, I understand, great grandchildren in their bereavement.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to associate National Party senators with the condolence motion that has been moved by the Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) concerning Geoff McLaren. I entered Parliament in 1983 when Geoff McLaren left this place. Therefore, I did not have the experience of meeting the former senator. But the senator's reputation preceded him and certainly existed long after he left. When the subject of Estimates committees came up long after he had gone, people used to mention the name of `Feathers' McLaren in some sort of awe. He was known for his exploitation of Senate Estimates committees.

PARA.TAB: Geoff McLaren spent nearly 12 years as a senator. He came from South Australia, entered the Senate in 1971 and did not seek re-election in 1983. He was a staunch representative of the Australian Labor Party and during his time in the Senate was always forthright in supporting the causes in which he believed. His contribution to the Senate reflected his interest in rural matters. He was one of the few people in the Labor Party who had experience in primary industry or rural pursuits. He fought for the people in rural areas to the best of his ability within the party structure and in this Parliament. He was a shearer and later became a poultry farmer. I extend the sympathy of the National Party in the Senate to the family of the former senator.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join with other senators who have already spoken and with others who no doubt will speak in this motion of condolence for former senator Geoffrey Thomas McLaren. I did not know him and, so far as I am aware, neither did the other Australian Democrat senators. However, I have listened to the other speakers testifying to his record of service in the Senate and I am sure he served this place extremely well, particularly in those areas that have been highlighted by other speakers. Other speakers have mentioned that he leaves behind a widow and children. The Democrat senators wish to join with others who have spoken on this motion.

—Geoff McLaren was a member of the Senate for some three years when I was elected. He was one of the first people, apart from some Western Australians, whom I got to know and with whom I became friendly. Geoff McLaren and I shared a country background and a record of prior employment as manual workers. Partly for that reason, we had common policy interests.

PARA.TAB: During his life Geoff was many things: he was a fruit picker, a shearer, a soldier, a poultry farmer and, finally, a Labor politician. He was an old-fashioned Labor man, an appellation that he himself would have been very happy to accept. He had empathy for ordinary working people, the working class, if that term is preferred, and a keen appreciation of their values and aspirations. I think that if Geoff were alive today he would probably say that there is too little of that in the contemporary Australian Labor Party, a judgment with which I tend to agree.

Geoff McLaren had a tribal loyalty to the ALP. He used his boundless energy to proselytise and organise for it in the Parliament and in South Australia, particularly in the country areas. He pursued issues with great tenacity, a point which has been noted by other speakers. He was a large consumer of time on adjournment debates, first reading debates and Estimates committees. Other speakers have noted that he was not alone in being such a large consumer of time. There are people in the Senate who still do that. However, I would suggest that there is a qualitative difference between the two. The people who do that today do it principally for reasons of self-aggrandisement; Geoff McLaren did it for other reasons.

At the commemorative afternoon held at his home in Murray Bridge last Sunday, Graham Maguire, in opening the comments by the various people there, said that we should regard that event as a celebration of the life of Geoff McLaren. I thought that was a very good way to look at it and an attitude which those of us who were his friends should bear in mind. His death was somewhat premature—shortly before his seventy-first birthday. However, his illness was short. I am sure that Geoff would have been one of the last people who would have liked to have lived a long period but spend many years of it in ill health, even helpless, and not able to live the full and active life which he did live right up until about six weeks before his death. To his wife Beryl and the rest of his family, I endorse the sympathies and the sentiments that the other speakers have expressed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to be associated with this motion. Geoff McLaren was a good senator. He knew his duties and he performed and pursued his responsibilities absolutely relentlessly, robustly and professionally. He was a formidable opponent who did his homework and did it very well. He was an example to us all for the way he did his homework. Geoff was well educated and knew the background of what he was dealing with. He knew the people he represented and had the practical experience to go with it. Geoff McLaren had both feet in the real world, and what he knew and how he got here were of his own making. He did things very well.

PARA.TAB: When I came into the Senate in 1976 Geoff McLaren was one of a group of quite colourful characters. People such as Bill Brown, Jim Cavanagh, Tony Mulvihill, the young and virile Peter Walsh and Geoff looked pretty tough stuff from the other side of the chamber. Looking back, I am sure that they really were. I regret, and it is a pity, that people of that calibre and background no longer get representation in this place.

I remember very well the tussles at Estimates committees and on the adjournment. I remember the way that Geoff McLaren used to be able to quote the Standing Orders from A to Z at any time, how he had the uncanny knack of knowing when quorums would be difficult and of using the rights that the Standing Orders gave him.

Geoff McLaren was absolutely relentless on the issues that he believed he should follow. However, he had a great sense of humour and was always good for a joke at someone else's expense or just jokes of any sort. I believe that that sort of sense of humour is essential for people who expect to stay in this place for any length of time and who want to be able to work and live at the same time. Most of all, I remember him for the work that he did. He worked and worked and worked. I do not think I have ever known anybody who worked harder than Geoff, particularly when he did not have a natural talent in this area in the first place. But he certainly put in the time and produced a lot to show for it. He represented his constituency very well indeed.

For some time Geoff and I had adjoining offices. That helped us to get to know one another much better. We always used to pop in and out of one another's offices. I remember the many discussions that we had on matters in which we had a mutual interest. It did not matter that we came from opposite sides of the chamber. If it was a matter to do with an interest group Geoff McLaren wanted to try to help it. I was the same. I found on those occasions that we could discuss things openly and clearly with one another in a totally non-political way. I was very pleased to enjoy that degree of confidence with him.

I respected Geoff McLaren as a very hard working colleague and formidable opponent. I certainly regret his passing. I have special thoughts for Beryl at this time. Again, because we were neighbours in the passage, we saw much of her. She was always good for a cup of tea at the right time. The Senate was certainly a lesser place when Geoff left it. I look forward to there being replacements of that nature in this chamber in time to come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would very much like to support the motion of condolence at the passing of former Senator Geoff McLaren. Geoff was elected to the Senate in 1970 and took his place on 1 July 1971, over four years before I arrived after the 1975 election. However, as there was a double dissolution in 1975, Geoff was a candidate at that election, and as well as becoming Senate colleagues we became firm personal friends.

PARA.TAB: Geoff was a great battler for the Australian Labor Party and never let an opportunity of embarrassing his opponents pass by. I remember very well how during Senate debates Geoff would leave the chamber and soon return with documents from his own files to refute the arguments of his opponents. He did this regularly and must have developed a remarkable filing system. It was certainly better than mine. Over the past few days I have searched in vain for certain contributions of Geoff in Hansard. I know that they must be there because I can remember his making the remarks as though they were made yesterday. Unfortunately, the Hansard retrieval system goes back only so far and many of Geoff's gems in Hansard are in parts which have not yet been computerised.

Life was never dull in the Senate while Geoff McLaren was there. Whether his presence was appreciated by his opponents is another matter. His overriding ambition was to see Labor returned to government after its defeat in 1975. He was not in the Parliament when that occurred, having retired when the double dissolution of 1983 was announced. Although he was no longer a senator, he retained an abiding interest in politics.

I have many fond memories of Geoff's performance in the Senate. I shall not go into great detail about those memories on this occasion for, with Geoff, it is hard not to recall those events in a non-party political manner. But those memories will remain, particularly with those of us who had the opportunity to be on the same side of the chamber as Geoff.

Many of us were often amused when Geoff would ask questions based on a newspaper called, I seem to remember, the Border Watch. Quite often his questions would carry the assumption that the Border Watch was the ultimate reference on a particular topic. I have no doubt that the Border Watch was a respected and well-known newspaper in the area where Geoff lived in South Australia, but it was hardly prescribed reading for other honourable senators.

As mentioned earlier, Geoff was good naturedly referred to as `Feathers', due to one of his former occupations as a poultry farmer. I can remember well when former Senator Douglas McClelland, who had—and indeed still has—a marvellous sense of humour, was highly amused about an interchange which took place when I was complaining about the lack of post office facilities at Hungerford in south western Queensland. Before I quote from Hansard, I mention that in those days Queensland did not have Lotto or, as we call it in Queensland, Gold Lotto, so there is a reference in here to explain what Lotto is. I pick up towards the end of my speech where I say:

SPEECH.PARA: Against the background of the possibility of Hungerford's losing its post office, I came into Parliament House this week and was absolutely amazed when I went down to our own post office in Parliament House and found that it is now an agent for Lotto. For those who are not aware what Lotto is—I imagine that some of my constituents in Queensland will not be—it is a type of lottery, or what we in Queensland call the Golden Casket. Where are our priorities? After 112 years Hungerford will lose its post office. After 53 years we in Parliament House, through our post office, will have an agency for Lotto.
Senator Geoff McLaren then said:
How about chook raffles?
I replied:
As Senator McLaren so appropriately says, we will soon have chook raffles.
I do not know whether or not the humour was subtle, but Doug, who immediately saw the feathers connection, certainly enjoyed it.

PARA.TAB: As with many members of parliament, a good deal of Geoff's work went unnoticed. I remember when he enlisted my support to expose a charlatan who was working out of Queensland and who had defrauded one of Geoff's constituents in South Australia. He and I worked on this matter for some time. Eventually the unscrupulous character was exposed and an end was put to his activities.

I last saw Geoff less than a year ago at Barcaldine during the centenary celebrations for the Australian Labor Party. It was a mark of Geoff's commitment to the Labor movement that, with his wife Beryl, he took his caravan all the way from South Australia to be present for the celebrations. It is a reminder of the uncertainty of the future that, when I renewed acquaintances with Geoff at Barcaldine, I had no inkling that I would be speaking so soon on a condolence motion for his passing. If I had not been out of the country at the time, I would have paid my respects at Geoff's funeral.

Although Geoff often mentioned his family to me, I did not meet them. I do, however, extend my condolences to them for their loss. I do know Beryl well and I offer to her my sincere sympathy at the time of her bereavement. It may be a little comforting for Beryl and her family to know that Geoff will be sadly missed by his former colleagues, but that the fond memories he left us will remain.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the condolence motion and to convey my sympathy to the relatives and friends of the late Geoffrey McLaren. Geoff was always a jovial character who, in common with the rugged tradition of shearers, always appreciated a good joke. As a vigorous supporter of ALP doctrine, he always applied his energies in a very robust manner. However, after the debate was finished, he saw no point in pursuit of his chamber-built-up consternation and returned to his usual conviviality.

PARA.TAB: Not long ago these corridors rang with Geoff's distinctive voice as we renewed old friendships in the new Parliament House, without a hint of trouble or difficulty. Geoff's sudden passing demonstrates to us all just how short and uncertain is our passage on this earth.

Geoff will be remembered for two great attributes which he displayed during his 12 years in the Senate. One was his desire to help people. His family played an important role in this, and they were extremely precious to him. He cared deeply for them. He applied his same caring attitudes to the many country people who came to him for help. Secondly, he made a daily habit of reading the whole of the Hansard. Consequently, he always knew all sides of the issues and would comment frequently, particularly on the adjournment, on the issues of the previous day. Like a heeler dog, his persistence in questioning earned him a special notoriety in the old Parliament House, especially during the Senate Estimates hearings. Perhaps the greatest tribute for those who remain is to follow those two important practices of Geoff's.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak in support of this condolence motion for former Senator Geoff McLaren. I knew Geoff McLaren not as a senator in this place but as a party official in the State branch of South Australia. For much of the time Geoff was a senator, I was either the State Secretary or Assistant State Secretary or State organiser of the Labor Party in South Australia. I spent many occasions in the rural areas of South Australia with Geoff. I remember as a very young organiser in 1970 going on an organising trip to the west coast of South Australia and discovering that Geoff's idea of a good start to each day's work was to rise at five and be on the road at six. I must say that I had always thought that 5 o'clock in the morning was the time for one to go to bed and that one would get up at about 10. Geoff started early, worked hard all day and went to bed early. So it took some cultural adjustment for me to get into the rhythm of Geoff's work.

PARA.TAB: I have to say, as a former party official, that in my time in the Labor Party in South Australia no senator or member of parliament has worked harder than Geoff in the non-metropolitan areas of South Australia on behalf of the Labor Party. Geoff at one stage used to put out a leaflet saying that he was the only senator elected in South Australia who had his electoral office in the non-metropolitan area. He used to make that point very strongly against Opposition members, who all had their offices in King William Street. Geoff was the first person to have a senator's office outside the metropolitan area. Now many of us have followed suit in one form or another and have our offices in the suburbs or elsewhere.

Geoff's activities in the rural areas were well known. He established enormous credibility in the rural community. He had a mailing list for his newsletter that ran into thousands. Every month or so he would mail out a newsletter outlining issues, and if one called into the McLaren household one would often find him and Beryl up at all hours of the night stuffing envelopes with his newsletter. Not only Geoff but the McLaren family were great supporters of the Labor Party. In everything Geoff did he was strongly supported by Beryl in particular, who was a great strength to him, and his other family members, particularly Harold and Doug.

I understand his reputation as a member of the Estimates Committee. When we were in opposition I heard the legion stories of Geoff being able to keep an Estimates committee hearing going hour after hour after hour, and, as Senator Walsh said, not just for the sake of longevity but as a tenacious operator seeking information on issues that he believed important.

I attended the commemorative service at Geoff McLaren's home last Sunday, with my colleagues Senator Walsh and Senator Maguire. I agree with Senator Maguire's remarks: we were there to commemorate the life of Geoff McLaren. Not only was he a great senator and a great member of the Labor Party; he was also a great member of the Australian community who all his life in his own way worked very hard, particularly for those people whom he believed were being hard done by by the vicissitudes of society.

In supporting this condolence motion, we are commemorating not just a great senator but a great Australian. I certainly extend to Beryl and the rest of the family my sincere condolences for the passing of a person with whom, for a long time as a party official, I had the opportunity to work, both as a colleague and a friend.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the condolence motion for the late Geoff McLaren. It was a sudden, surprising death because he was here just late last year. I counted Geoff a friend. I might say that that was not easy; perhaps I will come to that later on. Geoff was born in Koroit and worked in Woolsthorpe. They are areas near where I come from—Warrnambool and Port Fairy, the same region as Cyril Primmer, another former senator, came from—and Geoff used to remind me that he came from that area from time to time.

PARA.TAB: I would have to say, along with my other colleagues, that he frequently drove us mad in the Senate with his tenacious—and I agree that he was tenacious—speeches and questioning. I can recall that he took up one matter in particular, and that was the lingering loans made to certain Fraser Ministers. Those loans had been made to them when they were fairly new members of parliament, and were still lingering when they were Ministers on ministerial salaries. Geoff McLaren hung on to that bone like a dog—certainly he never gave it away, not even to his last day in this place—and probably even last year when he was up here he would have raised with some of those people whether those loans had been paid off or not. That was the sort of tenacity that Geoff brought to his position as a senator.

He made it clear that he gave no quarter. As I say, he used, in fact, to drive all of us mad. I might say that he even used to drive some of his own colleagues mad by going on on the adjournment debate. Apart from that, it was apparent that he had an enormous memory for detail. As Mr Deputy President has said, he must have had a great filing system, but to have a great filing system I think you have to have a great memory to be able to realise that there is something there and go to the files and find it.

He also had another natural talent and that was a natural talent for talking. He displayed that at great length. He was very good—I am not being critical of him—with his speeches. He would always take up his full 30 minutes.

TALK.START.PARA: —Always.

—Our Whip confirms to me that he always took up his full 30 minutes when it was 30 minutes; and when it was an hour, he would take the full hour. He would come into the chamber with a pile of documents at least a foot high and he would refer to them, table them and incorporate them. As someone else has said, he would certainly take advantage of the Standing Orders whenever that was possible.

PARA.TAB: Honourable senators have referred to the fact that he retired in 1983. I have to say to the members of the Labor Party that I do not think that that retirement was voluntary. In 1983 Senator McLaren was age barred by the Labor Party because he would have turned 65, I think, after he had served in the Senate for about 5 3/4 years. Because he was about two or three months older than he should have been, he was not allowed to stand for preselection in 1983. I do not think that Geoff was very happy about that rule at that stage.

I mentioned the difficulty of friendship. I think that Geoff probably came into the Senate with a deep and enduring hatred of the Liberal Party and Liberals. As for the National Party, his hatred would have been even deeper. He probably found after he had been here for some time that, while he would never forgive the Liberal Party for being a conservative party or the National Party for having no policies or principles at all—as I think he would have said—there were a number of us who were not so bad and so friendships developed.

In fact, friendships were inevitable with Geoff because he had such an irrepressible humour. Even when he was driving us mad he would be laughing and we could not help but smile with him at some of the things he was going on about. His humour would come through both in the chamber and, certainly, outside the chamber when one had an opportunity to talk with him in the corridors. I join with others in expressing my sympathy to his wife and family.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish also to associate myself with this condolence motion. Senator Geoff McLaren led a very full, active and fruitful life in South Australia, as he did also through his contributions to the Federal Parliament. He died at the end of January just two days before his seventy-first birthday. I was able to visit him in the Royal Adelaide Hospital just before he was transferred back to Murray Bridge Hospital. He certainly was still able to discourse very actively on politics and was very much in touch with the current issues.

PARA.TAB: As has been pointed out, he was born in 1921 in the western districts of Victoria. In later years he moved to South Australia. As has been pointed out by previous speakers this afternoon, there was a memorial ceremony at Murray Bridge last Sunday afternoon for former Senator McLaren and it was very much to celebrate his life and his contribution.

At the request of the McLaren family I was honoured to speak about Geoff's very large contribution in South Australia and in the national Parliament. That function was held at the McLaren family home in Murray Bridge and many friends and supporters were there last Sunday. However, unlike other members of the Senate, I really knew Geoff McLaren only as an MP. I did not have the privilege of working with him or knowing him before he came into the Federal Parliament.

As has been pointed out, he was elected in 1970 and began his term in 1971. As a result of the ALP's age rule in South Australia, his term expired effectively in February 1983 when Malcolm Fraser called the double dissolution for the 1983 elections. Senator McLaren served for almost 12 years in the Senate. He worked tirelessly in the latter part of that period to return Labor to the treasury bench in Canberra, but unfortunately, he did not have the opportunity to be a member of the Government from 1983 onwards as his term expired at the time that the election was called.

As I pointed out, I did not actually serve here while Senator McLaren was a member, but I know that he is spoken of with awe, certainly regarding Estimates committees. Other senators have referred to Estimates here this afternoon. He certainly used the procedures to the fullest to expose waste and mismanagement and incompetence. Of course, he also used the adjournment debates regularly and repeatedly to bring up grievances on behalf of constituents and certainly to publicise rorts and mismanagement. I also know that he used what has now become the very fashionable device of giving notices of motion. He certainly used that procedural device many times when he was in the Senate. I know this first hand because he used to ring me up in Adelaide and ask me for ideas about what he might actually do on a particular day to embarrass the Government with notices of motion on particular issues.

Geoff McLaren was a great Party man. His life very much was the Labor Party. He focused on country areas and country ALP members. He acted to give them a voice not only in Canberra but also in Adelaide and in the Party's forums in South Australia. He worked tirelessly. He travelled all over the State. I think also, as has been pointed out here earlier, his recreation was very much the ALP as well, and working for it. I certainly remember visiting his home, even on weekends, and seeing what were the makings of a very large mail-out of newsletters and so forth being prepared.

He was a great advocate for the Murray Bridge area in the Federal Parliament. He certainly had the common touch. He was in touch with working men and women in regional centres in South Australia. When I was out travelling in the country with him he would stop along the road. I remember in the Murray-Mallee districts of South Australia his stopping along the roads to speak with highway department workers. He would stop and have a chat with these people repairing the roads in very isolated areas to show support for them and to ask them whether they had any problems that needed to be raised in Federal Parliament.

Geoff McLaren is no longer with us, but we will certainly remember him. We will remember the work that he undertook for other people—the less fortunate members of our community and, certainly, those people living in remote areas of South Australia. I would like to express my condolences here to Beryl McLaren and to his sons Doug and Harold and their respective families.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to add my own words of sympathy to Beryl McLaren and the McLaren family and, indeed, to all those people in South Australia, my own State, who rightly respected Geoff McLaren—or `Feathers' as we affectionately knew him—for the work that he did on behalf of the people of South Australia, especially country people as has been referred to many times by honourable senators who have just spoken.

PARA.TAB: I most respect Geoff McLaren for the fact that he battled hard and tenaciously for the ordinary people of Australia and of my State, especially the country people. At times, he did drive us mad. He spoke interminably about the particular detail that he thought was of greatest concern to some person, especially in South Australia. He did wear out the patience of many of us in the Senate. He was out to support his party, the Labor Party, at all times and in the way that he thought would be most effective.

I first came to know of Geoff McLaren in the first couple of months of my time here. In my maiden speech of September 1978, I happened to express my concern as a South Australian about the recent Budget decision of the Fraser Government to introduce an increased brandy tax. I remember saying that the Government had got 99 things right and that this one was wrong and that I had yet to be convinced that this would be other than counterproductive. It would not raise the money that was projected and it would just add to the burden of those grape growers, especially in the Riverland, who, of course, would sell their excess grapes for brandy production. So this was something that was going to hurt the people of South Australia.

It turned out that the remarks that I, Geoff McLaren and Geoff Giles, the local Liberal member, all raised were correct. It was counterproductive and eventually the Government lowered the brandy tax. But, of course, having expressed such a concern at a decision of my own colleagues and of my own Prime Minister—I was a new young senator from South Australia; at that time I think I was only 33—Geoff McLaren noted that immediately in his voluminous files. When the time came for asserting whether we supported the Budget or not, he was without mercy in his attack upon me and my apparent, to him, inconsistency in not then voting against the Budget even though 99 things were right with it and this one thing was wrong.

I was very glad when, only a couple of months after this, I had the pleasure of sharing a room in a hotel on Thursday Island in the Torres Strait with Geoff McLaren and all his jovial humour. I felt all the closer to him because of our time together on the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources. It was a quarantine inquiry which took us to look at that link with Papua New Guinea and Queensland in terms of safeguarding Australia through quarantine.

I mention just one other matter which Geoff would have gloried in: television in this chamber. He served in the old Parliament House, in which we did not have television. But I remember on one occasion—I think it was following the 1980 election—that he brought in a newspaper headline, probably from the Border Watch, which read `Lies, lies, lies'. He held it up and had it put, I think, on every table in the Senate because this was the one newspaper in the whole of Australia which identified with his assessment that one of the promises of the then Fraser Government was not going to be lived up to or had not been lived up to. I cannot even remember whether it was a matter of history or some assessment as to the coming election.

But with real drama and with all the persistence and determination that he had in Estimates committees, in questions, in notices, in interjections, in points of order and in his committee work, he made sure that we all understood that he regarded the Fraser Government as not living up to the promises that those on the Liberal and National side had made.

I mention only one other matter, and that is that Senator McLaren, as Senator Schacht said, had his office outside the metropolitan area. Whilst Senator Wood obviously had his main base in Mackay, it was rare in the 1970s for any honourable senator to have an office located anywhere other than in the central business district. We all know that Feathers McLaren had his office at Murray Bridge. That actually had a positive effect on me in that I really did admire his closeness to the ordinary people of the State.

When we lost government in 1983, I happened to be then second to Feathers McLaren in moving my own electorate office out of the central business district to the Marion shopping centre in an attempt to try to win back the seats of Kingston and Hawker. As campaign manager in Hawker, I eventually succeeded in being a part of that victory by 14 votes in the last election. It was very much with Senator McLaren's example in mind that I moved out to an area in a shopping centre where I could be more approachable and more accessible to that part of the State that I wished more directly to serve.

This closeness to the country people reminds me that I have always felt that Geoff McLaren was closest to Peter Walsh. I know that he was inspired by Peter Walsh's analysis, from the Labor Party's point of view, of country issues. Peter Walsh was, at that time, writing a newsletter for country people that was, I think, amongst those that Geoff and Mrs McLaren would have stayed up so many nights to distribute in South Australia. He was, as Senator Walsh has said, one of the old-style Labor members and I especially respect him for the sincerity with which he represented his party's point of view but more especially for the tenacity with which he battled for the ordinary people of South Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was deeply saddened by the death of Geoff McLaren. He was a person that I had worked with in this place as well as within the Labor movement. During my time in the South Australian branch of the Australian Labor Party, I have met and worked with many notable characters. Amongst these have been some of the most well-known South Australians. The person to whom we pay our respects today, Geoff McLaren, was one of those well-known people.

PARA.TAB: Between 1971 and 1983 he worked tirelessly in this place for the benefit of his State, for the benefit of his Party and, most significantly, for the benefit of the working men and women of this country. His enthusiasm for the betterment of the union cause was matched by his willingness to use this institution and, indeed, all provisions of the Westminster system to further the principles that he believed in. Throughout his term in this place he continually asked questions, made speeches and raised issues that he felt needed to be addressed. He fought for the less privileged, he battled for the worker and at all times he tried to make a difference.

As a senator, he was active on committees as well as in the chamber. His particular interest was Estimates committees, as has been mentioned before, in which he was a lively participant. While he was in the Senate he was on nearly every Estimates committee at some time. For several years he served on two. His political dynamism was evidenced in the broad range of issues that he took a serious interest in during his political career. Aboriginal affairs, primary industry and industrial relations were just a few of his main interest areas.

Whenever he made a point about any issue, he always looked at it from a South Australian perspective as well as a national one. Indeed, he was a very patriotic South Australian who had particular concerns about rural South Australian issues. As a former poultry farmer from Murray Bridge, he used the wealth of knowledge that he had to assist in the formulation of public policy.

Geoff stayed in Murray Bridge after entering the Senate and continued to serve the specific interests of the people there. In fact, he has been described as being a regional senator. He toured the southern and eastern areas of South Australia regularly and became well known in provincial and farming communities. Geoff was always willing to speak out about anything he felt strongly about. He was even willing to protest.

As has been said, once he wore shorts into this chamber to make a point about dress standard rules. On another occasion he boycotted the presentation of a sword to the Black Rod on the grounds that the sword represented war and was `an offensive weapon'. He was also noted for being strongly influenced by the events of November 1975. After the dismissal of the Whitlam Government his condemnation of Kerr's actions and the ongoing fight against Kerr indicated just how strongly he felt about those events.
