This activity occurred long after the issue had died down in the public sphere.

After he left this place, Geoff was still actively involved in his Party and his community. He also served on the executive of the South Australian chapter of the Association of Retired Members of the Federal Parliament. He is particularly missed by the other members of that organisation, who were continually supportive of him and his family during his illness.

I wish to extend to Beryl and the rest of Geoff's family my deepest sympathy at this time. I know that all honourable senators share these thoughts with me. I also know that many South Australians would be aware of the contributions that Geoff McLaren made to this place and no doubt they also will be sad at his passing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was shocked to hear only yesterday of Geoff McLaren's death. I knew him in my time in the House of Representatives and again when I returned to this chamber. He occasionally rang me after his retirement. He also sent me newspaper cuttings about current issues in order to urge that particular action be taken. I remember that he called at my office in Hobart when he was visiting that city not long after his retirement. He went through all the current issues of the day and made sure that I was still pushing as hard as ever on them.

PARA.TAB: I would like to recall one story which relates to the current debate, beat-up though it may be, about the monarchy. There was a time when I strongly objected to Hansard correcting me and inserting the words `Sir John' when I insisted on referring to Senator Carrick without the imperial title. Geoff McLaren was one of my strongest supporters in trying to remove the words that Hansard sought to insert.

He had very strong views in those sorts of areas. As people have suggested, he was terrier-like in sticking to them and never going back on them. I would like to be associated with the remarks that others have made here this afternoon in memory of Geoff McLaren, and convey my condolences to his wife Beryl.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to associate myself with this condolence motion for the late Geoff McLaren. Most of the things, I assume, that need to be said have been said. Senator Lewis reminded me that although Geoff could be extremely involved with a particular point of view, he could, with a half smile, display a certain antipathy to those who opposed that view. This was very good.

PARA.TAB: So far as my association with Geoff was concerned, I did feel a good deal of that bitterness but I believe that that was based on some information that he may have been given which was not entirely in accordance with the facts. Over recent years I felt a good deal of warmth from Geoff McLaren when he has visited this place and I very much appreciated that.

The thing that many of us remember about Geoff was his tenaciousness in this chamber. He used this chamber and the Standing Orders to the utmost to get his point of view across. I recall that one day when we had almost drawn stumps here—we were all trying to get away just before Christmas, the planes were revving up their engines and we had to be on our way—Geoff was on his feet still talking on the adjournment debate. As I got out of the car at the airport I could hear on the radio that Geoff was still speaking on the adjournment. If a quorum had been called at that time, five or six senators may have turned up if one was lucky.

These are the sorts of things that we remember about people. They are indicative of the efforts that people make to ensure that this place does work in the interest of the electorate and those that they represent. I would like to convey to Beryl and to the whole of the family my deepest sympathy on the passing of Geoff.

I might repeat, Mr Deputy President, since you are in the chair, the appeal that I made a moment ago: I wish that the President, or the officials of this place, would notify us of the passing of our former colleagues, because I did not know of Geoff McLaren's death until I read about it on the Notice Paper today.
Question resolved in the affirmative, honourable senators standing in their places.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the President, I wish to advise the Senate of the retirement on 31 January this year of Mr Hillas MacLean, Parliamentary Librarian since December 1982, and to extend to him the Parliament's appreciation of his services.

PARA.TAB: Mr MacLean joined the Parliamentary Library in 1979 as Deputy Parliamentary Librarian after distinguished service in New Zealand, which included the position of Chief Librarian in the General Assembly Library in Wellington. He was promoted to Head Librarian in the Parliamentary Library in 1980 and Acting Parliamentary Librarian in 1981. He was appointed Parliamentary Librarian, the head of the Department of the Parliamentary Library, in 1982.
During his career with the Parliamentary Library, Mr MacLean presided over a number of important initiatives. These included:

INTERJECT.PARA: The 1983 proposal that the Library provide, on behalf of the Commonwealth Parliament, assistance to parliamentary libraries of the developing nations of the South West Pacific;

the introduction, following the general election in 1984, of detailed library specific orientation sessions for senators, members and their staff. These sessions have been of great value to very many senators and members as well as being of considerable benefit to the Library itself;

the development and implementation of the Parliament's information, storage and retrieval—ISR—system, which is used extensively by senators from both major parties and by Democrat and Independent senators; and
the formation in 1986 of a departmental council, through which management and staff could exchange views and information on a wide range of matters.

PARA.TAB: During Mr MacLean's term of office the Library responded to a number of changes and developments which added to its workload and responsibilities. The increased number of senators and members following the 1984 election led to greater demand for the Library's services and required a rearrangement of resources to ensure that the Library's high level of client service was maintained.

A particularly complex and difficult project during this period was the planning and implementation of the Library's move in 1988 from the provisional Parliament House to the new building. That year also saw the culmination of a very successful aspect of Australia's bicentenary celebrations—the Parliament's bicentenary publications project. The Library was involved in both book publishing and an oral history project.

Mr MacLean served under three Presidents and four Speakers and represented the Commonwealth Parliamentary Library at national and international conferences and on visits to overseas legislative libraries and research services.

On behalf of all senators, I wish Mr MacLean an enjoyable and productive retirement. The Speaker and Mr President have decided not to make an early substantive appointment to replace Mr MacLean. The Secretary to the Department of the Parliamentary Reporting Staff, Mr Templeton, will continue to head the Library Implementation Group and will from time to time act as Parliamentary Librarian to handle matters requiring head-of-department attention.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Constitutional Monarchy
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned shows:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that Australia, under its constitutional system based on the Monarchy, is one of the world's most successful democracies. The petitioners note particularly that:

PARA.TAB: Australia is one of the world's oldest democracies
Australia has led the world in many democratic reforms

PETITION.PARA: Our Constitution, based on the Monarchy, has:

PARA.TAB: ensured national independence
maintained national unity in a federation
provided constitutional stability
protected our liberties and freedoms
produced a tolerant society

PETITION.PARA: Your petitioners therefore request that:
Australia should remain a constitutional Monarchy with Her Majesty, the Queen of Australia as our head of State and represented in Australia by a Governor-General.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Michael Baume (from 18 citizens), Senator Campbell (from 26 citizens) and Senator Kemp (from 76 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Smokefree International Flights
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

PARA.TAB: We, the undersigned,
(i)are alarmed at the health and safety hazards that arise from the smoking of cigarettes and other tobacco products on international airlines, a dangerous practice banned within Australia;

(ii)call for the International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) of which Australia is a member to set a standard for smokefree international flights; standards set by ICAO must be agreed to by its 162 member nations.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Reid (from 99 citizens) and Senator Sowada (from 62 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

PARA.TAB: Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469,274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Uranium: Mining and Export
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That your petitioners request that the Australian Government take steps immediately to stop the mining and export of uranium
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate will, as a matter of urgency, establish a Committee of inquiry into
(a)the export of Australian military hardware and services;

PETITION.PARA: (b)the adequacy of existing controls over Australian arms exports;
(c)the implications of the international arms trade and ways in which it might be reduced.

PARA.TAB: And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: East Timor
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and the members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1.We request the Australian government demand from the Indonesian government that a United Nations sponsored inquiry be held into the Santa Cruz massacre.
2.We request the Australian government support a United Nations presence in East Timor to monitor continuous, severe, documented violations of which Santa Cruz is a well publicised example.
3.We request the Australian government promote United Nations sponsored talks between the Indonesian government, Portugal and the East Timorese.
4.We demand complete cessation of all military traffic between Australia and Indonesia, including arms supply and training.

5.We demand that the planned trip to Djakarta by the Prime Minister be cancelled unless serious and successful effort on the part of the Australian government with reference to the above four points is made.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: British Commonwealth Occupation Forces, Japan
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable, the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament.
The petition of the undersigned citizens respectively request that:

That all former members of the British Commonwealth Occupation Force (B.C.O.F.) Japan, who have not established eligibility through other military service, be granted eligibility for the Service Pension, and all benefits thereto, including the issue of campaign medals.
Your petitioners humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled, urge the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to so grant this request by legislation enacted by Parliament.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: FM Radio Station, Yilgarn, Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I present to the Senate the following petition, from 36 citizens, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form and does not contain a prayer at the end:

PARA.TAB: To the Members of the Senate

As a student body we wish to add our voice to a petition currently circulating in the Yilgarn area. We believe that as residents of W.A. we are entitled to what the city and metropolitan residents of Perth our age can listen to—96 FM radio station. We would like you to:
(a) recognise that the townships of Bullfinch, Marvel Loch and Southern Cross have no access to an FM radio Service.
(b) Act to rectify this situation by using your position as the Minister for Transport and Communications.
In support of our position we present to you the undersigned students of Southern Cross D.H.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)Australian women are concerned about the lack of opportunities available to them to plan for financial security in retirement,
(ii)adequate superannuation arrangements are not available to employees, mostly women, who are employed in part-time or casual work,
(iii)superannuation has not taken into account the different working patterns of men and women, and
(iv)Australian women are fearful of the safety of funds invested in large, anonymous companies and the failure of financial institutions in the past few years;

PARA.TAB: (b)recognises that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Coalition's `Fightback' plan makes provision for women in the unpaid workforce to have their own retirement savings accounts and for women returning to the workforce in later years to access substantial tax savings on lump-sum catch-up payments for superannuation purposes, and
(ii)compulsory retirement ages will be abolished and women will have the opportunity to work beyond pension age in exchange for larger pensions if they so wish; and

PARA.TAB: (c)condemns the Federal Government for:

TAB.TAB: (i)failing to provide any incentives for Australian women working in the home to save for retirement or for their husbands to save for them, and
(ii)sentencing many Australian women, after divorce or widowhood, to live out their lives in poverty.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Fiftieth Anniversary of Bombing of Darwin

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes the commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the bombing of Darwin on 19 February 1942, and is of the opinion that:

TAB.TAB: (i)we, as a nation, should pay tribute to the 243 allied personnel and civilians who lost their lives in the first air raids on Darwin 50 years ago,

(ii)an enormous debt of gratitude is owed to the Australian, American, British, Dutch and Canadian military personnel who served in the Northern Territory during World War II, along with civilian personnel,

(iii)we should remember the hardships faced by evacuees, more than 1000 women and 900 children, who were forced to leave their husbands, fathers, sons, homes and possessions, sometimes with only a few hours' notice, and
(iv)the Northern Territory Government should be commended for organising the memorial year; and

PARA.TAB: (b)trusts that the commemoration will provide lasting recognition for those who served in the Battle of Australia and ensure that their sacrifices are never forgotten.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the following bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to protect threatened species in Australia and overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the economic statement to be released on 26 February 1992 is, in fact, the 19th released during the Hawke-Keating Labor Governments,
(ii)almost all of the previous 18 statements have been promoted as the definitive answer to Australia's economic dilemma,
(iii)each statement, in fact, has been no more than an effort to correct the mistakes made by the Hawke-Keating Governments in previous statements, and

(iv)for rural Australia, the statement will be the last chance for recovery in a sector that has increased its indebtedness by 40 per cent while its profitability has slumped to a record low, with forced sales common in almost every rural community; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on Mr Keating, for once in his life, to get it right, and ensure that Australia's farmers, who account for 27 per cent of our export earnings, are given the recognition and encouragement they deserve, encouragement and recognition that has been totally lacking in the previous eight years of the Hawke Ministry.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes:
(a)the totally inappropriate and ambiguous speech delivered on 24 February 1992 by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in the presence of Her Majesty, Queen of Australia;
(b)that Mr Keating purported to speak for the Australian people and not just the leadership of the Australian Labor Party on that occasion;
(c)that the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) was denied the opportunity to speak, as is traditional and customary;

(d)that Mr Keating in the speech he read, which we can only presume he had read before he delivered it and therefore knew what he was saying, fuelled the divisive republican push in Australia at just the time we need to pull together; and

(e)that the vast majority of the Australian people, that is, a constant 70 per cent of those polled in properly conducted polls, support Australia's democratic constitutional monarchy as a system of Government that serves us well.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)condemns the Federal Government for its refusal to implement anti-dumping and countervailing measures against the dumping of Chinese peanuts on the Australian market;
(b)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Australian Customs Service (ACS) inquiry into the importation of Chinese peanuts established that these imports have increased 300 per cent in the past three years,
(ii)the ACS admitted the cheaper imports were being dumped and that Australian producers were suffering as a result, and
(iii)this is having a serious impact on Queensland's $30 million per year industry;

PARA.TAB: (c)further notes that tests on the Chinese peanuts have identified high levels of chemical residues, which are illegal in the Australian industry; and
(d)calls on the Government to take immediate action to halt the importation of these peanuts, and thus provide a `fair go' for Australian peanut farmers instead of support for those in China.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)there is to be a by-election in the Federal Seat of Wills following the retirement of the former Prime Minister (Mr Hawke),

(ii)people in the Wills electorate have suffered more harshly from the Hawke and Keating policies of recession than almost any other electorate in Australia, with thousands being thrown onto the unemployment scrapheap in the past twelve months alone, and
(iii)two Liberal Senators, Senator Short and Senator Kemp, have based their electorate offices near or within the boundaries of Wills to service the electorate which has been so neglected by Labor;

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Government for proposing that the people of Wills will be left unrepresented in the House of Representatives for an indefinite period; and
(c)urges the Government to call an immediate by-election in Wills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes that:

TAB.TAB: (i)the Premier of Western Australia (Dr Lawrence) had to put special legislation through the Western Australian Parliament to enable the Marandoo Iron Ore project to proceed;

(ii)while not denying the Premier acted properly in a farcical situation, special legislation would not have been required if common sense had prevailed among those sectional groups that would stop all resource development; and

PARA.TAB: (b)calls on the Government to put policies into place that will enable Australia to continue to benefit from its mineral resources under appropriate safeguards, hopefully by the evening of 26 February 1992.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)offers sincere congratulations to the new Tasmanian Liberal Premier (Mr Groom) and his State colleagues on their resounding victory in the State election held on 1 February 1992;

(b)acknowledges that, by their clear actions in returning a majority Liberal Government, the Tasmanian electorate demonstrated its rejection of the Labor/Green experiment which had proved to be an economic disaster for the State;
(c)notes that the vote of the State Labor party was decimated to a new low in modern times and the vote for the so-called Green Independents fell by over 25 per cent;

(d)recognises the vital role played in the Tasmanian State Liberal Party's decisive win by the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) who demonstrated that he is already much more than a match for our new, temporary Prime Minister (Mr Keating) on the election hustings; and

(e)on behalf of the many thousands of unemployed Tasmanians and people in the State's business sector who have suffered so much over the period of the Labor/Green experiment, calls upon the rest of Australia to heed the words of the former Federal Member and now State Member for Denison, and Speaker in the House of Assembly (Mr Hodgman) who has advised that Tasmania is now once again open for business.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: (a)that the Senate disapproves of the action of the Western Australian Government for failing to appoint Christabel Chamarette as a Senator for Western Australia, condemns the Western Australian Government for denying electors of that State their rightful representation in the Senate, and condemns the Western Australian Government for the disrespect it has shown to the Senate; and
(b)that this resolution be forwarded to the Presiding Officers of the Western Australian Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate—
(a)notes:

TAB.TAB: (i)the unnecessary delay by the Lawrence Labor Government in enabling the appointment of a replacement for former Western Australian Senator (Senator Vallentine), and

(ii)that this is the second occasion in less than two years that Dr Lawrence's Labor Government has delayed the appointment of a casual vacancy to the Senate and therefore denied the people of Western Australia full representation in the Federal Parliament; and

PARA.TAB: (b)condemns the Premier of Western Australia (Dr Lawrence) and her Labor Government for their clear lack of diligence in this matter; and
(c)calls on Dr Lawrence to immediately enable the appointment of the person nominated by the Western Australian Greens as a Senator for Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate notes that—
(a)Australian business taxes are uncompetitive when compared with international standards;
(b)the latest Industry Commission report and a report to the Australian Manufacturing Council list high taxes as among the biggest impediments to manufacturing and export growth;

(c)on an international comparison across seven countries, the average proportion of equipment investment that is tax-deductible within two years in key manufacturing sectors is 49 per cent compared with only 15 per cent on the same equipment for Australian businesses; and
(d)the depreciation rules need to be brought into line to the standards of our top competitors overseas.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, on the next day of sitting, I shall move:

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 25 February, from Senator Short:

PARA.TAB: Dear Mr President,

INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move
'That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Government to take urgent action to:
(a)increase employment by reducing business costs, increasing productivity and improving the climate for investment;
(b)reduce hospital waiting lists and improve the quality of service in health care;
(c)expand resources and provide greater choice and higher standards in education;
all of which have been comprehensively addressed by the Coalition's Fightback! program of reform.'

PARA.TAB: Senator for Victoria

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Government to take urgent action to:
(a)increase employment by reducing business costs, increasing productivity and improving the climate for investment;
(b)reduce hospital waiting lists and improve the quality of service in health care;
(c)expand resources and provide greater choice and higher standards in education;
all of which have been comprehensively addressed by the Coalition's Fightback! program of reform.

The motion of urgency is a matter on which the Opposition believes urgent action needs to be taken. It is for that reason that we have introduced this as a matter of urgency rather than just as a matter of public importance. My colleagues Senator Herron and Senator Tierney will address those aspects of the matter of urgency relating to hospital and health care and education respectively. I will concentrate my remarks on the first part of the motion, namely, the need for the Government to take urgent action to increase employment by reducing business costs, increasing productivity and improving the climate for investment. All of these matters have been comprehensively addressed by the coalition's Fightback program of reform, which was released late last year.

PARA.TAB: This Government has plunged Australia into a grave economic and social crisis. The architect of that economic and social crisis—the most serious crisis in this country for the last 60 years—is none other than the now Prime Minister, Mr Keating. Labor's engineered recession—the recession, honourable senators will recall, that Mr Keating said we had to have—has destroyed thousands of businesses and families throughout Australia and has created untold misery and hardship for millions of Australians. The level of national savings has collapsed; so has the level of investment. Of course, without investment and economic growth, there can be no jobs.

The official rate of unemployment is now more than 10 per cent and it will go higher, even on the Government's own reckoning. The underlying rate of unemployment exceeds 14 per cent, taking into account those who in despair have given up looking up for work. There are now well over one million people out of work in Australia. Those who are underemployed add at least another half million to those who are effectively out of work. Youth unemployment has reached the scandalous figure of more than 30 per cent. In some areas, including the former Prime Minister's electorate of Wills—about which I gave a notice of motion earlier today—youth unemployment is in the order of 40 per cent.

It is very difficult to comprehend the hardship and the despair for the future that that causes for the young people and the older people who are out of work. It was only two years ago, on 12 March 1990, that the then leader of the Government told the people of Australia:

SPEECH.PARA: And I'll tell you what, if you vote for me what you'll get is a continuation of record employment growth . . .

That was just two weeks before the 1990 election. Since then the full forces of the recession have hit us mightily. Only a few months later, in November 1990, the then Treasurer, the now Prime Minister, at last came clean and said, `Yes, this was an engineered recession, a recession we had to have'. He said, `I knew there had to be a recession but I didn't want to tell you'. At the same time, with the worst of the recession was yet to come, in November 1990 the same Treasurer, the now Prime Minister, said that the worst was behind us, that we would recover by the middle of 1991.

PARA.TAB: In May 1991, when this recovery was supposed to have occurred and when Mr Keating, the loyal deputy, as he then was, to Prime Minister Hawke was preparing his first political assassination coup attempt against the Prime Minister, he said that we would definitely have recovery by the end of 1991. Mr Keating was wrong again. He has been wrong, he has deceived the Australian people for nine years. I believe that the greatest test Mr Keating has—a test that I believe it is impossible for him to pass—is to convince the Australian public that he has any credibility left. He has shown no credibility in his statements over the past nine years. He has shown, quite frankly, that his statements cannot be believed. I believe that the Australian people are going to react very strongly to that.

Where does this shell shocked Government, led by a man who has shelled and shocked the Australian economy and the Australian people into great hardship and bleak despair, go from here? We have just seen that private new capital expenditure in the December quarter of last year declined by 11 per cent from the September quarter, which itself was sadly low. The figure was down 14 per cent from a year earlier. Estimated new capital expenditure for this year is 15 per cent lower than the corresponding estimate last year. New capital spending in the year ahead, 1992, on present forecasts and surveys looks likely to be down by a further 9 per cent. As I said, when investment is so depressed there is little hope for struggling businesses and for the unemployed.

The key to it all is confidence. But who can have any confidence in this Government, led as it now is by a man whose whole record is one of deceit and broken promises? What does the Government do? One thing is certain and that is that pump priming the economy with a spending binge is not the answer. Pump priming might suit the socialists and the traditional big spending instincts of Labor, but it would destroy any prospects of recovery.

As the head of the Treasury, Tony Cole, warned only last week, boosting Government spending in an attempt to kick-start the economy could quickly bring on an exchange rate and balance of payments crisis, leading to higher interest rates and depressing investment even further. No wonder Mr Cole said that. It is odd for the head of the Treasury to be saying that. We now know why: he is distancing himself from the Government's economic statement of tomorrow. Why is he doing that? He is doing that because the Treasury and, to a large extent, the Treasurer (Mr Dawkins) have been frozen out of the formulation and preparation of the economic statement.

We already have the seeds of a major division between the Prime Minister and his new Treasurer. We also have similar seeds of division in the way that two Cabinet Ministers—Senator Button and Simon Crean—have had their proposals rolled in Cabinet. By jove, they must be a happy little bunch of disunited and divided Ministers sitting around the Cabinet table.

Access Economics has warned that of the various policy options open to the Government, pump priming is least likely to be of value to the labour market. Labor's problem is its desperation to get things moving before the next election. It is therefore absolutely obsessed with priming the political pump.

The fact is that the economy cannot afford any more stimulus over and above what has already been built into the system. There have been substantial reductions in interest rates, the lagged effects of which will take some nine to 12 months to follow through the system. There has been a massive fiscal turnaround over the last two years of about $17 billion, certainly a minimum of $13 billion, to which I will return in a moment.

The coalition has done some economic modelling on various possibilities that might arise from tomorrow night's statement. We recently requested that the Parliamentary Research Service of the Department of the Parliamentary Library use the well known and highly respected Murphy model of the Australian economy to examine the consequences of a boost to Federal Government spending of up to, say, $3 billion and the highly possible fall in the exchange rate that would result of around US74c to US70c.

The Murphy model shows in detail that such a course of action would add 2.6 percentage points to the inflation rate by the end of the financial year 1992-93. That would result in an inflation rate of at least 6.1 per cent by the time of the next election. Employment would be boosted temporarily by a mere 50,000 jobs by the end of 1992-93, but the level of unemployment would be boosted three years down the track and foreign debt would rise from the already staggeringly high figure of around $130 billion to $135 billion today to a figure of $167.8 billion by the time of the next election.

It is absolutely amazing that the Government over the other side seems to be saying, `Let's go full steam ahead, let's pump prime the economy and let's dam the torpedos that will result from it'. It is exactly the sort of attitude that in the early years of the Hawke-Keating Government led to the damaging boom-bust cycle from which Australia is presently suffering and through which in recent years we have lived. It is an attitude that has led to the enormous build-up in Australia's foreign debt which, since this Government came in, is now 35 per cent of our total annual output compared with 11 per cent in 1983 when the Hawke Government came in. In fact, it looks as though this Government is again cranking up the old fallacious arguments about pump priming and spending that really went out of fashion a long time ago. The consequences of what the Government seems to be proposing to do will be horrendous indeed.

Market analysts and private economic forecasters have already estimated that the Budget deficit for 1991-92—which honourable senators may recall was planned at the last election to come in at $4.7 billion for 1991-92—is now likely to blow out to somewhere between $8 billion or $9 billion; and that does not take into account at all any further blow-out from new expenditure that will be announced tomorrow.

For the Government to bring the Budget in on track in line with its forecasts—and its latest forecast are only a little more than the $7.4 billion—there will have to be a turnaround, a different outcome, in the Budget balance between the first and second halves of 1991-92 of around $17 billion. Nothing like that has ever remotely happened before in Australia. The largest previous turnaround in a Budget was $12.6 billion, which was in the rapid recovery phase of 1986-87, and not even the Government is forecasting a recovery of that magnitude. Even to come in with a deficit of only $8 billion would require a $14 billion turnaround between the first and second halves of this year, which is still greater than any previous record.

The economy would have to boom at an unprecedented rate for the Government's Budget forecast, now revised to a little over $5 billion, to be accurate. Indeed, if such a strong economic recovery is under way or even expected, then why is the Government about to announce tomorrow the single largest deliberate relaxation in fiscal policy in nearly a decade? I say `deliberate relaxation' because there has, of course, been an enormous unplanned $13 billion to $16 billion relaxation over the past two years.

The increase in the Budget deficit will have to be funded by additional sales of government bonds; that is, by plunging the Government and the public sector further into debt. Various analysts—for example, Schroders—calculate that the Government will require an additional $3 billion to $3 1/2 billion in funds compared with the planned program for 1991-92. If that were all met by additional bond tenders, then the total requirement for the year would increase to $14 billion, leaving about $6 billion to be raised in the last four months of this financial year. That would be extremely difficult, if not impossible, given the current weakening in the bond market because of the lack of confidence in the market about where the Government is going from here.

The Government would have to resort almost certainly to issuing Treasury notes and running down cash balances. Either way, what would happen is obvious: bond prices would fall, interest rates would rise, and the short term pump priming would soon be swamped by higher inflation, a choking of activity, a loss of confidence and more unemployment when the bills come in. One could scarcely imagine a more grossly irresponsible course of action by any government. It simply shows the cost of political ambition, the desperate grab to stay in power regardless of what it does to the country. The tragedy is that it will be average Australians who will bear the cost.

The inevitable outcome of the Government's political survival strategy will be higher inflation, higher interest rates and a very sad delay in sustained economic recovery. This desperate and demoralised Labor Government has abandoned any sense of fiscal responsibility and is opting for the tried and proven failure of stimulating the economy with bigger and bigger deficits.

What should the Government be doing? If it had a longer term perspective, if it had any real concern for the future of this country and its people, it could take its cue from the coalition's Fightback package of economic reforms. It would accelerate the process of structural reform. It would tighten fiscal policy so that all public expenditure is covered by public revenue. It would ensure that monetary policy is run according to the objective of price stability.

But the Government does not have a longer term perspective. All it cares about, as I have said, is the next election. It says to the Australian people, `After that you can all be damned'. Despite the fact that the Government can rescue neither itself nor the Australian economy in time for the election in 1993, it seems intent on attempted short term fixes, regardless of the long term challenge.

So how will the Government's statement be judged tomorrow night? There are nine basic tests to apply to the Government's economic statement. These are the tests by which the statement must be judged. These are the tests that will determine if the statement contains any substance. These tests are: does the statement tomorrow night make Australia a more attractive and profitable place in which to invest? Does the statement increase national savings? Does it introduce such savings initiatives as those referred to by Senator Newman in her notice of motion put before the Senate earlier today to introduce superannuation for women who work in the home and whose retirement needs have been totally ignored during the nine years of the Hawke and Keating Governments?

Does the statement reduce the Budget deficit? What does it do to the bottom line? Does it reduce inflation and lead to stable currency? Does it lower interest rates? Does it reduce business costs? Does it include labour market reform, the essential ingredient to raising productivity and therefore to economic growth and employment creation in Australia? Does it remove arbitrary impediments such as the green, red and black tape to development? A decision on Coronation Hill here would be a litmus test of the Government's resolve on resource development. As Senator Peter Walsh, the former Minister for Finance, said just a month ago:
If the Government fails to reverse the decision on Coronation Hill, its proclaimed commitment to job growth should not be taken seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: I agree with Senator Walsh and I also will watch with interest to see what happens on that matter tomorrow night.

PARA.TAB: Finally, the test will be whether the statement will restore confidence and provide opportunity and vision for Australians as we move rapidly towards the next century. The Fightback package of reforms introduced by the coalition passes all those tests. The Government's economic statement must do the same if it hopes to do anything constructive to increase employment and provide any hope for the people of Australia.

The Government is on notice tomorrow night to the fact that these are the tests by which it will be judged. These matters are urgent and vital as they affect the lives of every Australian. That is why the Opposition has brought forward this motion for debate today. I urge the Senate to support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is passing strange that on the eve of a significant economic statement that will restructure the economy, the Government is called upon to act urgently. This is an urgency motion, and the Government will vote against it. It will do so for the reason that the motion itself gives the impression that nothing is happening, which is patently wrong. It also gives the impression that no urgent action is being taken to improve upon the positive signs in the Australian economy. That also is wrong.

PARA.TAB: Tomorrow the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) will put down a significant economic statement. I appreciate that the Opposition, in this urgency motion, may wish to try to damage or tarnish the impact of that statement before it arises. Indeed, Senator Short said, `What the Government is about to do tomorrow will be very damaging indeed'. I suggest that Senator Short should wait and see before he condemns what the Government does. I imagine that in this urgency motion the Opposition will try to winkle from us details of what the statement will contain, and indeed to pre-empt its impact. We will not be forthcoming about these details in this debate; it is best to wait for the statement. Over the last few months this has been a piece of very professional government by the Government of Australia. This is an occasion in which there has been no leaking, as unfortunately has bedevilled us on some of these things in the past. It is proof that our act is well and truly together.

Tomorrow will be the first major economic pronouncement by the first Keating Government of Australia. It will give a vision for this country, not just for the year ahead, but into the future beyond that. It will be a statement aimed at stimulating economic growth, and by so doing it will stimulate employment opportunities for those Australians who are unemployed and those who wish to improve their career prospects. It will be a statement, too, that will maintain the record low level of inflation that this country has at last arrived at because of the economic management of our Government. The statement will be committed to continuing the structural reform that we have undertaken in the economy that so underpins the future hopes of our economic strengthening.

Unlike the Hewson consumption tax package, this will be a positive statement. It arises not out of a government sitting in Canberra twirling the dials of economic models. It will arise out of an extensive period by the Prime Minister and senior economic Ministers in consulting with the Australian community, among business leaders, among representatives of business organisations, unions and other parts of the community, as to what needs to be done to further stimulate the economy. Therefore, it will be an example of a government acting with and through the community to implement its best ideas and not something dreamed up in a back room in front of the flickering dial of a computer or in the reams of computer printouts. It will be a real live flesh and blood statement associated with what has to be done in a practical world, unlike the Hewson consumption tax package which reflects the flickering screen mentality of computer driven economics and modelling.

What has been done until now provides a worthwhile springboard for this statement to bounce from to achieve the result at which it is aimed. What we have achieved through past fiscal restraint and responsibility as a government is an ability to have a cushion to undertake now responsible stimulation of the economy. What Senator Short has said, quoting from the Secretary of the Treasury—and I do not suspect that he has taken that quote out of context—in the emphasis he has given is too strong. He said that a kick-start could bring about a spending binge which will increase interest rates. We have brought down interest rates in the last 18 months by 7.5 per cent. But we have now, because of our fiscal rectitude of past years, obtained for ourselves in the economy a cushion by which we can now effect responsible and proper stimulation of the economy without arriving at the result forecast for us in the doom-saying speech of Senator Short.

Australia, in common with other countries, is affected by the world economic recession, but Australia, unlike the United States, for example, has the capacity to which I have just referred. It is true to say that the recent statement by President Bush to stimulate the United States economy had less scope to undertake the stimulatory reform that we now have scope for because we have managed to achieve that cushion by the responsibilities of the past.

Let me say to those who talk about further fiscal discipline or further cuts to the Budget, that what has now occurred means that one cannot address the issue of cutting more deeply into outlays unless one starts attacking major programs which will hurt people in areas of real need. One of the big defaults of Opposition spokesmen on the economy is to call blandly for further cuts without specifying on whose head those cuts will fall and who will be damaged and made worse off in our community. There can be no question of our deserting a commitment to social equity by having indiscriminate cutting which damages ordinary people in a position of real need.

We have worked hard to put into place a fundamental structure for the economy. I go to some of the things that we have achieved to indicate the underlying strength of the restructuring that we have been able to achieve in the Australian economy. The first point I refer to is the level of inflation. It is now the lowest for almost 30 years; it hit the 1.5 per cent inflation level about four weeks ago on the release of the December figures. It is now below both the average inflation levels of the OECD and the average inflation levels of our major trading partners. Clearly, an economic objective must be to lock in and make permanent as a feature of our economic landscape that low inflation level.

The other point that is often passed over in this debate because it is convenient for the Opposition to ignore it is that during the period of this Government we have managed to return the profit share so that in an expanding economy there are more and more funds for reinvestment into Australia. The profit share at the end of September last year—the latest figure—was put at 14.2 per cent. I compare that to the profit share in the 1982-83 recession when Opposition members comprised the then Government. At that time the profit share was 10.6 per cent—I refer to the September 1982 figure. The profit share now is in reasonable balance. So with economic recovery it should generate the funds for further investments. We have achieved that through a wages policy which works—not through a wing and a prayer style wages policy that is aimed at institutionalising the Fraser Government's system of confrontation and standover. Whereas in the 1982-83 period there was a wages explosion which aggravated the recession, we have managed to deliver in this country, over nine years of the Hawke Government and now a few months of the Keating Government, a responsible wages outcome. That will be a continuing feature of our economic management.

Thirdly, I turn to one of the strong areas of performance by this Government, and that is in micro-economic reform. Australia has undergone major micro-economic reform restructuring. We are now far more competitive as an economy than we were in 1983. With a return to growth, the advantages of that painful—and at times arduously argued and negotiated—restructuring will be felt. The major productivity gains have been on the Australian waterfront. While that is an area in which the Opposition claims it can go faster, better and higher, its answer seems to be not to do it by consensus, agreement and common commitment to achieve the goal of restructuring. Its answer seems to be that if there is resistance it will put in the troops.

Let me quote what was said by the managing director of the Australian Wheat Board—a place in the Australian community from which one does not necessarily expect to hear complimentary comments about this Government. In referring to the restructuring and major productivity changes of the Australian waterfront, the managing director of the Australian Wheat Board stated at the end of last year:

SPEECH.PARA: Australian ports are now among the most efficient grain loading ports in the world.
That is just one of a number of unsolicited testimonials to what are at last now coming through as being significant gains in micro-economic reform on the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: The next point on which I would dwell in order to make the case for micro-economic reform and how effective it has been is, of course, a reference to the change in the composition of exports from this country. Manufacturing exports out of this country are now booming. What is significant about that is that they are booming at a time when there is a world economic recession and the markets into which we are selling are recessed. That means that, with world economic recovery, our improvement in manufacturing exports should go even further; it should go up as world economic growth escalates.

The OECD figures show that Australia has the best growth record in manufacturing exports in the OECD bloc. We have performed better in expanding the amount of manufactured exports out of our country than any other OECD country. In real terms, the annual growth of manufacturing exports has been 15 per cent plus over the last five years. Compare that with the OECD average of the most developed countries of 6 per cent real growth.

The next point I wish to make relates to the highly contentious area of labour market reform. We are witnessing significant labour market reform in this country, occurring not without pain but certainly harmoniously across the country. Extensive restructurings have been going on in the Australian workplace. It is now more typically the case that there is greater flexibility, greater commitment to training and greater productivity as a consequence of that.

The favoured index often cited by our opponents is the level of industrial disputation. What is true about our performance is that the level of industrial disputation in this country is now 60 per cent below what it was during the same average period of the Fraser years. We have achieved significant change in the labour market without industrial disputation. This sets us up for a productivity surge in the general economy and for growth.

I can cite two examples which are perhaps worthwhile mentioning in this context. They are small examples but they are typical of the sorts of changes that we are achieving. Take the note printing branch of the Australian Treasury that actually prints the money that we use. Workplace negotiations in that area resulted in an agreement being reached in October last year with the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. The negotiations were linked to extensive restructuring in the organisation as a result of the dramatic improvements in productivity and efficiency. In its first year of commercial operation, Note Printing Australia delivered 445 million notes to the Reserve Bank compared with 275 million in the previous year. The average price in the latest period was more than 30 per cent lower and efficiency improvements are continuing to be made. That is a good example of improved productivity in an area in which significant workplace change has occurred.

The second example I offer is that of ASTA Aircraft Services Pty Ltd, another government business organisation. This organisation recently negotiated a pace setting workplace agreement. The company and its unions have been forerunners in industrial relations reform and improvements in productivity. The improvements at its plant have been exceptional. It has introduced cellular working groups, total quality management and significantly revised rostering arrangements. There have already been reductions in overhead costs and improvements in on-time delivery. There has also been a 50 per cent increase in flow time on aircraft.

The company, which was set up in 1988 with 100 staff, now employs 720 people. Because of the significant changes in productivity and efficiency, it has become more competitive and has been able to grow and employ more people. They are models of the sorts of workplace reform that this Government is undertaking in the wider area.

I should not conclude without referring to tariff reform. In March last year we announced a major industry statement in which we committed ourselves to faster tariff reform. Tariff reform provides a simple discipline in which Australian business has to look outwardly at the world and become more world competitive. It faces world competition on the global scale with the removal of this level of protection.

But we are not in a race with the Opposition. The Opposition has called for faster, quicker reform with further reductions over a shorter period to end up with zero protection or negligible protection in the end. One has to say that that is a scenario which has the potential of burning Australian industry into the ground and removing industry capability to compete on a world scale by removing protection too rapidly.

We are committed to the discipline of reduced protection. We think our scale of reduction is right. It ensures a continuing discipline on industry to become more competitive. But to do it at the level the Opposition preaches would mean that industry would become unable to compete and therefore would go to the wall. That is not something that we support. We support the view that industry be given time to make the adjustment and that the other necessary micro-economic reform changes in the wider economy and in the labour market should also have a chance to come through.

I want to conclude by talking for a few moments about the Hewson consumption tax package. Will that solve the problems confronting this country? What is being proposed is essentially a book entry method of changing the revenue side of the Budget in the way in which tax is collected. If one changes the way in which revenue is collected, will that somehow or other help solve the major economic problems in this economy? The ringing answer to that question is no. One cannot replace, as the Hewson consumption tax package seeks to do, or modify significantly a progressive system of taxation with essentially a regressive system and supporting compensation and achieve the significant reform that needs to be made. One queries whether the level of compensation is credible or believable and whether it would continue. One queries whether the level or the amount of direct taxes that will be imposed by a consumption tax on all the goods and services we purchase will remain fixed. No economy in the world that I can think of has introduced a consumption tax and then kept the level of taxation the same.

Among the myriad flaws that the consumption tax package has, two are most glaring. One is that it will exacerbate the level of unemployment in this country, not cure it. The second is that, according to Department of Finance and Treasury estimates, there is a $3.9 billion shortfall in the estimates that have been presented to the Australian public. It is a shortfall that affects both sides of the ledger. It means that insufficient revenue will be raised on the income side and that, on the costing side, more will be outlaid than is proposed within that package. Therefore, the consumption tax package offers us no hope.

The high unemployment aspect of the consumption tax package needs to be stated a little more fully. The proposal by the Opposition is that it will create two million extra jobs by the year 2000. That is based on the high road scenario of the Access Economics-Murphy econometric model of the Australian economy where the projections are based on the full implementation of Industry Commission reforms. This scenario requires an inflation rate—if one accepts the scenario—of 12.4 per cent in 1994-95.

If one reads Gerard Henderson's column in the Sydney Morning Herald of 10 December, one can see that someone who was the chief of staff of John Howard when he was the Leader of the Opposition and a senior adviser to Malcolm Fraser when he was Prime Minister, someone who is an in-house, big `L' Liberal, believes that the employment scenarios in the consumption tax package are just not true or publicly sustainable. So from within the ranks of the Opposition itself, from one of its more senior bureaucrats, comes ringing condemnation that ought to be heeded.

I conclude with these remarks: we have undertaken significant reform in the micro-economy. We are now going through significant labour market reform. The answer to all those reforms rests at the very base of the ability of a government to deliver outcomes in that reform process. I do not think there is any dispute that the need for reform has to go ahead. There is certainly a big dispute in the way in which one goes about it. One does not achieve micro-economic reform on the waterfront by putting the troops in if workers raise reasonable questions about their own future and security. One does not achieve wages policy reform and reform in the labour market by promising, as Dr Hewson has said, to destroy the Australian trade union movement. What one does by taking both those steps in these key and sensitive areas of economic change is bring Australia to confrontation, not to cooperation.(Time expired)
Motion (by Senator Coulter) agreed to:
That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Coulter) moving an amendment to the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Omit "all of which have been comprehensively addressed by the Coalition's `Fightback' program of reform.", substitute:

PARA.TAB: (d)reduce the intolerable and devastating burden of 30.3% youth unemployment; and
(e)implement strategies for ecologically sustainable development.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats agree with many of the objectives outlined in the opening words of each clause. (Quorum formed) It is rather intriguing that a quorum has been called on an urgency motion brought on by the Opposition and that, while the Government members have come in, only one member of the Opposition, Senator Watson, deigned to come in to make up a quorum to hear its own urgency motion debated.

PARA.TAB: As I was indicating when that quorum was called, we in the Democrats would agree with the objectives in each of the clauses, but we simply could not agree at all with what lies after those stated objectives. I go quickly through some of the clauses. The first part of the motion mentions increasing employment. Of course, that is the most urgent area of social injustice in Australia at the present time. But to us the words `by reducing business costs, increasing productivity and improving the climate for investment' mean something quite different from what they mean to the Opposition. What the Opposition means by reducing business costs is really to tear the guts out of the agreements which have been built up over many years dealing with fair and equitable treatment for workers. Those opposite want to reduce and remove all those careful protective measures which have been put in place to protect the hard won pay and conditions for workers. That is how they will reduce the business costs.

Those opposite will further reduce the tariffs—they will tear those away, as Senator Cook has indicated—to reduce conditions for workers in this country to those of workers in many Third World countries. As far as the much vaunted level playing field that the Opposition talks about is concerned, I remind the Senate that at present we have a multinational company, Nike shoes, in the United States contracting to have made shoes that sell on the international market for $150 by Korean companies, which then subcontract to Indonesian companies which pay workers—largely women workers—80c per day for a 12- to 14-hour day. Those are the sorts of work conditions that the Opposition would impose on workers in this country in an attempt to reduce business costs in Australia.

While the Democrats certainly believe that employment should be increased, we do not believe that that employment should be won at the price of wrecking totally those carefully worked up structures which ensure that workers in this country get a fair amount of pay and fair working conditions.

In relation to reducing hospital waiting lists, yes, we do believe that there should be an improvement in health and sickness care in this country but not at the expense of totally disbanding Medicare; not at the expense of throwing everybody to the wolves of the private system, which means that the well-off can afford health care and everybody else goes to the wall, such as one finds in much of the American system where the sick simply die on the streets without any health care at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —You know we are retaining Medicare.

—I do not know that the Opposition intends to retain Medicare. I know what happened on a previous occasion when those opposite were in a position to retain a national health care scheme and they promised to retain it. It did not last very long, did it?

PARA.TAB: In relation to part (c), `expand resources and provide greater choice and higher standards in education', again one finds in the Fightback package an overwhelming emphasis on private education and the steady running down of public education. In other words, those who will have the greater choice will be those who can afford to buy the education for themselves and for their children. The rest will simply not have any choice at all; there will be no education whatsoever available for them under a Fightback package.

However, I want to stress more than anything else the total lack of vision in both the Fightback package and also in the Government's response to Fightback, which we will hear about in some detail tomorrow night but which we have already heard about tonight from Senator Cook.

What sort of Australia are we trying to produce 10, 15 or 20 years in the future? The vision one gets from both the Opposition and the Government is one in which Australia is simply left to the naked forces of the market—an unregulated system driven by greed. The motto of the 1980s was, `Greed is good'. That was officially put in place by the Keating treasurership and the Hawke leadership.

What we hear from Hewson is, `More greed is better'—they will drive the system harder, further and more vigorously. That is the sort of Australia that both the Government and the Opposition will lead us to. Not one with any clear vision of fairness, of equity, of sustainability within its model at all, but one in which they simply deregulate and leave everything to the market—to those competitive, greedy forces—and what comes out the other end is, by definition, good and desirable and inevitable.

That is not the sort of Australia that the Democrats are looking for. The Democrats are looking for a society which moves towards ecological sustainability, which quite deliberately encourages those industries which will move us towards a more sustainable economy and, at the same time, deliver the employment which is necessary and, by addressing the problem of exports and import replacement, address the problem of the massive foreign debt. We believe that that is possible. We believe it is achievable. We believe that there are a number of nascent industries in this country which can be encouraged, which can meet those criteria, and they are the criteria which we believe should be put in place.

Senator Short went through the criteria which he said needed to be used as tests by which the Government's economic statement would be measured. Every single one of those tests is a dollar test. There is no humanity at all in the Opposition senators. They would quite literally sell their grandmothers for a dollar if they thought there was a dollar in it. They have no sense whatsoever that Australian society consists of people of flesh and blood with real feelings. They have no sense at all of the need to move Australia towards greater ecological sustainability. For that reason we are seeking the inclusion of those amendments and the deletion of the Fightback package.

Interestingly both Senator Short, in speaking to his motion, and Senator Cook, in opposing it, mentioned the Access Economics analysis. A major conference of 70 academic economists started on Monday in Canberra and a number of the papers presented were reviewed by Peter Hartcher in the Sydney Morning Herald just late last week. Interestingly, they make a very mixed bag.

There is no guarantee whatsoever within the Fightback package that it will deliver any of the things which are promised. It is quite literally, as a number of the economists said, and I believe Dr Hewson himself said, a magic pudding. If certain things happen then it may deliver some good results but, in itself, there is no guarantee that it can address any of the problems of unemployment, any of the problems of foreign indebtedness, any of the problems of inequity, any of the problems of moving Australia to a more productive economy and certainly no promise whatsoever, because it is not even mentioned, that it will move Australia towards greater ecological sustainability.
Some of those economists who have actually directly supported the idea of a GST have expressed great concern. I note, for instance, that of Professor Freebairn it is said:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . he also punctures some of the familiar claims about the virtues of a consumption tax: "Contributions to the aggregate level of savings, to greater work effort, and to combating tax evasion and avoidance are doubtful and, in any event, they are likely to be small at best.

Dr Terry Dwyer, another economist, who works for the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, claims that the Hewson economy would have as many distortions, inefficiencies and disincentives as the one it would remould—that it is replacing problems, not curing them. The article states:

Dwyer raises a host of potential new problems that Fightback may throw up in practice and draws the conclusion that throwing out the old system and replacing it with the new may be a "zero-sum" game where each old problem is replaced with a new, and slightly different, one. The moral he draws: "Caveat emptor".
We would argue that while some of the objectives stated in the urgency motion are laudable, the means by which it is suggested they should be achieved are totally reprehensible.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Coulter has totally misrepresented the coalition health policy. I have a copy with me and I will leave it with him so that he can read it and, hopefully, try to understand it. He said, for instance, that we would abolish Medicare. We will retain Medicare. We will improve Medicare. When he said he was going to introduce the co-payment the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, said that that was an absolute necessity.

PARA.TAB: Senator Coulter totally misunderstands the American health system. He is not aware that 60 per cent of people are insured in America by their employers. One of the biggest problems with the American system is that that insurance is not transportable between occupations or between jobs. Twenty per cent are covered by the American Medicare and Medicaid which are the two systems to care for the poor, the aged and the veterans. The 35 million who are uninsured in the States are the people who do not qualify under any of the other systems and there are only 10 per cent who are privately insured with their own funds.

So the systems in the two nations are in no way at all comparable. President Bush, in the release of his statement on health in Cleveland two weeks ago, said that he will introduce many of the elements of the coalition health policy in the provision of support for private insurance for those who are not covered—vouchers that are tax credits for private insurance and portability of insurance. For Senator Coulter to get up and complain about our health policy without introducing anything at all comparable from his own Party, and to draw a comparison between the American system and the Australian system, is indicative of his total misunderstanding of what the coalition health policy is, and his total misunderstanding of what the American health policy is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In responding to the matter of urgency today I would like to concentrate on the section which deals with the necessity, in the words of the coalition, to `reduce hospital waiting lists and improve the quality of service in health care'. It is suggested that all of these have been comprehensively addressed by the coalition's Fightback program of reform. After a serious and comprehensive reading of the documents that were issued by the coalition late last year, I find that statement very hard to justify. I would like to detail a few of the miscalculations that are included in that particular package.

PARA.TAB: The total national expenditure on health under the Hewson package would rise by $2.113 billion per annum in 1991-92 prices, or about 6 per cent. Commonwealth outlays themselves would rise by $395m, not $37m as the coalition claims, indicating significant omissions by the coalition and conservative assumptions on the part of the departmental costings. The $2 billion increase in global expenditure would be borne largely by individuals' direct costs plus private insurance premiums.

Well over one million families would be up to $1,000 per annum worse off, even allowing for tax credits and the safety net. Some 245,000 single people would be up to $500 a year worse off. A family with an annual income of $26,000 will face the additional burden of over $800 a year for private insurance. Families in the $20,000 to $30,000 per annum range will be faced with health insurance fees and large out of pocket costs. They will hardly be comforted by a $200 tax credit, which will nowhere near compensate them for the extra charges they will face.

We know for a fact that doctors' fees under the coalition plan would inevitably rise. The AMA schedule, which seems to find favour with the coalition, currently averages over 130 per cent of the medical benefits schedule fees, and the floor price will inevitably rise to this level. Charges above this are also totally predictable, and they will not be covered by either gap insurance or safety net provisions. The AMA apparently accepts no constraints on the fees on its schedule.

We have the prospect, under the plans put forward by the coalition, of a great gap in policy making, a great inadequacy. The coalition's policy will do nothing to improve people's access to public or private hospitals. It simply serves as testimony to the fact that the Opposition is hopelessly ignorant of the health insurance system.

Tax credits for low income earners would not cover the cost of even basic table insurance, let alone provide for private hospital coverage. The daily benefits available under the basic table average $185. Bed day and other charges in private hospitals average twice that—$335. Even insured patients would have significant out of pocket expenses for admission to private hospitals. Quite obviously, they would continue to use public hospitals. The only guarantee an age pensioner has of free hospital treatment is as a public patient under Medicare. The Opposition would remove that guarantee by luring age pensioners into private insurance by making totally spurious claims.

There has been a vast amount of uninformed rubbish talked and written about waiting lists—one of the legs of the urgency motion before us tonight. This totally ignores the fact that waiting lists have always existed for elective surgery, and I am quite sure Senator Herron would confirm that. Elective surgery by its very nature is non-urgent. To be able immediately to schedule such procedures would need a vast structure of beds, resources and personnel that would be idle much of the time. Private hospitals are living testimony to this. They are conducted on this basis. Many such hospitals actually close on weekends and hire staff on a casual basis in order to deal with the peaks and troughs. Public hospitals simply cannot do this. The demands and expectations of public hospitals are entirely different. They are required to be open 24 hours a day and to provide the full range of services for those 24 hours a day seven days a week.

Once again, however, the coalition's policy is quite off the mark. It gives us nothing to address the fundamental needs of the Australian health system or the needs of the Australian people. It gives us nothing to ensure access to services, especially access for disadvantaged groups such as Aborigines and the chronically ill. It does nothing to improve public hospital facilities and nothing to address waiting times and improve access to hospitals.

To try to rectify some of the misleading statements we have been hearing on and off over the years about waiting times I have turned to Issues Paper No. 2 of the Macklin review. There is some very interesting information in Appendix 2 about waiting times for a range of elective surgical procedures in Victoria and South Australia. It is stated in Appendix 2:

SPEECH.PARA: The aggregate figures for Victoria and South Australia suggest that there is a weak relationship between changes in the number of people treated and the changes in the number of people waiting. Indeed, in some periods, waiting lists grew despite increases in throughput.
I guess that is bureaucratese for the number of people who have had their elective procedures. The report continued:

This finding may reflect the commonly observed situation in health care where growth in supply can lead to an expansion of demand, and vice versa. It suggests to policy makers and funders that there should be some caution exercised in interpreting the meaning of waiting lists as an indicator of need, and pursuing patient throughput strategies to reduce waiting lists.

In contrast, the Government is already setting in motion the recommendations in Issues Paper No. 2 of the Macklin report. I recommend chapter 16 to the coalition as necessary and interesting reading. This chapter is entitled `Core elements of reform to Australia's hospital system'. I might add that it is the result of painstaking research, consultation and policy development in conjunction with the States and Territories, which of course is inevitable. Chapter 16 summarises measures such as the development and introduction of area health management responsible for broadly defined health services; equitable funding of geographic areas, using population-based resource allocation models; a price mechanism for funding both public and private hospitals using case mix as a measure of output; and the development of strategic hospital plans, a judicious restriction of bed supply.

PARA.TAB: Other measures of importance in the better utilisation of existing facilities include State-wide management of waiting lists for elective surgery—a very sensible approach; improved productivity of public hospitals; improved information systems for both providers and clients; and resolution of Commonwealth-State roles and responsibilities. In other words, it is a comprehensive approach to improve accessibility, efficiency and effectiveness in hospital systems, which are, after all, primarily the responsibility of the States. Of course, there is also the examination of the close relationship of public hospitals to all those other services which are of so much importance in planning for the necessary number of beds and resources—nursing homes, hostels, home and community care and mental health services.

In addressing this subject this evening I would also like to go to a very important initiative of the Government which was announced late last year and which is meeting with a great deal of enthusiasm amongst the general practitioner population. I refer to the introduction of demonstration practice grants, the purpose being to foster new ideas for the funding and delivery of general practice services. Over 800 applications have been received and acknowledged in the short time since the announcement of this new program. Some of those applications are from large groups of GPs. The total number of GPs involved is substantially larger than 800.

Applications are now being considered by a panel comprising a representative of the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, a departmental officer, and a general practitioner independent of both the Department and the College.
