Announcement of successful applicants is expected to commence in March and April. I understand that the AMA has been very critical about its omission from the panel. The fact of the matter is that the AMA was initially offered a position on the panel but rejected that offer. So the claim that it has been omitted is quite mischievous in view of the fact that it dismissed the Government's offer when it was made.

The demonstration grants are intended to include, but are not limited to, enhanced continuity of care through the provision of after-hours, home and off-site consultations by general practice doctors and the development of better links between general practitioners and other providers such as hospitals and allied skill workers. Another range of uses is the provision of a greater variety of primary health care services such as group and personal health promotion and disease preventative services and allied health care. Where do we get any emphasis at all on preventative health in the Fightback program? It ignores the actual needs of individuals and goes to a whole lot of totally spurious changes such as those in the taxation system which will benefit nobody except perhaps some medical practitioners.

Other possibilities under the demonstration grants are practice consolidation to encourage the formation of clinically and economically viable practices or cooperation between GPs, community health services and hospitals, a larger range of appropriately qualified practice staff, practice nurses, practice-based community nurses, other allied health professionals, and practice managers to complement the work of the general practitioners and to promote greater efficiency, and improving and continuing education and training for all practice staff and participation in the training of medical students and/or family medicine program trainees. These are all totally praiseworthy and legitimate projects within a program which obviously appeals very strongly to those general practitioners who wish to provide for their clients a range of services which is beyond the usual narrow general practitioner service. The applications are being assessed currently and the grants to the successful applicants will be announced quite soon.

It is clear from what I have said today that we in the Government are looking ahead and have been doing so for some time. The reason that we needed an inquiry into hospital services in Australia was not that our hospital system was on the point of disintegration; it was that there were inadequacies and we could see that there were ways of changing and of improving and wanted to make sure it was done in the correct way. Rejigging the health system to make it a matter of private responsibility for individuals—many of whom simply cannot afford it—seems to me a totally specious and superficial way of approaching the whole question.

To come back to the demonstration grant as another example of the way in which we hope to go, special consideration will be given to applications targeting areas currently underserviced—that is, rural and remote areas—or providing services catering to the special needs of areas with high numbers of disadvantaged groups, such as, for example, homeless youth, unemployed people, those with AIDS and so on. Our plans are targeted, they are well thought through and they are the result, as I said earlier, of a great deal of consultation.

To conclude, if the Opposition was truly concerned for the health of the Australian people, it would not be advocating the introduction of a totally new taxation system of which it is said by Mr Dwyer, an economic consultant with the Australian Catholic Social Welfare Commission, that there should be suspicions of any tax reform package which claimed that there were no losers. We cannot all be winners. Initial losers would be those who spent more of their income than average on consumption, such as families, the very people who are the widest users of any health system. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to speak for the remainder of my allotted time.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I spoke previously solely in response to Senator Coulter's misinterpretation of our policy, but I now want to speak to the motion before us. Changing Australia's health system to one which is more reliant on individual and private initiative and less on government, while improving service quality, requires fundamental reform at many levels. The challenge is to bring about changes in a predictable, orderly manner with minimum disruption and with clear objectives in mind.

PARA.TAB: This challenge has obviously not been met by the Government and it behoves the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) to address it in his statement tomorrow. The most recent example of his failure to understand the problem, let alone address it, was the reversal of the decision to introduce patient co-payment of medical fees. The original decision was quite correctly based on the need to take urgent action on the burgeoning cost of health care. The reversal of the decision had everything to do with who should be leader of the Government and nothing to do with the delivery of health care. To quote the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, Mr Howe, on 20 August 1991, he said:

SPEECH.PARA: The major problem facing Australia's health care system is the growth in use of medical services per person. This growth means that every 20 years the number of medical services per person doubles.
A further quote from the same speech reads:
The national health strategy has indicated that an integrated approach that addresses the demand and supply sides together could have a major impact on growth in the use of medical services.

He went on to detail the measures associated with the introduction of co-payment. And then he was rolled. The Deputy Prime Minister, no less, was quite correct, but he trod on the ideological nerve endings of the troglodyte left wing of the Labor Party and was humiliated. I am sure that those of us who believe in Parliament, as opposed to politics, squirmed as we witnessed Mr Howe trying to justify the reversal of the decision rather than resign.

PARA.TAB: Demand and supply is at the bottom of the problem of waiting lists in our public hospitals. Senator Giles referred to it and misrepresented our policy in relation to preventative health care. The largest single preventative measure that could be achieved in this country would be to influence the consumption of cigarettes. This Government has not had the guts to ban the advertising of cigarettes when that is the very least that it could do to try to prevent the massive death toll that results in this country because of the smoking of cigarettes.

We have a grossly over-utilised public sector and an under-utilised private hospital sector. Yesterday we saw reports of an increase of 14 per cent over the previous year in New South Wales of patients waiting for non-emergency surgery. There are now over 24,000 people, with 20 per cent waiting six months or more. These figures are paralleled in other States. Furthermore, I am aware that in at least one State, there have been selected delays in more expensive surgery such as joint replacements because of fiscal constraints. Waiting lists, however, are blunt measures of failure. Like icebergs, they are only the tip of the problem, but they are visible. Less visible are the more fundamental problems.

Commonwealth Budget outlays on health have increased from 7.6 per cent of total outlays in 1983-84 to 13.5 per cent in 1991-92. They have nearly doubled. This reflects the increasing use and cost of technology, the use of pathology and radiology, the dramatic increase in health insurance rates—over 100 per cent in the last five years—the use and cost of pharmaceuticals, the increase in population and the increase in those over 60 in the population. It represents and reflects the increasing number of doctors—there has been a 50 per cent increase in the last 10 years—the increase in unit labour costs, the maldistribution of health personnel; the gap between Medicare fees and Medicare refund; the increasing demand for nursing home beds; the increasing number of pensioners, going from 2.9 million to 3.8 million, an increase of 22 per cent in the last five years; the demand for screening; the increasing costs for the public hospital sector, increasing at 12 per cent per annum; and the cost shifting between State and Federal Governments in relation to pharmaceuticals, outpatients and billings.

Allied with that, we have the decreasing level of private insurance. Seventy per cent in 1983 were insured and only 44 per cent were insured in 1991. We have a dramatic deterioration in the fabric of our public hospital system in Australia which is not realised—I have not yet seen any members of the Government go to public hospitals—but only 3 per cent of recurrent costs is being spent on the public hospitals.

The other day I did a survey of the Royal Brisbane Hospital, in which I was trained, and I was appalled. The beds were the same and the paint on the walls was the same as when I trained there over 30 years ago. There is dissatisfaction at the quality of care on the part of both patients and providers. The Government response, as we heard from Senator Giles, is to introduce further controls: the use of practice budgets and the accreditation of general practices.
It has been said elsewhere that socialism has failed. Will the regulators fill the void? I quote from today's Dateline News Digest:

SPEECH.PARA: In Russian hospitals, patients bring their own food and medicine, pay for a change of bedsheets and pray for a merciful operation.

Faced with run-down and overcrowded wards, extreme shortages and dubious care for all but the privileged, falling ill in the former Soviet Union is not to be recommended. That is the direction in which the Government is going. More controls, less expenditure and head in the same direction. They are asking us to do that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have you seen the health system in the United States lately?

—It is one of the best in the world for those who can afford it. There are five main objectives in the coalition's health policy. First, we will maintain universal coverage of health care for the whole population while expecting those who can afford it to take some responsibility for their own health costs. Secondly, we will establish the financial and legislative framework for the States to take over the responsibility for the delivery of health services once the structural reform measures are firmly in place. Thirdly, we will maintain and improve existing standards of health care delivery for pensioners, war veterans and welfare beneficiaries. Fourthly, in cooperation with the States, we will carry out a major program of structural reform of health delivery systems, particularly hospitals, through better incentives, improved management practices, contracting out and implementation of our industrial relations reforms. Finally, we will eliminate the starvation of funds to health systems, particularly the hospitals, by achieving a better mix of private and public funding and service deliveries.

PARA.TAB: These objectives can be achieved and they are imperative. It has been said that health is the aftertaste of society's other activities, the residue of all its policies. Thus it appears to be in political terms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—A man called Karpf. The health portfolio is usually regarded as the poisoned chalice: it is not a portfolio that people like to come to terms with because of its difficulty. Good health is of vital concern to all Australians. For too long, Australia's provision of health services has been stunted by a system that has reduced individual and family responsibility, damaged the professional standing and sense of fulfilment of doctors, nurses, physiotherapists, administrators and other health workers, and threatened the reputation for excellence of Australia's hospitals. Changing the system into one more responsive to human needs and less reliant on government is a massive task. As in so many areas of Australian society, it involves fundamental reform at many levels. As I said previously, the challenge is to bring about the changes in a predictable, orderly manner with clear objectives in mind.

PARA.TAB: Reforming the health system is fairly simple if it could only be understood by the Government. There is no magic cake. There is a private sector and a public sector and there is a private purse and a public purse. We can either take it all out of the public purse, as the Government is intent on doing, or we can take it partially out of the public purse and partially out of the private purse, as we are advocating with our policy.

Overall, we advocate freedom of choice—the right of people to go into the public system or the right of people to opt out of the public system. That is what we propose with our policy. We are offering and encouraging individuals to take more responsibility for both preventative and curative care by giving financial subsidies, particularly aimed at those with low incomes and the aged. We allow freedom of choice with financial incentives to take out private insurance. Not all the measures taken can be popular, but if the necessary decisions are not taken now the results will become progressively worse, leading to greater problems later on.

There is no reason why Australia's health prevention and care system cannot be the best in the world. I believe that with the coalition's health policy we have this opportunity. We have a golden opportunity to introduce a system that will be the envy of the world rather than a run-down, slowly disintegrating system that exists now. The coalition's health policy marks out the essential first steps in that direction and its introduction is now a matter of urgency. I support the motion.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the third part of this motion, there is no doubt in the minds of most Australians that the Government needs to take urgent action to expand resources and provide greater choice and higher standards in education. Only through education can Australia thrive and become the truly great nation that it has the potential to be. It is ironic, therefore, that a government that purports to fight for social justice and which has continually stated the need for a clever country has neglected education in Australia.

PARA.TAB: Under the Labor Government our education standards have deteriorated to the extent that, in 1992, 50,000 eligible students cannot obtain easy entry to a university and approximately 150,000 students will be locked out of TAFE positions. This is not social justice and it certainly does not lead to the creation of a clever country. The decay of the Australian education system must be turned around and only a coalition government is capable of doing this through the Fightback program of reform that will expand resources and provide greater choice and higher standards in education.

In all areas of education in Australia the Labor Government has failed. It has failed to recognise the vital importance of this sector; it has failed to provide adequate resources to the sector; and it has failed to give the education sector the freedom to flourish. Mr Keating failed to realise when he forced upon us the worst recession in 60 years that it was naturally going to increase the demand for tertiary places as unemployment skyrocketed to a post-war high of 10.6 per cent. Despite the overwhelming demand, the Labor Government continues to neglect this sector. This is best illustrated by the Government's inability to adequately fund tertiary places to meet demand and, with its outdated ideology, the Government refuses to give back to the university the freedom to offer additional places to students who could get private sector funding. The present Government was warned by the Industry Commission in the middle of last year of the gross unfairness to Australian students that was being caused by its policies, and it has still failed to act.

Education and training are amongst the most important investments any country can make. In Australia this year we are seeing the tragic consequences of the Government's failure to give post-school training the importance it deserves. The only solution to this crisis is a change of government and the immediate implementation of the Fightback reform package. Education and training will have a vital place within the program of reform of the first Hewson government. Australia's long term future will be guaranteed only if the knowledge and skills of Australians are equal to the world's best. Our education and training policies are an integral part of our strategy to provide soundly based job opportunities and improve the quality of life for all Australians this decade. Our schools, training institutions and universities must encourage a desire for learning, the pursuit of excellence and ensure that Australians are fully prepared for the challenges of a changing and highly competitive world.

The coalition will raise the standard of Australian education and training to international levels and make Australia a leading provider of education and training services. The level of skills in Australia's work force is a key to determining our international competitiveness. Australia is lagging behind its main competitors. At a time of historically high unemployment, such as is now being experienced, training and retraining have a crucial role to play in maximising job opportunities for those currently out of work and for laying the foundations and basis for economic growth in the future.

The Finn report on post-compulsory education found that Australia fell short of best international practice with regard to this type of education. The report stated that Australia will need to pay greater regard to rapid development in competitor nations if we are to maintain or improve our performance relative to best international practice. It is important, therefore, that the goals of education and training relate not only to participation programs but also to standards of attainment.

By the year 2001, at least 50 per cent of people up to the age of 22 should have obtained at least a vocational certificate or a diploma or a degree, and this has to be done if we are to have a world class system. While TAFE is generally the responsibility of the States, the Federal Government has the responsibility to ensure that in the national interest there is a high level of skill in our work force.

While the Labor Government has taken some initiatives in recent times, it has never adopted a comprehensive strategy for raising the level of skills in Australia to an international level. Its ideology of centralist control and support of excessive union power has consistently distorted its approach. If we are ever to achieve excellence in education and training, we must break down the monopolies that we have in the bureaucracy and the unions, devolve responsibility and encourage competition and choice.

Training policy must be integrated fully with an overall education policy encompassing schools, industry training, tertiary education in all its forms and private as well as public education provision. By the same token, training cannot be left to the unstructured hit and miss methods of the past. We must set national goals which embrace the needs of industry and commerce for specific training, and meet those goals with a combination of flexible and highly qualified provision.

Industry has a key role in the provision of skills, either through enterprise based training or through the use of external trainers, both private and TAFE. Industry should meet the cost of such training. Industry also has a vital role to play through links with all levels of education, ensuring that these providers are aware of the significance of the workplace for their curriculum. TAFE has a central role in lifting the levels of skills of Australians. It is the largest provider of post-school education and has a particular role in relation to the upgrading of adult skills and providing courses for disadvantaged groups.

There are serious structural problems in TAFE arising from the rigidities imposed by the centralised administration and industrial relations arrangements applying within the TAFE system. Above all, TAFE must be flexible and responsive to the needs of local industry and be able to provide the training courses which industry requires. TAFE's primary role is to provide high quality entry level training and advanced training for industry.

Total TAFE enrolments grew steadily throughout the 1980s but declined in 1989 and 1990 and now, in 1992, we have 150,000 students unable to obtain entry to a TAFE course. This is completely unacceptable in a modern industrial society and reflects the needs to ensure adequate funding for TAFE and proper recognition of its key role in the national training systems in accordance with the recommendations of the Finn report that I alluded to earlier.

In stark contrast to the Labor Government's policy of neglect, the Liberal and National parties will work with the States and Territories to ensure greater freedom for TAFE institutions to respond to the needs of their local communities and to rationalise fee paying arrangements. In resourcing TAFE, institutions should be encouraged to expand resources raised from fee for service and other activities.

The coalition believes that for TAFE to perform its vital role, structural reform of the TAFE system is essential. Therefore, we will ensure that TAFE has greater autonomy in relation to staffing and conditions of employment, a high level of independence for TAFE directors and boards and the ability to charge fees where appropriate. Recognising the key role of TAFE in the national training arrangements, the coalition will ensure that the growth of TAFE is adequately supported and, to this end, undertakes to increase funding by $75m a year above current commitments, or $450m to fund growth in TAFE over the remaining years of this decade.

Unlike the Labor Government, the Fightback program's primary objective for higher education is a university system of world class standard, providing the diversity of opportunity required to meet the diversity of student needs. There must be places in the universities for all students with the capacity to pursue higher education, and no student should be prevented from undertaking higher education on financial grounds alone. The key role of the universities as the primary location of basic research effort needs to be strengthened. Under the Labor Government our universities have suffered a drain of academics of world class standard, chronic overcrowding in lectures and tutorials and the disgraceful statistic of 50,000 eligible students unable to obtain entry to a tertiary institution.

The Labor Government has also destroyed any basis for institutional autonomy that the universities of Australia once had. The establishment of the national unified system by the former Minister for Education, Employment and Training has created a system of higher education which is directed by political and bureaucratic discretion. Resource allocation is highly centralised and institutions are tightly regulated with respect to their student numbers and course offerings.

Under the Labor Government, a narrow agenda was imposed on universities which were seen as adjuncts to the economy. There has been no appreciation of the breadth of their role and contribution to knowledge and society. The fundamental weakness of the present system is that there is excessive reliance on centralised direction and regulation in an attempt to improve efficiency in teaching and research. Institutions are operating under significant bureaucratic interference. Financial constraints, rigidities of centralised industrial relations, centrally coordinated institutional profiles, restrictions on the development of new programs and on student admissions all serve as barriers to efficiency and to adaptations to the demands of the student market.

The basic research efforts of the universities have been disrupted by ad hoc decision making and by the damaging clawback of funds from the operating grants for redistribution through the Australian Research Council. Researchers have lost a large part of their decision making autonomy and the central role of intellectual inquiry and creativity has been undermined.

The problems being faced by Australian higher education at the present time are the characteristic symptoms to be expected from a centrally regulated system. The appropriate strategy to correct them is a significant deregulation of higher education and greater exposure of students and institutions to market signals. This strategy is a part of the Fightback reform program and should therefore be adopted.

The coalition in its Fightback strategy has developed strong incentives to promote excellence. Government regulation and imposed uniformity stifles initiative and diversity and leads to mediocrity. A genuinely competitive framework for higher education will allow each institution to develop in its own way. Freedom for institutions, academics and students requires a decisive move away from a centrally administered system to one based on a greatly strengthened student market in which students can choose their university according to their own judgment, and institutions have the flexibility to respond to these choices.

As we are all aware, Australia's education sector has been led to disaster by this Labor Government. There are not enough resources at a time when the Government is indirectly forcing record numbers of people off the dole queues and into our universities and TAFE colleges. This has created massive overcrowding and record numbers of young people are missing out on higher and further education. This is an appalling situation. It has been addressed by the recommendations of the Finn report which demands much more emphasis on post-compulsory education.

At the same time, through the centralised system introduced by Mr Dawkins, the education sector has been reduced to one of conformity and an arm of Government policy. The result has been one of low morale, dropping standards and academics leaving for the private sector. The only way to redress this is for the policies outlined in Fightback! to be adopted. With the better resources, greater choice and higher standards that the Fightback package will provide, the education sector can lead Australia to the competitive edge of the international economy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The urgency motion we have before us today is quite interesting because it is the first stage of discussions about education in this chamber that stem from the so-called Fightback proposals that Mr John Hewson has put before us. It is really the first opportunity we have had to debate the question of what the Liberal and National parties would do in the area of education if they got into government.

PARA.TAB: I am sure that hundreds of pages of documentation have been put before the press and this House indicating what the Opposition might do if, for some reason or other, it happened to get into government in the next year or so. Let us go back to square one: who really cares about education? My guess is that it is people who consider that Australia needs a trained work force. It is those who consider that education is socially a liberating experience for many people who otherwise would never have been able to fulfil all of their potential. It is those who think that education is a way of making society work because it gives people a chance, it teaches them tolerance and it teaches them to fulfil their personal ambitions. All those sorts of things are part of the whole educational process. It is why all societies that are intelligent invest in education.

When did that real investment in education start? Where did it start at a national level? It is very obvious, if one looks at the history of Australian educational politics, that the real efforts started with the Whitlam Government. Before that one must give credit to the former Liberal Prime Minister, John Gorton, for the attempts that he made to introduce education into the national agenda. Of course, his party was not all that interested in that issue. One need only look at the way the Liberal Party ranked its Cabinet in that period. It was pretty obvious that education did not count for too much in terms of the hierarchy of Liberal government Cabinets and Ministries before Whitlam turned up on the scene. It was Whitlam who first actually put down the vision for the development of education in this country by a national government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Menzies, actually.
—Menzies had a few views but, as we all know, basically he was living in a world that was based upon some sort of acute late 1940s view of what the world was all about.
—What was inflation under Menzies?

—If Senator Parer wants to argue about economics, we could talk about the inflation rate that Menzies presided over following the Korean War; we could talk about the lost opportunities in terms of investment in Australia's productive capacity; we could talk about the lost markets in South East Asia and Asia that Menzies deliberately turned the Australian economy away from. We could talk about those things if he wants to. Let us face it: the Menzies era was a golden era. We all remember that. It was the time when we ran home for lunch every day. We had treacle and white bread for lunch and mummies always stayed at home to look after us. We are talking about the real world now; we are talking about a world which is much more competitive. Australia has to look after itself in a very tough world.

PARA.TAB: Those opposite can look back to the golden era for as long as they like. The simple fact is that Australia is now in one of the toughest parts of the world in terms of international economic competition. In fact, as a result of about 40 years of intellectual malingering on the part of Liberal-Country Party governments, we are not able to face the fact that we have to compete with countries which are prepared to work, which have thought about their futures, which have no natural resources to fall back on and which are streets ahead of us at the moment.

Whether we like it culturally or otherwise, we are in the south-east Asian region, we have to earn our living there and it requires a certain degree of intellectual activity on our part in order to compete. Senator Panizza, Senator Brownhill and others may have properties or businesses to hand on to their sons and daughters—I do not have that; a lot of people that I represent do not have that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who earned them in the first place? Not by sitting on your backside.

—Senator Panizza should not get excited. I simply mentioned the fact that if parents were able to pass on their businesses to their sons or daughters, that is fine for them and they are lucky. But most of us, and most of the people that we represent, do not have that luxury. Children have to go into the work force and get what they can. They enter occupations that maybe they do not always choose. They are young people who will have to face a very competitive future in a world which is not going to say, `Australians must have all the benefits because they are the chosen people of not only South East Asia but also of Europe'. The simple fact is that Europe has turned its back on us and the United States is increasingly going to be America first, regardless of whether Buchanan wins the election or not. We are not going to be given a free ride by anybody in the world.

PARA.TAB: Education has two functions. The first is to give people certain power and authority in their lives, to give them skills to compete. The second is to give them a certain view about the world, to open their eyes to the possibilities of what could go on. The so-called Fightback proposals of the Liberal Party, which it dropped on us months ago, strike a chord with the Australian public. There is no doubt about that. Most Australians said, `It is very nice to have a party which is prepared to go out, put everything in a nice capsule and say, "This pill, if you take it, will make you better"'. Senator Herron is one of those who would fully appreciate that the placebo effect in medicine, as well as in politics, is a very important factor.

The simple fact is that although the Australian public for a time said, `It is nice to see a package put together by Dr Hewson, it is nice to see that there are some simple solutions to our problems', they are now starting to realise, by a process of discussion, by a process of analysis, by a process of debate, that the so-called Fightback package is designed for public relations purposes to win elections. It actually cannot withstand proper economic analysis. More importantly, it actually confuses people and deludes people in the sense that it is sold on the basis that it will solve all of our problems. They are not that simple.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish.
—Yes, it is a load of rubbish; quite right.

—Yes, the Fightback package is a load of rubbish. I agree with Senator Panizza. He said that the Fightback package is a load of rubbish and I understand that. Maybe he expressed some views in the party room and he was rolled. The Opposition will have to make some cuts which will be horrendous in their impact, which will, to use a crude term, knacker the Australian economy and the Australian arrangement in order to make ends meet. If, at the end of the day, the Opposition happens to achieve those objectives, it deserves an OBE or the Victoria Cross. There is no way that we can get out of the difficulties that Australia is in at the moment unless we plan for the long term and education is part of that.

PARA.TAB: Senator Tierney, in many ways, said some things that I agree with. He said that if, for example, there are tight central controls by unimaginative bureaucrats who cannot see beyond their noses—let alone beyond their State; let alone beyond Australia—if they are running the show and if they have total domination of what is decided in terms of education policy, we are in difficulty.

The simple fact is, that is not going to happen. We have a political process here into which all of us have an input: Senator Tierney, the Opposition, the Government, Cabinet—you name it—the education groups. In the end, all the consumers of education in this community will decide what we will do. The planners can talk about the creation of so many places in universities; they can say, `This is the direction in which education ought to go' at high school level, primary school level or higher education level, but, at the end of the day, the consumers will decide. The consumers will decide in ways that will not be predicted by the bureaucrats—and the Government accepts that. Maybe some of the bureaucrats do not accept it, but then, let us face it, they do not speak for us, they do not speak for Opposition senators and they do not speak for the consumers. In this place the important thing as far as education is concerned is that we try to work our way through that.

The process of politics, of course, is one in this chamber—and I guess in most places—where we pull apart; we try to put our separate options. We do not allow for the fine analysis which is ultimately necessary for us to make the right decisions. We can go back over our history, but to go back to the point at which I started my speech, the turning point was the Whitlam Government. It may not have spent money on education wisely, but it did say loudly and clearly to the bureaucrats, to the Parliament and to the Australian community, `Education is important'. It was prepared to spend up to $3 billion on education a year overall.

That in itself was the message to the Australian community which I believe all of us took up. Senator Tierney may well be right in some of the technical comments and criticisms he has made about the way we are moving at the moment, but the one thing he cannot deny is the fact that the Labor Party has put a value on education far higher, far greater than any government ever did before us. In other words, Whitlam started it and when we got back into government we continued it.

I have had my debates, discussions and disagreements with Minister Dawkins. Nobody in this place denies that. I do not deny it in the Party room. It has been a healthy disagreement. I have said, `Bureaucrats have too much influence. They are unimaginative; they are not outward looking. You accept their advice too often'. I have said that. I believe that at the end of the day we have come to an arrangement—an agreement—about where we should be going, and I believe that the bureaucrats have been put in their place on many occasions. There are other areas where I have lost completely, and Senator Tierney, I think, would be very well aware of those.

The simple fact is that education has now been put on the agenda. It has been put on the agenda by a Labor Government—a Labor Government which has convinced people that we have to spend money; we have to increase our expenditure; and we have to put an emphasis on education, because education and training is an area where the future of Australia, our competitiveness, is going to be decided. It will not be decided by the 26-year-old who sits in front of the VDU and says, `Let's move the Australian dollar up a point or two'. Those people come and go. In a sense, they are restricted already by Australian government policy. What will count is how we train our young people for the future.

I can go through all the details, and I will leave those until a later debate because I will be quite happy to debate this whole question of educational funding and educational policy in this chamber, but I do not want to do it in 12 minutes. I do not think that is of any value to either this chamber or to the Australian public. What I want to do today is put on the record what we have done in terms of emphasising the importance of education in this community and, if we have done it and Opposition senators are prepared to either back us or take it further, then we would pat them on the back. The simple fact is, education is now on the agenda and we have done it. (Time expired)
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australia and North-East Asia in the 1990s: Accelerating Change

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating today the report called Australia and North-East Asia in the 1990s: Accelerating Change prepared by the East Asia Analytical Unit of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The importance of the north-east Asian region to Australia can hardly be overstated. It must be cause for regret that this report will receive a maximum of only half an hour's consideration, with five minutes allocated to each speaker.

PARA.TAB: The importance of this region to Australia can be gauged from the trade figures with that region. Over 40 per cent of Australia's merchandise exports go to the region and almost 30 per cent of our imports come from it. Japan alone amounts to almost 30 per cent of Australia's merchandise exports and supplies 20 per cent of imports. It is also the single most important market for education exports.

We see quite clearly from the region and its development that there has been a massive shift in that region, exemplified by Japan in particular, towards high-tech industries. Japan has now consolidated its position with products which require high levels of skill, knowledge and sophisticated technology. Indeed, high value service industries are now growing rapidly as incomes rise. The other nations in that group, notably the Republic of Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong, are now in the position in which Japan found itself a decade or so ago and they are moving very quickly up the ladder in this shift towards high-tech industries.

When one looks at this development one realises that the expenditure in any one nation on research and development is perhaps the single most important factor. We note from page 3 of the report that in Japan, the Republic of Korea, Taiwan and Hong Kong, government research and development expenditure has been increasing by around 15 per cent a year and private sector research and development expenditure at an even higher rate. When we compare that with the Australian situation, where we barely keep pace at a much lower level and there is no notable increase, I believe we have some cause for concern.

A recent report by the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development showed Japanese expenditure on research and development at the level of 2.85 per cent of GDP. Compared with that figure, Australia stands at 1.23 per cent of GDP—less than half and almost a third. But the most important and worrying factor is that in the past five years we have been at that level and no increases have been recorded. We must realise, therefore, that there are certain policy challenges for Australia, particularly in developing our high technology manufacturing industries.

The report makes a number of other recommendations, some of which are fairly obvious and general. The report recommends that we should develop a more competitive economy; that we should achieve better coordination between the public and private sectors; that we should have stronger multilateral and bilateral trading systems; that we should express support for Asia-Pacific economic cooperation, and so on. There are others which require comment and a different emphasis or even qualified dissent.

I refer to a question that I put earlier today to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Senator Evans) asking him to indicate what assistance Australian manufacturing industries will be receiving from the Government in overcoming the barriers which are present in these north-east Asian countries and in other areas of our region. It was clear—and it is confirmed by this report—that no such assistance will be forthcoming.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to address some aspects of the report entitled Australia and North-East Asia in the 1990s: Accelerating Change. There is little about which one can argue in terms of the summary of conclusions in the report. I have not had the opportunity to read all aspects of the report as yet and it will require considerable study to analyse it all. I refer to the conclusion in the report relating to policy changes, which states that it will be important for Australia to continue to pursue sound macro-economic policies, micro-economic reform and improvements in international competitiveness.

PARA.TAB: We have just listened to a debate led by Senator Short and others from our side regarding the changes we need in Australia at this time. It is particularly fitting that the report should be brought down at this time, some 24 hours before a statement from the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) concerning the future of Australia—albeit that it is at the end of a long line of statements similar to this one or with the same name.

I want to emphasise some points that are very important in terms of our international competitiveness. The first is the necessity, if we are to be competitive with the Asian region, to maximise what is happening in Asia. While there is a lot of emphasis on Japan, from what I have read of this report so far it is also worth noting that in Asia we have an economy the size of Japan's growing about every 18 months.

While this report refers to North East Asia, it is crucial that in tomorrow's economic statement such impediments on business as the wholesale sales tax, fuel excise, payroll tax and a number of other development impediments to maximising opportunities in Asia be considered seriously. Their removal would give business the ability to maximise the potential that exists in Asia and would allow the horrific levels of unemployment we have now in this country to be addressed in a meaningful, long term manner.

The report mentions micro-economic reform, which includes the waterfront, transport and aspects of our export regulations under AQIS. On those aspects of our policy position, I emphasise that, even though there have been reported massive changes on the waterfront, which have been at significant cost to the Australian taxpayer and the people operating on it, I have yet to have an industry say to me that the cost of getting goods across the waterfront has decreased.

TALK.START.PARA: —They have increased.
—They have increased, not decreased. So one must question very seriously whether we are better off for the taxpayers' dollars that have been invested in the waterfront.

PARA.TAB: I want to talk briefly about AQIS. In export regulation, there are still massive inefficiencies, there is still massive overemployment, and there are costs and restrictions which impact on our ability to penetrate the north-east Asian market. We must have proper labour market reform. That matter has not been addressed effectively by the Government. If we are to compete and trade in these markets, we must have labour market reform. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak very briefly on this matter. It is something that needs a lot more than five minutes to deal with. I have read the report briefly, but what prompted me to get to my feet was the sheer hypocrisy of what the Australian Democrats said. As Senator Spindler said, our future lies in South East Asia and with the north-east Asian countries such as Japan, Taiwan, Korea and so on. But if ever people have gone out of their way to deter trade from that area it is people such as Senator Spindler and Mrs Kelly.

PARA.TAB: Only last week in the Brisbane Courier Mail an article stated that the Japanese were going to put money into infrastructure on the west coast of the United States so that they could increase their purchases of coal from the United States and thus have a lesser reliance on Australia. It so happened that I had arranged on that day to have lunch with some old Japanese friends from one of the major trading companies with whom I had dealt over the past 20 years but with whom I do not deal today. I asked them whether the remarks of the Democrats and Mrs Kelly about carbon taxes and the reduction of CO(2) levels to unachievable figures had affected the Japanese thinking in any way. They said, `Of course it does'. It is not a major issue at this stage, but it is just another little nail in the coffin where the Japanese, who rely entirely on resources for their continued existence—

TALK.START.PARA: —The Japanese have an exemplary environmental record, don't they!

—What an amazing remark. We have the Democrats on the one hand talking about increasing trade—I just heard Senator Spindler say it—and on the other hand Senator Coulter saying what an amazingly bad record the Japanese have. The Japanese have had incredible growth and we have benefited from that growth. This report enhances the view of what has been happening over the past 20 years. Certainly, Japan had problems because of its high growth rates, but if ever a country has addressed those problems it is Japan. The Democrats should recognise this when it occurs, instead of sitting back criticising and doing their damnedest to help destroy the trade we enjoy and thus our standard of living. For goodness sake, get out of the bottom of the garden and be real. That is a fact. If the Democrats do not want us to trade with Japan, they should go on the way they are. We are not the only supplier of materials to that country. Many other countries would be happy to take our place and are waiting in the queue to do so.

PARA.TAB: I also noted the remarks of the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) in Darwin when he suggested that the Japanese should apologise for what happened 50 years ago. I was offended by that. I suffered from what happened in the Second World War. My father was the first Australian killed in New Guinea, but neither my family nor myself want the Japanese to apologise publicly. Casting the sins of the parents back on the children is an utter nonsense, and it is something that is preoccupying this country.

That remark also stunned my Japanese friends. Their concern was that if one wants to be populist, as the Prime Minister obviously was trying to be and as Mrs Kelly apparently tries to be, one offends people who through no fault of their own and who actually are major tourists into the country—

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in Darwin when he said it. Totally supportable statement.
—Absolutely insupportable and ridiculous.
—I speak for every serviceman I spoke to. Total nonsense.
—Does Senator Collins know that Japanese tourists who come here are concerned, because of those sorts of remarks, that they are about to be subject to some of the lunatic fringe in this country.
—Total nonsense.
—If Senator Collins cannot recognise that, there is something wrong with him.
—Order!
—Those remarks are unwarranted. They do not help us. We are relying on an increase in tourism. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Giles Sen P.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I have two purposes in speaking to the Training for Aboriginals Program—Review. First, of course, it is an excellent review which will provide a lot of material for policy development. I particularly want to pay tribute to the author of the report, Elliott Johnston, QC, who, as we know, has made an inestimable contribution to the sum of knowledge and informed debate on questions fundamental to the well-being and status of Aborigines and Torres Strait Islanders, having completed his term with the Royal Commission inquiry which he headed for much of its duration. The Commission reported about half way through last year and Mr Johnston then commenced work on this particular review, which was completed by the end of the year and which, once again, provides us with a great deal of information and direction.

PARA.TAB: It is impossible for me in these few minutes to summarise the wide range of recommendations that are made as a result of the review, but I would like to draw the Senate's attention to just two or three issues which are highlighted in this program. One of the fundamental questions faced by Mr Johnston was whether the training for Aboriginals program is for training or for employment. He very firmly came down on the side of its being a training program operating within the Aboriginal employment development program. This issue was in need of clarification in view of existing guidelines which were somewhat confusing for the personnel involved. At paragraph 3.27 of this report, Mr Johnston expresses the view that TAP is for training on three broad grounds, the most important of which is that it:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . is the best way in which Aboriginal people, disadvantaged by history, by poor educational outcomes, by little or no work experience, by absence of capital reserves, by absence of entry into jobs by way of family or friendships with non-Aboriginal business people and by prejudice can in fact enter the employment field (using that word as above).
That is a direct quote from the report.

PARA.TAB: He also draws attention to special needs groups, and these he details as youth, women and prisoners. Referring to the final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, which focused on the particular needs of those involved in the criminal justice system, he then makes recommendations for education and training within that justice system and reiterates much of what was said in the report of the Royal Commission.

He refers also to the particularly disadvantaged group of Aboriginal women, emphasising that they have a much lower labour force participation rate than Aboriginal men. He suggests that one way in which programs can be tailored more to the needs of women is to widen the concept of employment to include part time employment. He emphasises that there is a high ratio of young people and children to adults among the Aboriginal population and that many women, although they wish to return to work, cannot do so on a full time basis. He goes on to say, inter alia:

SPEECH.PARA: Given the high present unemployment rate, I think it is highly desirable that part-time work be encouraged by providing subsidy and training assistance for part-time positions just as it is provided for full-time ones—

There is provision for this in the TAP manual. Another reference to women comes right at the end of the report where he suggests that the enterprise employment assistance program be extended so as to be a cost neutral benefit made available to Aboriginal incorporated organisations wishing to avail themselves of the benefit—once again, a scheme which `might be particularly useful for women with families for whom full time work is often quite unsuitable'.

PARA.TAB: I commend the report to the Senate and to all people who are concerned about the high unemployment rate among Aboriginals, the lack of employment opportunities for them and the enormous enhancement which will come with education and training for employment.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.PARA: I congratulate the Australian Wheat Board on its annual report for the year 1990-91 and on the work it does in trying to maximise the net returns to Australian wheat growers.

PARA.TAB: If we are looking for a critical year for Australia's wheat growers, then the period covered by this report would be it. It is obvious when reading the report that the year provided the Australian Wheat Board with one of the toughest marketing environments in recent years. It had to cope with record world wheat production, export subsidies at record levels, a static import demand and low world prices. It is sad to read that some growers suffered the same fate that many others involved in Australia's rural industries have suffered over the past few years.

The report notes that `some growers were unable to withstand the substantial decline in wheat returns while the livelihood of many others has been threatened'. I note from page 2 of the Chairman's report that the AWB's focus in the period was, therefore, to try to minimise the impact of this world situation on growers.

The 1990-91 marketing year was a turning point for the international wheat market. A record level of world wheat production combined with increased, aggressive use of export subsidies forced prices lower. The Chairman reported:

SPEECH.PARA: The AWB continues to be dismayed that the United States and the European Community persist in using export subsidies which artificially lower prices and distort world trade patterns.
He also noted:
Pressure on these countries to reduce their subsidies must be maintained—
and that, therefore, the Board—
supports the Australian Government's position in the Uruguay General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade round (GATT).
He said further:
A successful outcome of the Uruguay round should yield meaningful and lasting trade reforms to the benefit of the Australian grain industry.
Furthermore, the Chairman reported:

World grain trade is likely to be increasingly dominated by the availability of government-backed credit, combined with the use of export subsidies. This will place pressure on Australia's ability to compete with the credit terms offered by other major exporters.

I have heard many speakers in the Senate and in the media argue about the merits of free trade and the abolition of tariffs, but I have yet to see any significant benefits flow to our rural sector. Only hardship seems to be the end result. Australia has been building its tariff policy around its commitment to the Uruguay round of GATT. We are told that it is necessary for Australia to reduce its tariff barriers to demonstrate our good faith at GATT and to encourage the larger, more powerful nations to demonstrate that they will follow our lead.

PARA.TAB: However, it seems to me that this philosophy is not working. The EC and other countries have failed to respond to any of the initiatives taken by Australia and other trading nations. This came under the spotlight in the Senate last year when we addressed the Customs Tariff Amendment Bill. In that debate the Government outlined how it intended to set what it calls a level playing field for the motor vehicle industry, the textiles, clothing and footwear industry, the vegetable industry and the sugar industry. What concerns me greatly is that it did this without regard to the impact of its policies on the competitive conditions under which producers in each of those industries work.

In following this policy, what we are really saying is that, because we are on the altar of free trade, because we want to be able to hold our hands on our hearts and say to the Europeans, the Americans and the Japanese that we are acting as we believe they should act, we will be in a better position to ensure that they do so.

Unfortunately, in doing so, we place a number of our major industries in a position where there will be even more unemployed, where there will be an even larger number engaged in those industries who will be shutting up plant and moving offshore and where, in many rural sectors, we will find that imports will take over their market share. Reductions of tariffs in these areas, as some sort of grand gesture, while they are not being matched by our trading competitors—and I emphasise that—is a warm inner glow nonsense.

Indeed, no-one can ignore the impact of all the arguments and evidence about the effects of this tariff war on Australian farmers put to the President of the United States when he was here in January. George Bush simply indicated that his job was to protect American farmers first and not leave them to the mercies of such trade wars. I ask honourable senators why this Government does not do the same for our own people instead of, in effect, selling them down the chute. What makes it even more criminal is that we are doing so after people have committed their life savings in what has been a very economically difficult time.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have not had time to analyse properly the annual report of the Australian Wheat Board, although that will not stop me from speaking on it. However, I have only one minute in which to do so. The annual report shows the result of two years in which the new deregulated domestic market has operated. I am still looking for the benefits of the deregulated domestic market. From what I have seen, the deregulated domestic market has simply allowed the Australian millers, the Australian poultry feeders and the Australian stock feeders to pick the eyes out of the market for a simple $2 to $5 per ton premium. That is all they have been paying.

PARA.TAB: I was quite happy to see a deregulated domestic market in the hope that some day we might see some benefits, but we have not seen them. Under the old system—the previous regulated domestic market—the millers and the stock feeders had to take at least a reasonable amount of other wheat if they wanted to pick the eyes out of it. This has now resulted in that happening.

DEBATE.TITLE: SUBMISSION RELATING TO PROCEEDINGS IN THE SENATE AND IN ESTIMATES COMMITTEE A
