DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 13 February 1991, I table the report of the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration entitled Review of the Commonwealth Ombudsman together with the transcript of evidence which was presented to the Deputy President on 20 January 1991. In accordance with the terms of the resolution the Deputy President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: The review by the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration of the office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman was the first significant external review of the office in its 15 years of existence. The Committee undertook the inquiry at the request of the former Prime Minister following a suggestion made by the former Ombudsman, Professor Denis Pearce, shortly before his retirement. The inquiry was prompted by the concerns of Professor Pearce and his predecessors about the Ombudsman's resources and aimed to review the powers, jurisdiction and performance of the office.

PARA.TAB: The Ombudsman is generally seen as part of the administrative law system. It might therefore have seemed appropriate for any review of the office to have a legal orientation. But administrative law, by definition, affects administration and this Committee was concerned more with the impact of the Ombudsman's office than with the professional discipline within which it operates. The Committee's review was explicitly conducted from a public administration rather than a legal standpoint and concluded that the Ombudsman has made a positive contribution to Australian administration.

The nature of that contribution and of the role that should be assigned to the Ombudsman was the subject of controversy during the inquiry. The report reviews in some detail the development of the ombudsman institution, drawing out a longstanding tension between two broad concepts of the office.
I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the remainder of my remarks in this tabling statement about the Ombudsman's role and some more detailed comments about the recommendations of the Committee.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.PARA: One view of the Ombudsman holds that the office is a central link in the legal system of administrative review, a reviewer of the whole system of administration and a defender of the citizen's rights. A less ambitious but no less important possible role is in the resolution of individual complaints, many concerning simple errors or misunderstandings which offer no lessons for the administrative system, although these issues may be very important to those raising them. The contrast between the two roles has been illustrated with the metaphor of "lion hunting" versus "fly swatting".

The original proposal for a Commonwealth Ombudsman, advanced by the Kerr Committee in 1971, clearly envisaged a lion hunter. However, the detailed blueprint for the Office, contained in the Bland Report of 1973 provided specifications better suited to a fly swatter and that approach has been adopted or endorsed by successive governments. Despite lingering support for a lion-hunting role in some of the evidence to the Committee, the Ombudsman is settled in a role that is oriented primarily towards resolving large numbers of relatively minor complaints.

The report stresses that this is not an ignoble or unimportant function and the fly swatting/lion hunting metaphor may mislead. Errors and misunderstandings affecting individuals can have little significance for the overall system of administration but still be very important to the persons concerned. The Ombudsman provides a check on the unique powers and functions of government which can be of enormous significance to individuals. As a cheap, accessible remedy for people who are in dispute with government bodies, the Ombudsman contributes in a major way to equity in our society. This should be treasured at a time when so many other aspects of equity and social justice, and even the need for those qualities, are under attack.

The survival of the Ombudsman in an era when equity is unfashionable may owe something to the Ombudsman's value in promoting efficiency. Providing a voice to aggrieved clients is one of the cheapest and most efficient ways of monitoring the performance of large organisations. Witnesses from several GBEs echoed the sentiments of Telecom's corporate secretary, who told the Committee "the Ombudsman has added value to our operations" (Report, p. 42). The spread of the ombudsman institution to the private sector in the form of the Banking Industry Ombudsman supports that judgement and provides a commendable model of the private sector learning good management from the public sector.

Acknowledging the Ombudsman's contribution to equity and efficiency, the Committee made 31 recommendations for improvement. The first, recognising that the Ombudsman's main contribution is to administration rather than to law, was that the Government consider candidates from non-legal backgrounds as well as lawyers when future appointments are made to the office. The other recommendations fall into five broad groups.

Firstly, the Committee believes that all Commonwealth bodies should fall within the Ombudsman's jurisdiction unless specifically excluded for stated reasons (Report, p. 43). This reverses the present situation and would bring into the Ombudsman's jurisdiction the administrative decisions of court and tribunal registries, the parliamentary departments, and a wide range of statutory bodies and government companies. A related proposal would extend the Ombudsman's jurisdiction to employment-related complaints which are currently covered for only some Commonwealth bodies by the Merit Protection and Review Agency. The Committee also recommended that the Government consider giving the Commonwealth Ombudsman responsibility for ombudsman-type functions proposed for industries such as telecommunications.

A second group of recommendations concerned complaints about Police and other major complaints. The Ombudsman is responsible for reviewing the files on internal investigations of complaints about police and may also investigate these complaints independently. However, only one independent investigation has been undertaken in the last ten years and there have been long delays in the review of files. The Committee could not regard this situation as acceptable.

The Committee proposed that either funds be found to provide an acceptable level of review of police complaints or the function be removed from the Ombudsman. The Ombudsman and the Government together should face up to the inadequacies of the present system and devise suitable remedies.

Complaints about police are different in kind from the bulk of the Ombudsman's work. These and a handful of other complaints, such as those raising possible fraud or illegal behaviour, require formal investigation rather than informal fact finding and conciliation. They need to be resolved promptly. Recognising the qualitative difference between the few serious complaints, including those about police, and the bulk of the Ombudsman's work, the Committee recommended that the Ombudsman establish a separate investigation unit to handle major complaints.

The Committee also considered the issue of the Ombudsman's relationship with Parliament. The recommendations in this area seek to retain the Ombudsman's statutory independence while strengthening the links between the office and Parliament. The most important proposal in this regard is for the Senate and House of Representatives Committees on Finance and Public Administration to meet jointly with the Ombudsman twice each year.

A further group of recommendations aim to have the Ombudsman's existence and functions promoted more actively, with the promotion being targeted to low income and disadvantaged groups. The Committee also proposed that the Ombudsman actively seek to improve and encourage internal complaints-handling mechanisms in government departments and agencies.

In its recommendations concerning the management of the Ombudsman's Office, the Committee mainly sought to encourage the secondment of some public servants to the Ombudsman's Office and an appropriate level of lateral recruitment to the Office. The Committee rejected the idea of charging for the Ombudsman's services as inequitable and impractical, and was supported in that conclusion by the Department of Finance. However, the report suggests that departments or agencies which are subject to a high level of complaints could be required to fund the secondment of suitable staff to the Ombudsman's Office.

TALK.START.PARA: —As one who first entered Parliament in the Whitlam years, I take some pleasure in reporting on one of the genuine administrative successes of a government that has often been criticised unfairly. The establishment of an ombudsman's office was overdue by 1972 and Prime Minister Whitlam's initiative in pushing the proposal through almost to conclusion—the Bill was not passed until 1976—has proved to have been well judged. It has paid substantial dividends in the past 15 years and clearly will continue to do so. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the resolution of the Senate of 7 November 1991, I table the report of the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs entitled First Report on a National Drought Policy: Appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force which was presented to the Deputy President on 11 February 1992. In accordance with the terms of the resolution the Deputy President has authorised the printing and circulation of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.PARA: On 7 November 1991 the Senate referred to the Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs for inquiry and report the reference, `A National Drought Policy: Appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force'. This task force, of course, was a specialist and non-political or non-parliamentary task force. During the last two months the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee has undertaken an extensive program of hearings and inspections in several States in order to gauge responses to the 58 recommendations made in the report of the Drought Policy Review Task Force published in 1990. The Committee undertook an extensive program of hearings, holding them in 14 centres, mostly rural towns, and hearing evidence from over 160 witnesses. This first report on a national drought policy records many of the concerns and issues raised by these witnesses. We did give an opportunity to the audiences at these hearings to make short statements on their experiences of drought. Although that was quite new to the process of the Committee, it was very much appreciated by those people in the rural areas.

PARA.TAB: As Chairman of the Committee, I am particularly pleased that this first report was available to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Crean) and his State and Territory counterparts before the meeting of the Australian Agricultural Council, convened on 14 February 1992 to consider the principles for a national drought policy.

The Committee's report records several general conclusions relating to a national drought policy and programs to manage for drought. For example, the Committee endorses the concept of self-reliance in relation to drought management. Many witnesses told the Committee that the best drought policy is one which places the utmost reliance on the farmers' own provision for drought. In this regard, the view is often expressed to the Committee that farmers are basically looking to be self-reliant and that they are not looking for handouts.

As part of this self-reliant approach, the Committee was told that farmers and graziers must be provided with incentives to prepare for drought. Two measures to encourage self-reliance received considerable comment. These are: an income equalisation deposits scheme; and taxation arrangements relating to storage facilities for hay, grain and fodder and plant or structural improvements for conserving or conveying water.

The Committee is of the view that there is a need for an effective income equalisation deposits scheme that will encourage a self-reliant approach to farm management. The Committee also considers that, in regard to taxation arrangements, evidence for a shorter period of depreciation for storage and other facilities is persuasive, specifically when this is directed towards drought proofing of rural properties.

I must say that the Committee did consider, and properly so, that there are two aspects to preparing for drought and the resultant assistance that must be given to farmers who are in very bad circumstances. Firstly, of course, one does not want to see farmers disappear from the industry because they have not been able to manage in such conditions. Secondly, there is also concern about the national interest: that it is very important to have in place appropriate arrangements to enable farmers to provide produce for the population of Australia as well as generate quite a large amount of our export earnings. So I guess one aspect related to the self-preservation of the farmer and the second related to community interest in general. Of course, both of those issues must be thought through and provided for.

Although the concept of self-reliance received overwhelming support, it was suggested to the Committee that a self-reliant approach to drought cannot protect rural producers from extreme droughts which, statistically, might be expected to occur once or twice in a farmer's working life. It was argued that in these instances only the Commonwealth has the resources to provide such assistance.

Although advocating a greater role for the Commonwealth in situations of extreme drought, witnesses had difficulty in defining `extreme drought' and identifying appropriate trigger mechanisms for the provision of assistance from the Commonwealth. The Committee also heard differing views on how such assistance should be provided. For example, some witnesses suggested changes to the ratio of Commonwealth and State contributions to Part B of the rural adjustment scheme, or RAS as it is known. Other people advocated more direct relief by the reinstatement of Commonwealth assistance through transport subsidies for producers affected by extreme drought.

We were left in no doubt, as a result of all the evidence given to us and the obvious sincerity of those people who indicated that they were in difficulty, that the rural adjustment scheme needs adjustment, that it is not working in the way in which it was intended to work.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is hopeless.

—In answer to that interjection I say that it is not hopeless. But it is not appropriate; it does need adjustment. On the basis of the evidence presented to the inquiry so far, the Committee considered that in cases of extreme drought arrangements for assistance between the Commonwealth, State and Territory governments must be consistent, transparent and clearly enunciated.

PARA.TAB: The Committee's report comments on several other matters including rural counsellors, farm financial management, administration and implementation of the rural adjustment scheme, and access to Social Security benefits. I must say in regard to the Social Security benefits touted sincerely, I am sure, by the Minister as being of benefit to people in the community, that that hope has not been realised. It has been very difficult for some people to get assistance through the Social Security scheme and structure. We should reconsider in some instances making this assistance available to enable people to continue to live until the rains come. In many instances, that assistance was given as the Committee visited the drought areas. We were thanked for that by the locals.

I will not address all of the other matters specifically as I am sure other members of the Committee will comment on the issues when they speak to the report. Finally, the Committee's report notes that some of the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force have been implemented but responses to most of the recommendations are yet to be made. Accordingly, the Committee considers that it is imperative that the package of recommendations contained in the report of the Drought Policy Review Task Force be reviewed immediately.

The Committee recognises that it is important for Australia, as one of the driest continents on the globe, to develop a comprehensive, integrated and effective approach to drought. The Committee therefore recommends that the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, in consultation with other members of the Australian Agricultural Council, give urgent attention to the development and implementation of a clearly defined and comprehensive approach for the management of drought.

I must say that this is our first report. As I indicated and emphasised earlier, we wanted to make the report available to the Australian Agricultural Council. We wished to add the force of our argument and thoughts to those that had been expressed in the report of the previous task force and to the attitude of people in the community. We will be bringing down a final report. It is the intention of the Committee, by working in a cooperative way, to do that within two months.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to support the remarks of the Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs, Senator Burns. Everyone knows the history of this Committee, which has only just been set up. It is the first standing committee on rural and regional affairs in the Federal Parliament since 1942 or 1944. I believe it is an indictment of this Parliament that since that time we have not had an all party standing committee to look after rural and regional interests. We can now look in a bipartisan way at different subjects that are put to us by way of terms of reference.

PARA.TAB: Some 67 submissions were received on drought. We looked at a national drought policy and the appropriate Government responses to the recommendations of the Drought Policy Review Task Force. I believe that it is a great achievement that the interim report has been brought down in such a short time. It has been tabled well within the time frame.

I believe that the Chairman chaired the Committee well. I believe that the members of the Committee have worked well together. I think special thanks should go to Neil Bessell and the members of his staff on the Rural and Regional Affairs Committee for the job that they have done.

Some 166 witnesses appeared before the Committee in under four weeks. So we had a great number of people to listen to. In some places people told us of the devastation caused by the drought in their area. Of course, this drought followed a period of high interest rates which had prevailed in the community for so long. It also followed a downturn in commodity prices. There has also been a very deep recession in place in rural communities. Obviously, those factors caused a lot more problems in terms of this drought than had been the case with previous droughts.

For this Committee to go out to the people, whether they be in New South Wales, Queensland, Tasmania, Western Australia or South Australia, and talk to them where it is really happening was, I think, most important. First of all, we were impressed with the strength of the people out in the communities. I think you actually have to go out into the rural communities to see the depth of the problems that are associated with the rural communities at the moment.

In Queensland one in every seven grain properties is for sale and farm debt has increased by 24 per cent since 1989-91. We were told that as a result of the drought lost production in Queensland was just under $1 billion and that in the coming year there would be another loss to Queensland of some $1 billion.

I think the area that really struck the Committee most was the western division of New South Wales. That is where people broke down at the table while giving evidence. It was the most moving experience that I have had since I have been in the Federal Parliament. People gave evidence of losing 10,000 out of 15,000 sheep. Other people had lost 2,000 out of 4,000 of their breeding ewes. The problem is how those people will get going again.

We heard evidence that everyone wants to be self-reliant. I can understand that. The farmer never wants a handout. He does not want to be pandered to. He just wants a fair go. It was brought home to me at the Committee hearings that the farming communities were just not getting a fair go at the moment. They used to have an income equalisation deposit scheme that was very popular prior to 1983. Now that that scheme has been changed, it is not anywhere near as popular. People do not want to put money into it because of the very nature of the scheme. It does not give the incentive to people to prepare for drought. We believe that everyone wants to be self-reliant and that people in the farming community should be self-reliant to prepare themselves for drought.

The problem that concerns the Committee, and me in particular, is how people are going to put money into income equalisation deposits when they do not have big cash flows at the moment. All the big cash flows from the mid-1980s have now been lost so there has to be some method of allowing people to become self-reliant. Self-reliance, and the fact that income equalisation deposits should definitely be revamped, is one area to which the Committee addressed itself.

Different people suggested different ways in which the income equalisation deposits could be revamped. The most persuasive way was that the farmer should get a deduction from his income in the year of placing his money into the income equalisation deposits. Also, the farmer should get a reasonable rate of income from interest rates when he has the money in the income equalisation deposits. When he withdraws the money in the year of drought, he should be able to pay tax at the rate that is applicable in that particular year. The rural counsellor, Mrs Katherine Simms from the Macquarie Rural Advisory Service, made the point in our report and it is clearly enunciated here. I quote from the report where she said:

SPEECH.PARA: In general—and this includes right down to the hardest battler and one who is leaving his property—I have not found a farmer who would say that the philosophy of self-reliance is wrong. I think farmers are basically looking to be self-reliant. They are not looking for any handouts. However, in reality, in Australia's climate, drought hits hard and without some form of assistance of whatever kind, farmers feel they are not going to be able to make it through.

There was another area that the Committee felt needed attention. We were of the view that effective depreciation or other tax measures were needed to provide incentive for farmers and graziers to become self-reliant. I know that Senator Crane will talk on this. Throughout the inquiry he has been talking and asking questions about tax credits and whether that would be a way to solve the problem. It is good to see the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Senator McMullan, in the chamber tonight because he may be able to take on board some of those ideas about tax credits.

PARA.TAB: The other area considered was the fact that the Commonwealth always has to play a part. Although the Government has taken drought out of the natural disaster relief arrangements, it still has to recognise that when a drought gets beyond the capabilities of the individual and the State to handle it in an economic way, it then becomes necessary for the Commonwealth to do something. That requires more than rural assistance.

One of the areas that has concerned me since we brought in this report—and we brought it in quickly for the Agricultural Council meeting—is that the Council has said that it wants to take away the transaction-based support. They also want to phase out subsidies for stock to be taken away from properties and stock to be brought back to properties after drought. In New South Wales, for example, the State Government has spent more than $9.2m on helping farmers.

There have been some 16,666 applications from rural communities for assistance in the transport of water and feed to stock or to move stock in and out of drought-affected areas. That area is very important because environmentally it is good. The stock gets away from the property in the drought. It is good for the animals and it is good from the animal welfare aspect. It is good for retaining the breeding herd and the breeding flock and that is absolutely essential. So it concerns me that the Agricultural Council and the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Crean, do not think a little bit more about those transaction-based subsidies.

At the moment we have not got a national drought policy. That is what concerns the Committee and that is what we went to look at—the Drought Policy Review Task Force's recommendations. I know that another matter is to be debated here tonight, and I know this matter will be dealt with again on Thursday in general business, so I seek leave to continue my remarks.

TALKER.NAME: Senator McMullan
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief explanatory procedure. It might help Senator Brownhill and some of the other senators who want to speak in this debate.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I make it clear to all senators that we are hoping to get to the tabling of papers by the Clerk before 10.30 p.m. because there are some important matters in there which the Standing Orders require us to deal with today. The only matter that I believe is likely to be spoken to there is that listed on the Notice Paper. I have discussed it with the initiating senator, Senator Vanstone, and she indicates that provided there is a minute or two before 10.30 p.m. for her to speak, that should be sufficient. So perhaps the people who wish to speak in this debate will take note that we can keep this matter going until about 10.28 p.m. I know that there are several people who wish to speak, but provided that one or two minutes are left, we will be right. I make that clarifying explanation and hand back to Senator Brownhill.
—I was hoping that I and everyone else could have spoken for the full time on Thursday. If Senator West will yield to that, then I will finish.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Bjelke-Petersen)—Senator Brownhill, you will be able to be called again on Thursday if you wish.

TALK.START.PARA: —If I can be called again on Thursday, I will just make the point that it is of concern to everyone that if one is not in the national drought disaster relief arrangements there has to be some other mechanism whereby the Commonwealth Government decides that it has to come in and help. Whether that will be because of the length of drought, the amount of money spent on the drought in that particular State, environmental aspects of the drought causing problems in that area, or whether it will be because of the national interest, there has to be some trigger. I will yield to Senator West and talk about this on Thursday. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been said before, this is the first report of the revamped and reconstituted Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. If anyone wants to know what senators do in January and February when the Parliament is not sitting, I suggest they read the preface of this report because they will certainly find out. We are reported as having had 11 public hearings. Since then we have had about three or four more in Western Australia and South Australia. The Committee has certainly spent a lot of time doing a lot of work quickly. It is a very commendable report. I want to associate myself with the thanks to the Committee secretariat and to Hansard who travelled with us through western New South Wales and south-western Western Australia.

PARA.TAB: We were able to visit and see many places around Australia. Some areas that had been suffering drought had since had rains and, by the time we visited, had recovered.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you do a rain dance?
—Not quite, but after we left a few places it did rain. I do not think we should be called upon to repeat the performance of breaking droughts again.
—No, it caused floods.

—I think people would prefer too much rather than not enough, from what we were able to see. The other thing that we were able to see in visiting such a broad range of places was the contrasting agricultural systems that exist in this country. This means that drought in different places has different effects and different factors also affecting it. These inspections provided us with first hand knowledge of this.

PARA.TAB: I have never before seen soil actually moving. In areas that Senator Crane is familiar with we were shown the effects of this and why it is so essential to move stock out of such areas very quickly. Soil will move because it is so fragile. Yet in other areas stock can be left on the whole time. Sure, there is dust, but the soil does not have the same reaction to the cloven hoofed animals. It is very important for us as senators to recognise and outline in our reports that there is a very wide difference within the country in the effects upon drought.

There are also other factors that affect drought. It is not just lack of rain that has an impact. It is things like the build up of native animals. We have provided watering holes or water supplies for native animals around this country and we now have a much larger number of kangaroos than when the white colony first arrived in 1788. We also had evidence that people would sow a crop of barley, oats or wheat and it would be the only couple of hundred acres of green fodder within miles. They were not able to get a crop off it, but had to put their stock on it very quickly because they were competing with the animals, and if they had not put their stock on they would have lost the value of the crop, even though it was only fodder and not grains as they would have hoped.

We were also able to look at the problems of feral animals. One women in Cobar gave evidence that in the three months from January 1991 to April 1991 she employed someone to eradicate rabbits. She had 19,000 pairs of rabbits destroyed on her property in three months. The impact of this, coupled with a shortage of water and feed, has a devastating effect not just on the land but also on the animals that the farmers are trying to graze to make sure that they get to a decent marketable standard. We also learnt of the problems that woody weeds add to drought and the problems of distance, which is well known to many people here.

We had evidence of the important role of women in farming pursuits. As we know, one-third of farmers are women. We also had evidence from some witnesses that some organisations and some banks—not all—do not fully appreciate the role that these women play. That is a problem for those organisations. It is also a problem for those farming families and farmers who have to deal with these organisations. That is something that no number of reports on drought will overcome. It is something that we as senators must be aware of when we are talking to these organisations; we must remind them to be conscious that one-third of farmers are women.

We spoke with a number of excellent rural counsellors. The service and support that they are providing to these primary producers in hard times when they not only have a commodity price drop but also a drought superimposed on that, is valuable. We recognised that they also require access to a wide range of appropriate support services. This is not just support services in terms of their financial counselling but it is also the support services in terms of general counselling and general support.

We must never lose sight of the fact that anybody who is working in the area of counselling and providing those types of support must themselves have some sorts of support mechanisms otherwise we will end up with counsellor burn-out. This is an area that can be pursued further with the authorities. We spoke to a number of these counsellors and they were able to get this support counselling that professional counsellors and the like use, but they had to organise it themselves; there was nothing within the structures of the whole thing to ensure that they were provided with these support mechanisms. That is something that I feel very concerned about and I think we must continue to pay attention to.

We also heard the counsellors say that it was often difficult to refer people who came to them to other counsellors for other types of problems that they may have had. It is very easy to be presented with a physical problem such as a financial problem because that can be looked at as something that is tangible and there to be changed and moved. We also have to make sure that people recognise the need to support these counsellors to broaden their role of counselling knowledge and experience. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take a few minutes of the time of the Senate to refer to what is colloquially known as the Hepples case. I wish to bring to the attention of this chamber an area of the present taxation legislation that needs urgent revision. I refer to those sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act colloquially known as the terrible twins, or sections 160M(6) and 160M(7). These two sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act have been brought to the attention of every tax writer and commentator in the land by the recent High Court decision in the Hepples case. Before I fully explain that case, I will give some examples of the adverse comments that have arisen:

SPEECH.PARA: A capital gains tax fiasco.
The decision of the Full High Court in the Hepples Case must. . . be a nightmare come true for the Australian Taxation Office.
Hepples case. . . represents the Finnegan's Wake of the Australian Capital Gains Law.
The High Court decision (in the Hepples case) was a disgrace.
The law is obscure to the point of being impenetrable.

Last October during the Senate Estimates hearings, I raised this case with the Government and the officers of the Australian Taxation Office. I emphasised the need for an urgent clarification of this part of the capital gains legislation. Senator McMullan, who is in the chamber tonight, in answer to questioning at that time agreed and an assurance was given that the Government would examine the issue and that, hopefully, before the end of the last sitting something would be done. Nothing was forthcoming last session, and I now take this opportunity to remind the Government of its assurances.

PARA.TAB: The beginning of a new session is now upon us. The uncertainty, the confusion and now the possible window of opportunity that has been opened for executives to receive tax-free payments needs to be clarified once and for all by legislation. The High Court has only recently ruled on this case. It decided to allow commonsense to prevail and to uphold the previous judgment. The amount received by Hepples is to be tax free. However, in the previous judgment by the High Court on this case, strong words were used that indicated that it was up to the Parliament to act to clarify these confusing sections of the Act. I now call upon the Government to confirm its previous assurances and to act in a responsible manner to clear the confusion.

The facts of the case are relatively simple. In 1986 William Hepples was the general manager of the Hunter Douglas window furnishings division. He was paid $40,000 by his employer for giving a covenant not to compete after his employment ended and not to divulge trade secrets—a not uncommon agreement. The Commissioner of Taxation, wishing to exact his pound of flesh, included this amount in the assessable income of Mr Hepples, relying on the two difficult capital gains provisions I have already mentioned. Five years later, and probably well over $100,000 or more in legal fees, the courts have decided in favour of Mr Hepples. However, since 1986, when the capital gains tax legislation was enacted, there has been a chorus of commentators debating the meaning of these terrible twins, sections 160M(6) and 160M(7).

The High Court justices in this instance are no different. The decisions reached have added only further layers of complexity to the tax law. Let me give an analysis of their decisions. In the Hepples case, four judges found section 160M(6) inapplicable. A differently constituted four judges said that section 160M(7) did not apply. A further majority of four judges, differently constituted this time, found that either provision applied. Where they did agree, different judges often had different reasons for reaching the same conclusion.

The justices have failed by their judicial technique to deliver some certainty and clarity to the law on the question of public importance. This illustrates that this section of the tax laws is in an appalling state. Even the highest courts of the land are divided on the meaning of vital sections, and even when they do agree on the application they do so for different reasons. Consequently, because the judges could not agree, we have a situation where, as one commentator put it, four out of seven judges found for the Commissioner. Including the Federal Court, this means that six out of 10 judges found for the Commissioner, yet at the end of the day the taxpayer won the case.

The most recent ruling of the High Court in the past fortnight reaffirms this situation. One of the judges, Sir William Deane, has aptly displayed what is wrong with the terrible twins sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act. He stated in his comments on this case:

SPEECH.PARA: Statutes imposing taxation derogate from the ordinary rights of the citizen in that they represent a compulsory exaction of money. . . The framing of such legislation is essentially within the control of government. Indeed, in so far as the provisions of the Act are concerned, it would seem that, particularly in relation to technical matters, the content and drafting of such provisions may, on occasions, reflect the advice and views of officers of the ATO. . . In circumstances where the heavy burden of legal costs is likely to constitute an insurmountable obstacle to the challenge by the average taxpayer of an assessment in the courts and where successive administrations have allowed the Act to become a legislative jungle. . . the least that such a taxpayer is entitled to demand of government, is that, once the relevant provisions are finally identified, a legislative intent to impose a tax upon him or her in respect of a commonplace transaction will be expressed in clear words.

In simple, plain words, the taxpayer should be able to understand clearly whether or not he needs to pay tax. It is the Government's responsibility in framing the legislation to see that the taxpayer understands. The capital gains terrible twins need to be simplified as well as clarified. This is not the first time the courts have been critical of the capital gains section of the Income Tax Assessment Act.

PARA.TAB: An important point that must not be forgotten is that, under a system of self-assessment, the Government expects members of the community to understand what the law requires them to pay in tax. To help in this understanding, there are heavy penalties for understatement of tax. Margaret Gibson in her syndicated column states that one of the reasons for the degeneration of our taxation laws to a `legislative jungle' is that Parliament, especially during recent years, has seemed to be merely a rubber stamp for the Taxation Office. She states that if our seven justices of the High Court cannot satisfactorily interpret a tax provision, it is not likely that our politicians in Canberra have understood the full effect of what has been passed. I honestly believe that in this case that is what has happened. It has been beyond everybody's comprehension.

If we go back to the explanatory memorandum, it is not surprising that we were all fooled. The explanatory memorandum which accompanied the Income Tax Assessment Amendment (Capital Gains) Bill and the Income Tax (Rates) Amendment Bill in 1986 stated when referring to subsection 160M(6):

SPEECH.PARA: Sub-section 160M(6) applies to a disposal of an asset that did not exist (either by itself or as part of another asset) before the disposal, but is created by the disposal. The sub-section makes clear—
note that it says `clear'—
that such circumstances constitute a disposal of the asset for the purposes of this Part.

When the words of the explanatory memorandum are expressed in such terms that make it clear—when, heaven forbid, the seven justices found it difficult to make it clear—it is not surprising that people of our ilk were misled. It was this Government which passed the sections—indeed it was this Parliament—thinking, as the explanatory memorandum had stated, that it clearly refers to what is an asset and the circumstances of what is constituted a capital gain. It is now this Government's responsibility to clarify these sections.

PARA.TAB: This Government cannot continue to allow ordinary Australian taxpayers to enter into ordinary business transactions uncertain of their tax fate. Tax lawyers and advisers can provide some assurances, but there is no clear answer. A further manifestation of the complexity of the tax laws is the position that so many of Australia's largest companies have found themselves in, according to the Pappas Carter report, in coming to a conclusion somewhat different to tax auditors. I refer again to the Hepples case. In fact, as one eminent tax lawyer has stated to me:

SPEECH.PARA: Speaking as a person who has had to spend hours dissecting the decision to determine what it decides, if anything, I find it an intolerable waste of taxpayers' money. This is now exaggerated by the fact that I and other members of the tax advising community will now have to pass the cost of analysing the decisions on to our clients.
This is an intolerable situation. The tax expert continues—I reiterate the sentiment of his remarks:

Apart from the paucity in the drafting of the legislation, what this case illustrates is the need for specific legal divisions within the judicial hierarchy. At the very least there should be a tax division within the Federal and High Courts so that we can get some consistency into tax decisions.

I support that. Consistency is important. In order to achieve this we have to have a separate tax division within the Federal Court and the High Court. In conclusion, let me say that as far as the terrible twins are concerned it is now Parliament's turn and it must act decisively in the wider public interest. I look forward to Senator Evans's response.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the electorate of Hotham, in which my office is located, is at the coalface of what is the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. Unemployment in Hotham has almost tripled in the last 18 months. In Oakleigh, the number of unemployed has quadrupled since the last Federal election. There are now over 40,000 people in the south-eastern suburbs who have been forced onto the dole.

PARA.TAB: The Nissan plant at Clayton, situated in the heart of Hotham, will close in October. Some 1,800 Nissan workers will lose their jobs. It has been estimated that up to 6,000 more jobs may go as a result of the effect of Nissan's closure on local suppliers and retailers. A large number of other locally based companies, including Humes, Bosch, R.P.Scherer and Telecom Industries, for a variety of reasons—some because of reform and some because of the failure of the Government to realise how its regulations have a stranglehold on some industries and are affecting them—are also being forced to retrench significant numbers of workers.

Naturally, the local member, Mr Crean, is running scared. In a desperate attempt to divert attention from the fact that it is his Government that deliberately caused this recession, Mr Crean has been announcing special packages and task forces to assist workers affected by the Nissan closure. But there has been precious little from Mr Crean for the thousands of other Hotham people who have lost their jobs or businesses as a direct result of this Government's failed policies.

The specific local example I want to refer to this evening is typical of this Government's attitude. It shows how politically motivated Mr Crean's recent actions have been and how a member of parliament can quite willingly sit on his hands when the media spotlight is cast somewhere else. Acromet is an Australian firm situated in Clayton in the heart of Mr Crean's electorate of Hotham. It was established in 1962 and manufactures and supplies pumps to local and overseas buyers.

Two weeks ago Acromet wrote to its local member, Mr Crean, expressing concern about various issues relating to the conduct of an Australian Construction Services tender for metering pumps for the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories. Acromet is concerned about the validity of the tenderer's rationale for favouring a German competitor which has been rewarded a large slice of this contract. Acromet contends that it satisfied all of the requirements set down in the tender and by the inspecting engineers of ACS and CSL.

Acromet claims that the reasons given for favouring the German company over it are fallacious and cast grave doubts on the capabilities and qualifications of the decision makers. Acromet believes that it is also able to offer far superior post-installation service, support facilities and expressed doubt as to whether its German competitor's product was subject to the same rigorous testing as its own metering pumps. Disturbingly, Acromet also claims that its competitor was able to resubmit its prices subsequent to the closure of the tender while the Australian firm's request for a similar opportunity was rejected by ACS.

I stress that I am not in a position to make an informed decision about the comparative worth of each of the tender applicants or about the claims that Acromet makes. However, the concerns expressed by Acromet are indeed serious. The concerns expressed are doubly serious, I believe, when an Australian manufacturer is expressing them in relation to an overseas competitor for a Commonwealth Government contract. I think we would all agree that it is inappropriate for the Federal Government to favour local producers regardless of quality and price. I consider that, all things being equal, we have an obligation to support Australian companies. The Government's procurement guidelines also reflect this point of view.

Acromet is claiming that all things are not equal in this particular case. It is adamant that it can provide both a superior product and superior post-installation service. It claims that it is the victim of the technical cringe mentality whereby preference is given to foreign brands due to a longstanding distrust of the quality of Australian products.

What has been the reaction of the local member, Mr Crean? Nothing—not a reply, not an acknowledgment. I know that it has been only two weeks, but in the electorate of Hotham the loss of one—albeit not very large—contract means that one or two jobs are not available. I have had people in my office in tears because they do not have a job. Every little bit counts. Each of those small businesses is creating the one or two jobs that will add up to create employment in that area. There has been nothing from the honourable member. It is all very well to get publicity, to go out and make promises to the Nissan employees.

TALK.START.PARA: —And very quickly.

—And very quickly, as Senator Watson so rightly says. But when it is a small thing, a small company and a small contract that is in question there is no response from Mr Crean. Frustrated at Mr Crean's lack of action and after receiving no acknowledgment from him of Acromet's letter—I acknowledge that as a Minister he is busy and that this is a small factory in his electorate—it wrote to me informing me of its concerns.

PARA.TAB: As a result of the company's approach, I visited its factory, inspected its pumps, talked to the engineers and these people who are so proud of their pumps and was given a list of a thousand firms. If I were to repeat the names of those firms here in this chamber, the names would be recognised—large firms, medical firms and firms which need pumps to pump products in such a way that germs, disease and bacteria cannot get in. This company is supplying pumps to leading companies in Australia.

As a result of my visit and my discussions with Acromet, I have written only today to the Minister for Administrative Services, Senator Bolkus, asking him to postpone the letting of this contract in the light of its strongly expressed concerns. In my representations I have also asked Senator Bolkus for any available relevant information pertaining to the letting of this tender, including the rationale for the final decision, details of product testing and specialist advice sought and the relevant qualifications of the decision makers.

I urge the Minister to give this matter his urgent attention. Australian manufacturers are finding it hard enough to survive with the excessive taxes and regulations imposed by Labor. To then ask them to overcome the technical cringe mentality of government decision makers is simply too much in the current recession. As I said before, each one or two jobs created by these businesses will help to get Australia back on track. I call on the Minister to address the issue I have raised this evening.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will only take a few minutes of the Senate's time. Today, outside this Parliament House, there was a demonstration by a number of people who had travelled some distance to be at Parliament House, hear some speeches and present what they call `a log of claims' to the Prime Minister (Mr Keating). Unfortunately, the Prime Minister left this afternoon. I understand he was farewelling the Queen.

PARA.TAB: I think everybody in this chamber has from time to time had presented to them what the presenters have called `a petition', and very often these things are not in a form which is suitable for presentation to the chamber. One of the people from this group outside came in to see me this afternoon and said, `We wanted to present this to the Prime Minister but were incapable of doing so. Can you present it to the Senate?'. It is not in a form which can be presented to the Senate; the signatures were not even attached to the letter. But it does seem to me that in a democracy it is not sufficient for those of us who know the correct form of these things to deny the citizenry the opportunity to present words to the Parliament which are their words and which are in the form of a claim on the Parliament to consider certain things.

Therefore, I seek the permission of the Senate to simply table these three pages. The first page is an overview saying that they are presenting a log of claims to the Parliament and the other two pages are a list of 34 points which they seek to present to the Parliament. As I say, I make no claim for or against any of these particular points but simply seek to table them so that members of this Senate have an opportunity to have a look at them. They are the words which are presented by those people who have been demonstrating outside today. I seek the leave of the Senate to table these three pages.
Leave granted.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 13 August 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) When is it planned that the Interdepartmental Committee will be established which will produce a plan for the development, survival and protection of children in Australia in accordance with our ratification of the Declaration on the Rights of the Child.
(2) Who will be represented on this Committee.
(3) Will it produce a plan for Australian children by the end of 1991, as promised at the World Summit for Children.
(4) Will non-Government organisations already working in the areas be consulted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) to (4) The World Declaration on the Survival, Protection and Development of Children was issued at the conclusion of the World Summit for Children in New York on 30 September 1990. The Declaration was signed on 13 May 1991 by the Prime Minister. One of the commitments enunciated in the Declaration is that countries will work to promote earliest possible ratification and implementation of the Convention on the Rights of the Child.
With regard to other action being undertaken pursuant to the World Declaration, I refer to the answer in the House of Representatives Hansard, 19 December 1991, page 3907.

The Convention on the Rights of the Child, a quite separate document which Australia ratified on 17 December 1990, does not require Australia to produce a specific plan for the development, survival and protection of children in Australia. At this stage, the Government has no plans to establish an Interdepartmental Committee in relation to the Convention. The Attorney-General is currently considering options for the administrative implementation of the Convention in Australia.

Under Article 44 of the Convention, Australia is required to report to the Committee on the Rights of the Child by 16 January 1993 concerning Australia's compliance with the Convention. In preparing the report, the Government will be consulting with relevant non-Government organisations as well as with State and Territory Governments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, upon notice, on 8 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) How much flake or shark meat is produced by Australia.
(2) How much flake is imported into this country.
(3) Which countries supply the Australian market with flake.
(4) What guidelines are in place to ensure the shark meat does not contain high levels of mercury or ammonia.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Information is not available to provide an accurate figure for shark meat produced in Australia, as product is landed and marketed in a variety of ways. Available information is compiled by State authorities, however not all States keep production records. Further the units by which each State records the amount produced differs between States. The figures available on a State basis are:
shark production by carcass weight for calendar year 1990 was 1374 tonnes
shark production by carcass weight for calendar year 1990 was 845 tonnes
shark catch for the calendar year 1990 was 1329 tonnes carcass weight
estimated total shark production for the 1990 calendar year was 800 tonnes.
reported shark catch for the 1989/90 financial year was1234 tonnes landed carcass weight.
estimated local consumption for the 1991 calendar year of shark fillet is 120 tonnes. In addition QLD exported 2.5 tonnes in 1991.
estimated shark catch for the calendar year 1990 was 426 tonnes live weight

(2 & 3) Information is not available to accurately determine how much flake is imported into Australia, and from which countries. The Bureau of Statistics has advised that 'Imports of flake are not separately identified, as flake may be recorded under several commodity classifications (which also include other types of fish).

(4) The National Food Authority develops the 'Food Standards Code' which currently sets the acceptable level of Mercury in shark meat at 0.5 parts per million. However, it is at the discretion of each State as to whether they legislate this code, and how the standards are enforced.

It has been generally accepted that the larger the shark the higher the level of mercury content. Therefore, most steps taken to ensure that the mercury content is not exceeded rely on limiting the size or species of shark landed for consumption. Western Australia limits the size of shark to be sold for human consumption while Victoria has banned certain shark species where the mercury is likely to concentrate and exceed safe levels.

The NSW Health Department withholds large shark and other suspect fish from sale until a sample is taken and the mercury level determined. NSW ensures compliance through the co-operation with its fish marketing authority and the Health Department's Food inspection branch.
Tasmania and Victoria have conducted several surveys to ensure compliance, including the national Australian Market Basket Survey.
The Queensland Department of Health monitors public markets on a part time basis.

With regard to the monitoring of ammonia levels, guidelines in place to ensure that shark flesh does not contain high levels of ammonia rely essentially upon conforming to the provisions of State food hygiene regulations. As ammonia in shark flesh originates as the product deteriorates (natural spoilage), correct handling of the product from the time of harvesting to the time of final consumption should ensure ammonia does not become a problem.
NSW's Food Act 1989, contains a number of general provisions relating to adulterated foods, unfit for human consumption. The presence of ammonia could be used to support a charge of adulteration.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is it correct that only 7 per cent of the employees of the Department of Defence are union members and that they represent 31 unions.
(2) By what method will 'the agreed union' be selected to nominate candidates and to run an election for health and safety representatives in the designated work groups.
(3) What is the justification for barring members of the Australian Defence Force from voting in such elections in their workplace.
(4) Is the move towards integration of the community with the Defence Force to be all to the benefit of the community with no resulting benefits to the Defence Force.

(5) Does the draft Defence Central memorandum of 12 August 1991 state that: 'The Act has been interpreted in such a way that the ACTU and all civilian employees will be represented by a union whether or not individual employees are members of a union', and is this a correct interpretation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I refer the honourable senator to the answer to Question No. 1361 published in Hansard on 26 November 1991. The Department of Defence's assessment is that the figure is closer to 40 per cent.

(2) I presume that the honourable senator is referring to section 25(4) of the Occupational Health and Safety (Commonwealth Employment) Act. The answer to the question is in sub-section (b) of that section which, in relation to the conduct of an election for a health and safety representative for a designated work group, provides that, if there is more that one involved union in relation to the group, the unions agree on which union is to conduct the election.

(3) Health and safety provisions for the Defence Force relate essentially to the performance by the ADF of its current and foreseeable military function. Hence the decision was made that ADF health and safety must continue to be within the chain of command and that ADF members will be excluded from sections 24 to 38 of the Act, insofar as the term 'employee' is applicable. As such, ADF members will not be members of Designated Work Groups and, as a consequence, they are ineligible to vote for, or be nominated as, Health and Safety representatives under the provisions of the Act. All other provisions of these sections will apply to members of the ADF, particularly those relating to the responsibilities of the Commonwealth as an employer, which will be exercised through the ADF chain of command.

(5) The draft Defence Circular Memorandum of 12 August was a working paper in an early stage of development. The sentence quoted by the honourable senator was contained in that particular draft. It was at the time thought to reflect an interpretation of the equivalent provision in the Victorian OH&S Act. Among the amendments made to subsequent drafts was the deletion of that sentence on the grounds of doubt about its accuracy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Science and Technology, upon notice, on 23 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: During the years 1985 to 1990, did the chemical industry or individual chemical companies pay officers of the CSIRO to attend: (a) conferences; (b) meetings; (c) study tours; or (d) other excursions, including travel costs, accommodation, meals; if so: (i) how can the CSIRO remain independent of chemical industry influence, (ii) which companies provided the sponsorship, (iii) what are the names of the officers who received the sponsorship, and (iv) for each officer, what was the event(s) the attendance at which was sponsored and the value of each sponsorship.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Science and Technology has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question: The answer to questions (a) (b) (c) and (d) is that, in the years 1985 to 1990, a number of CSIRO scientists attended conferences and meetings using funds provided directly or indirectly by the chemical industry or by individual companies. CSIRO's accounting systems are not designed to report comprehensively on the issues of travel and associated expenditure sponsored by companies. Accordingly, the question was referred to Institutes and Divisions for responses and the following information is based on these responses which are as encompassing as their accounting systems allow. Virtually all CSIRO proposals for research to be funded by industry include a travel component for purposes such as consultation with scientific colleagues, negotiation with existing or potential commercial partners, or communication of the results to end-users. Travel expenses are also an integral part of charges made for any consultancy work CSIRO undertakes for industry. Most of the funds in question were provided as part of normal CSIRO industry collaboration, where industry funds contribute to relevant attendance at conferences and meetings. In some cases the funds are provided by industry and consumer associations, not by individual companies and are directed at conferences which discuss reductions in chemical use.

PARA.TAB: Chiefs of CSIRO Divisions have responsibility for determining whether to accept external funds under the amount of $100,000; the question of any potential conflict of interest is one of a number of factors, including relevance of the project to CSIRO's charter, taken into account before any decision is made to accept such funds.

CSIRO's relationships with industry, including those with "the chemical industry" provide Australian research and Australian industry with a means of working closely together for the benefit of both parties and ultimately for the benefit of all Australians. CSIRO would strongly oppose any attempt from industry to compromise its independence, and most certainly does not consider that its relationships with industry render it susceptible to any undue influence.

In the case of the Division of Chemicals and Polymers, no officers of the Division have received direct payment from the chemical industry or individual chemical companies to attend conferences, meetings, study tours or other excursions. This Division carries out most of the research done by CSIRO to support the Australian chemical industry.

The Division's strategy is to apply its research results and to utilise its expertise in chemistry to develop new products and processes for Australian manufacturing. An important feature of this strategy is to undertake research projects in collaboration with the chemical industry at as early a stage as possible.

A number of collaborative research agreements have been established with individual chemical companies operating in Australia. These companies provide external funding to augment Appropriation funds to the extent of meeting a target of 30 per cent of total funding of the Division, which is a guideline set by the CSIRO Board.

An action plan is drawn up for each research project and lists the financial contributions by CSIRO and the company, and how these funds will be spent by the Division on salaries, equipment and operating costs. Progress is periodically reviewed by a joint management committee comprising representatives from CSIRO and the company.
The independence of CSIRO is assured through these arrangements, which are providing the industry with a basis for the development of new products and processes.
The end result is the potential to stimulate growth in this sector and to improve the adverse balance of trade in chemicals.

The answers to the remaining questions are: (i) CSIRO is confident that it has not been influenced in favour of individual companies, nor the industry by making use of these arrangements. Details in response to questions (ii) (iii) and (iv) are as follows:

(2a) Attached are copies of the instructions for use of these products held by the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods (attachment 1—additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office).
(2b i,ii,iii) The matter of the adequacy of product information for these products had been raised at a meeting of the National Co-ordinating Committee for Therapeutic Goods in October 1991.

This committee contains representatives of the Commonwealth, State and Territory Health Departments and the product information is relevant to the committee because of the public health information on the treatment of head lice issued by the States and Territories. The Committee identified deficiencies in some of the product information and the Therapeutic Goods Administration (TGA) undertook a review of the product information to ensure its consistency with current attitudes for the treatment of head lice infestations.

The package inserts are currently under review by the TGA and a detailed answer for each product is not available. However, attached is a publication issued by the Queensland Department of Health (attachment 2—additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office) which was published following a careful review of the current knowledge on pediculosis and its treatment. The product information is being assessed for consistency against this document.
The important points are:
(a)there is no place for the prophylactic use of these preparations unless the label text is worded in terms of protection against reinfestation during a confirmed outbreak,
(b)it is important to follow the recommended contact times and products should generally not be used more than once weekly.

The frequency of treatment depends on the agent used. In the case of maldison (malathion), only one application is necessary because it destroys the eggs and the lice. Success depends upon the patient using the product exactly in accordance with instructions, typically being a 12 hour contact time. In some package inserts, reference is made to using a second application of malathion about one week after the first, which is to eradicate a new infestation, rather than clean up parasites that were not destroyed in the first application.

Pyrethrins, however, being non-ovacidal, must be applied in two applications seven days apart to destroy the emerging nymphs. The time interval is important as it coincides with the sensitive points of the parasite's life cycle.
(c) if used as above, the potential toxicity of the active ingredients is acceptable.
Certainly there are deficiencies currently in some of the product information importantly:
(a)advising the frequency of use and clear instructions for the quantity to be used, and
(b)claims about the means of reinfestation.
(3) These are matters which are being covered in the review. As explained in the answer to (2), following the frequency of use is important to the efficacy of the products.
Sponsors will be asked to update product information to be consistent with the information in the Queensland publication.
(4) As indicated in (3), prophylactic use of these preparations is not appropriate, except to prevent a reinfestation.

(5) Many of the products listed in (1) are locally manufactured and have been in the market for a substantial period. Until the start of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989 on 15 February 1991, locally made therapeutic goods were not subject to premarket evaluation, except via the registration scheme which operated in Victoria.

With the start of the Therapeutic Goods Act 1989, a national scheme commenced which covers both locally made and imported products. Products being legally supplied at the commencement of the legislation had the right to apply for entry into the Australian Register of Therapeutic Goods without assessment (grandfathering) at that stage. However, Section 31 of the Act permits the Secretary to require sponsors to provide further information about the goods upon request. This Section is being used to review the product information of head lice treatments.
(6) This information is attached (attachment 3 - additional copies are available from the Senate Table Office).

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 29 October 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Did the Minister state to the Senate on Thursday, 10 October 1991, (Senate Hansard, p.l778) in answer to a question without notice from Senator Schacht, that an article by Mr Brian Toohey in the Sydney Sun-Herald of 6 October 1991 and the Adelaide News of 7 October 1991, was wrong, when the writer asserted `that the Oberon standard displacement is 1600 tonnes compared with the 2500 tonnes for the Collins class'.
(2) Did the then Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) in a press release of 18 May 1987 (67/87) state in a footnote that the displacement of the Oberons was 1610 tonnes.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I did advise the Senate on 10 October that Mr Toohey was wrong when he asserted `that the Oberon standard displacement is 1600 tonnes compared with the 2500 tonnes for the Collins class'. I made this statement in view of the fact that 1600 tonnes equates quite closely with the publicly stated standard displacement of the Oberon, as listed in Janes Fighting Ships 1991/92, whereas 2500 tonnes equates quite closely with the estimate of the surface displacement of the Collins submarine as listed in the same publication.

(2) Mr Beazley did issue a media release on 18 May 1987 which quoted a displacement for the Oberon submarine of about 1600 tonnes. The reference quoted, Janes Fighting Ships 1986/87, states that 1610 tonnes is the standard displacement of the vessel. In my response to the Senate, I quoted a displacement of about 2030 tonnes for the Oberon, based on Janes data for the surface displacement. In fact modifications to the Oberons have resulted in small adjustments in both displacements. Displacements also vary slightly from vessel to vessel.
To clarify any confusion over standard, surface and dived displacements of Australian submarines, I also now provide the following information:
The current standard displacement of the Oberon submarine is approximately 1700 tonnes; the surface displacement is about 2230 tonnes; the dived displacement is approximately 2450 tonnes.
The figures for the Collins submarine as estimated in the contract are standard—2490 tonnes; surface—2860 tonnes and dived—3140 tonnes.
As part of refining the Collins Class design, the displacements of the vessels may vary.
I reiterate the points made when I responded to the question on 10 October.

The Collins Class submarine will not be significantly different from the Oberon in overall external dimensions; being shorter in length, about the same size in beam, but deeper in draught and larger in pressure hull diameter.
Although volumes and dimensions do reflect changes in submarine design since the time the Oberons were constructed, they are peripheral to the main issue.
The Collins Class submarine is ideally suited for its important contribution to the defence of Australia—and it is providing valuable opportunities for the Australian shipbuilding industry.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 11 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to Australia's invitation to be a partner at the world's largest technology trade show, the CeBit Forum to be held in Hanover, Germany 1993:
(1) Has Australia accepted this invitation; if not, why not.
(2) What is the estimated cost of participation in this show.
(3) How many visitors are expected to attend the show.
(4) Can the Minister provide an estimate of the likely benefits to Australia's manufacturing industries from participation in the show.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Trade and Overseas Development has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Australia recently received an invitation from the organisers of CeBit to be the host nation at the 1993 show in Hanover, Germany. The invitation was extended by the organisers during their visit to Australia October 23-25.

Australia, through Austrade has been a regular participant at CeBit since its inception. The role of host nation, however, involves a broader participation in the show. In addition to participation in the exhibition through a National Pavilion, Australia would be required to host the international seminar and to present major cultural, tourism and other more general promotional activities.
The organisers are also seeking major Government and Ministerial representation.

This is a major exercise and is being addressed by Austrade in consultation with Federal and State Government Departments, the industry body Australian Information Industries Association (AIIA) and relevant individual companies—all of whom would need to contribute financially and in kind to the costs of the exhibition if it is to go ahead in 1993.
It is interesting to note that Canada was initially offered host nation status for 1993, but deferred until 1994.

The CeBit organisers are seeking a decision by the end of December 1991. This is a very short lead time given the size of the task involved. One option under consideration is to defer acceptance until 1995 to provide a longer lead time for organisational purposes.

(2) A `back of envelope' estimate of the cost of participating as a host nation in 1993 is in excess of $1 million. (This compares with around $300,000 contributed by Austrade and industry participants in a `normal' exhibition year).
(3) In 1991, 578,000 visitors attended CeBit—including 90,800 from outside Germany.
(4) Responses from Australian companies (typically 12-18) who have participated on the Australian Pavilion in recent years indicate that the show is well worth while.
Information provided by participants in 1991 indicates `probable' sales in the order of $18m will result.

However, a key issue is a general lack of industry support. Austrade is having some difficulty in recruiting participants for the 1992 show and while host nation status would raise the profile of the event there is no indication we will find it easier to attract industry participation.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, upon notice, on 12 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Are claims made at the recent National Aboriginal Corrections Conference 'that more Aborigines are being gaoled and conditions in some prisons have deteriorated since the report of the Royal Commission on Aboriginal Deaths in Custody' correct.
(2) Is it true that funding for education and drug and alcohol programs has been reduced since the Royal Commission report.
(3) Will the Minister make arrangements to facilitate distribution of the Royal Commission's recommendations so that Aboriginal communities can become aware of their rights.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am unaware of the claims made. The Final Report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody made significant recommendations concerning the care and custody of Aboriginal prisoners and the need for police officers to receive instruction concerning Aboriginal culture.

These matters were the subject of discussion and endorsement by the Joint Ministerial Forum of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments. The Commonwealth has already acted upon the recommendations of the Royal Commission concerning cell refurbishment and has allocated funding for that purpose.

The Joint Ministerial Forum has committed the States and Territories to do everything in their power to remedy the situation and as Chairman of the Joint Ministerial Forum I will do all I can to ensure that the recommendations are carried out.

(2) In respect of drug and alcohol programs, the 1991/92 ATSIC budget allocation of $5,260,000 exceeds the initial 1990/91 allocation of $4,900,000. During the 1990/91 financial year savings from other functional allocations were identified to the initial budget allocation resulting in an end of year expenditure of $6,450,555.
At this stage of the financial year it is not possible to determine whether similar reallocations may be achievable during 1991/92.

(3) I am informed that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission has distributed, as far as possible to all Aboriginal bodies, services and the elected Aboriginal Regional Councils the final report of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. To better inform Aboriginal Australians the printing of an "Overview" edition of the Royal Commission's Final Report was arranged, which has been widely distributed throughout Australia.

Copies of the final draft response of the Commonwealth to the Royal Commission's recommendations have also been distributed to the same bodies to seek Aboriginal comment and policy input before the Commonwealth's response is tabled in Parliament. This has been done in line with recommendations contained in the Royal Commission's Final Report.
