(2) What measures are in place to protect Australian flowers from pests and diseases, such as chrysanthemum leaf miner, western thrip, carnation anther smut and philophora wilt, which are presently not in Australia but which could be transmitted through imports.
(3) Does the department consider that the devitalisation treatment is sufficient to eliminate the threat of all such pests and diseases, as mentioned in (1) and (2).

(4) Is the department aware that some imported cut flowers have been treated or sprayed with toxic chemicals not registered for use in Australia, and have these chemicals been assessed for the health risks involved for Australian workers exposed to these chemicals through physical contact or inhalation.
(5) Does the department consider there is any risk involved from access to the chemical Pentac manufactured by Sandoz of Sydney.

(6) With reference to the facts that the major pest or disease confronting the Australian flower and nursery industries is the two spotted mite for which there are no legally available pesticides, that the miticide Pentac has been used in most flower-producing countries, including the USA, Europe and New Zealand for 20 years without the development of resistant, and that the elimination of two spotted mite problem would greatly increase exports of flowers, is the miticide Pentac likely to be authorised for use in Australia; if so, when.
(7) Does the department agree with the industry's view that the use of the miticide Pentac would reduce substantially the occupational hazard from chemicals to flower industry workers.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Primary Industries and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service (AQIS) is responsible for ensuring that adequate measures are in place to prevent the introduction of serious exotic pests and diseases into Australia. The present procedures for the importation of cut flowers recognise that potentially serious pests and diseases may be carried with these goods, and, consequently, appropriate inspection and treatment measures have been implemented to counter this risk. AQIS does not differentiate between those pests and diseases which can or cannot be controlled by chemicals currently available in Australia, but seeks to stop the entry of all quarantinable pests and diseases.

(2) AQIS has developed strict procedures for the importation of plant material which is capable of transmitting serious pests and diseases. Imported cut flowers are subject to inspection for the presence of pests and diseases and, if detected, are treated accordingly. Where live insects are found, the consignment is fumigated with methyl bromide, whereas if diseases such as carnation anther smut and philophora wilt are detected, the consignment may be destroyed.
In addition, susceptible cut flower imports from countries known to have chrysanthemum leaf miner (Liriomyza trifolii) are subject to mandatory fumigation with methyl bromide.

(3) AQIS' devitalisation requirements recognise that the risk of introducing exotic diseases is much greater in living plants than in non-propagatable plant material. By ensuring that all cut flower importations cannot be subsequently propagated by conventional methods, the risk of spreading exotic plant diseases is contained.

(4) The treatments which may be applied to cut flowers in exporting countries can vary considerably, and are not monitored by AQIS, as it is not a quarantine issue. This matter would be more relevant to State responsibilities for monitoring pesticide usage, to the same standards as are applied to domestically produced and marketed flowers.

(5) All agricultural chemicals must be assessed and registered before their use can be approved. Until an application is made for registration of Pentac on cut flowers, the risk to public or occupational health cannot be assessed.

(6) There has been no request to the Department of Primary Industries and Energy for clearance and registration of Pentac on cut flowers. Should clearance and registration be considered necessary then the chemical manufacturer or his agent can seek approval of the product under the terms and conditions of the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals Act, 1988 which is administered by my Department.

(7) Without access to the appropriate data which would be required as part of the clearance and registration process, it is not possible to assess the likely occupational hazard to flower industry workers.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the total amount allocated to Indonesia as part of the Defence Cooperation Program for 1991-92.
(2) What will this money be spent on.
(3) How many Indonesian military personnel are currently studying or training in Australia and where are they being trained.
(4) What exchanges between Australian and Indonesian military personnel are scheduled to take place in 1991-92.
(5) What joint military exercises are scheduled to take place in 1991 involving Australian and Indonesian military personnel.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Australia-Indonesia Defence Cooperation Program was terminated at Indonesia's request in 1988. Since then, costs of cooperative defence activities with Indonesia have been shared between the two countries. The amount allocated from Division 232, Defence Cooperation, in 1991-92 is $2.312 million.
(2) This amount has been allocated to support training, study visits and personnel exchanges.

(3) As at 26 November, there were four Indonesian officers attending Australian staff college courses, 22 personnel in combat instructor training at the Land Warfare Centre in Canungra and one officer at Canungra on the Foreign Officer's Tactical Intelligence Course. They have completed their courses and returned to Indonesia.

In January 1992, 11 Indonesian military personnel are scheduled to begin courses in Australia. Of these, four will be attending staff college courses, two will be doing Regimental Officer basic training, three will undertake an aircraft surface finishing course at RAAF Base, Amberley and two will be at RAAF Base, Edinburgh for radar operator training.

(4) On exchanges, there is currently one Army officer attached to the Indonesian Armed Forces Mapping Centre to support Indonesia's development of a topographic mapping capability. There are no Indonesian exchange officers in Australia.

Proposed consultancy assistance to the Indonesian Navy in developing a maintenance capability for its Nomad maritime surveillance aircraft includes the short term attachment of six Australian Army personnel in Indonesia for 3-4 months followed by reciprocal attachments of two personnel from each country for two years.
(5) No further combined exercises are scheduled for 1991. Exercises held in 1991 were:
Passage exercises by Australian and Indonesian Navy vessels while Australian ships were transiting Indonesian waters. There were four in the AUSINA series between February and June 1991.
A maritime exercise NEW HORIZON involving ships and aircraft from both countries in October 1991.
A small-scale Air Force exercise using a C130 aircraft in its airdrop capability at RAAF Richmond in June.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 26 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Given that the original intention of the Commonwealth's funding arrangement since 1985 was to provide a minimum level of Government (Commonwealth and State) funding equivalent to 25 per cent of the Community Standard, does the Commonwealth have a commitment to a minimum level of Government funding for children in approved non-Government schools; if so, what is that level.
(2) What arrangements does the Commonwealth have in place to ensure that this minimum level of funding is maintained.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Commonwealth Government funding for non-government schools is provided according to assessed need with those schools with the greatest capacity to generate funds on their own behalf receiving the lowest level of Commonwealth subvention. The minimum rate of Commonwealth funding is currently $379 per primary and $601 per secondary student.

(2) It was never the intention of the Government to provide a minimum level of funding for non-government schools from both State and Commonwealth sources equivalent to 25 per cent of the Community Standard. This figure of 25 per cent has been drawn to the Minister's attention previously. It comes from Appendix D to Options for Commonwealth Funding of Recurrent Resources For Australian Schools—A Discussion Paper. This paper was circulated by the then Commonwealth Schools Commission in February 1984. Appendix D is simply a forecast resource configuration. The Hon Senator may be aware that in the body of the document mention is made of the difficulties some State Governments would have with the concept of a national resourcing standard. Further reference to differences in funding approaches across the States is found in the Commission's final document Funding Policies For Australian Schools although no mention is made of a 25 per cent minimum funding level.

The Government has provided stability and security with its funding arrangements for non-government schools which enable them to plan in a known context. These arrangements guarantee real increases for those schools most in need. Schools are advised of Commonwealth funding levels in eight year cycles. These levels of funding are guaranteed through the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act which sets funding levels for four year periods.

The funding position of non-government schools was reviewed and schools advised of their funding category for the period 1993-96 in 1990. Funding levels for this period will be guaranteed through legislation to be introduced in 1992.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the following circular, on what date and to whom did the department issue the circular:
CIRCULAR

QUESTION.PARA: PROVISION OF DIRECT MARKETING SERVICES (Incorporation Telemarketing, Computer and Fulfilment Services)

PARA.TAB: PERIOD: Date of Acceptance to 31 January 1993

QUESTION.PARA: Attached is a Request for Tender for the Provision of Direct Marketing Services.
Tenders have previously been invited for this service and a National contract is already in place.

However after reviewing the contract, it has been determined that additional capacity is required in the ACT, WA and the NT particularly for the fulfilment segment of the service which by its nature, is often best undertaken using local service providers.
In fairness to existing contractors tenders received for services outside the abovementioned regions will not receive consideration.

PARA.TAB: (2) With reference to the matters stated in the circular: (a) who reviewed the contract; (b) what procedure was followed in the conduct of the review and who participated in it; and (c) who determined that `additional capacity' was required in the ACT, WA and the NT.

(3) Did the department or the Minister receive any representations, either before or during the review, that additional capacity was, would, or might be required in any of the ACT, WA or the NT; if so, will the Minister table a copy of each such representation.

(4) Once it was determined that `additional capacity' was required in the ACT, WA or the NT, were existing contractors approached to determine whether they were in a position to supply that additional capacity within the terms of their existing contracts; if not, why not.
(5) What does the expression `fulfilment segment of the service' mean and what is that, by its nature, is often best undertaken using `local service providers'.
(6) Do `local service providers', as that expression is used in the circular, exist in each of the ACT, WA and the NT.

(7) Do the existing common-user contracts for the provision of direct marketing services include provision for payment of compensation to any existing contractor if their services are terminated or if the contract is otherwise determined; if so, what are those provisions.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The tender was advertised in the Commonwealth Gazette of 30 October 1991, the Northern Territory News of 31 October 1991, the West Australian of 2 November 1991 and the Canberra Times of 2 November 1991. The circular, which accompanied the tender document, was despatched to 26 known potential tenderers. A further 55 sets of documentation were despatched during the tender period in response to the advertisements. A full list of those organisations receiving the documentation can be provided if required.
(2) (a) The contract was reviewed by the National Manager, Purchasing Services.

(b) The National Manager, Purchasing Services reviewed information from an internal DAS Audit review of the tendering process for this contract, quarterly returns of the various suppliers on contract, and knowledge of the contract usage and the industry.
(c) The National Manager, Purchasing Services and the Assistant General Manager, Audit had recommended this be examined.

(3) This was the first time the work had been tendered as a common use contract. The Department received a representation about the tender process. This was examined by the Department's Audit Branch which recommended review of the capacity/choice available in ACT, NT and WA.

(4) Suppliers with an office in each capital city were appointed in response to the initial tender. However, the Department tries to provide clients with a choice of suppliers/products on its contracts to enable purchasing officers to assess best value for money in their particular circumstances. Performance of the contract indicated that locally based suppliers were receiving a significant proportion of work where choice was available. It was therefore not appropriate to seek this extra capacity from existing suppliers although they were advised of the action being taken.

(5) Fulfilment Services provided under the contract cover the process of responding to enquiries. They comprise inventory control (including stock control, product selection etc), enveloping (including collation, folding, insertion, sealing, application of address labels etc), and packaging (including stapling, taping, cartonning, addressing etc) and supply of materials (i.e. envelopes, cartons and/or labels) including also warehousing, distribution and/or preparation for distribution (i.e. lodgment with Australia Post).

For campaigns and other longer term projects, telemarketing, direct mail and fulfilment choices do not necessarily have to be undertaken in the same city as the client. However, some work, particularly fulfilment work, requires very quick turnaround eg overnight enveloping for urgent delivery next morning, which requires the work be undertaken at the particular location.

(6) Local service providers are believed to exist in ACT and WA and may exist in NT. Responses to the tender advertisements will establish whether, if the capacity exists, the proprietors are interested in undertaking this work for the Commonwealth.

(7) Common-use contracts are not contracts in the strict legal sense. They are standing offers by the supplier to supply goods or services at the price agreed and on specified terms and conditions if they are ordered by the Commonwealth. The Commonwealth may choose whether to place orders or not. There is no provision for and no need for a provision for compensation to existing contractors when changes are made to these continuing offers.
There is no intention of terminating any arrangements with current suppliers of Direct Marketing Services, merely of adding suppliers to provide for local service in the regions nominated.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 27 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the commitment given by the Government on 2 March 1990 to transfer the School of Artillery from Sydney to Townsville:
(1) When will the transfer take place.
(2) Why has the transfer been delayed.
(3) What preliminary steps, if any, directly associated with the plan to transfer the School of Artillery, have been taken and at what expense.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The proposal is due for authorisation in FY 94/95, and on current planning the School of Artillery will not move before 1998.

(2) There is presently no pressure for the School of Artillery to vacate North Head, however increasing restrictions on the use of Holsworthy Range for artillery field firing have caused the School of Artillery to use alternative ranges (Singleton Range and High Range Townsville).

Implementation of the Defence Force Structure Review has led to a requirement to reassess the planning options which led to the selection of Townsville as the preferred long-term location for the School of Artillery.

(3) Director General Accommodation and Works—Army advise that commencement of preliminary design work for the Townsville option has been deferred pending reassessment of the original planning options. It is unlikely that funds will be expended on design work on the Townsville option this FY. Programming provisions have been made in the later part of the decade to fund the relocation, when the final location is determined.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 28 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the civil rights campaigner, Mr John Doohan, called for the release of the details of the sinking of HMAS Sydney in 1941.
(2) Are there documents that have not been released to the public; if so, how many, and when are the documents expected to be released.
(3) Can the Minister confirm reports that radio signals from HMAS Sydney were picked up in Perth and Darwin after it had been hit; if so, can any of the information transmitted be given.
(4) Can the Minister give any further information to fill the void of information that the relatives of the 645 men lost have endured for 50 years.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Mr Doohan has written to me about this matter and provided me with a copy of a submission which he presented to a public forum in Perth in November 1991.

(2) Australian Archives has recently compiled a list of Commonwealth records known to relate to HMAS Sydney which are in the custody of the Archives or of the Australian War Memorial. Copies of the list are available for public consultation at regional offices of the Archives. The only material included in the list which is not publicly available consists of some personally sensitive information in three crew ledgers and some signals records which are being examined by the Department of Defence to determine their suitability for release.
(3) No evidence has been located by the Department of Defence within its archival records to support the reports that radio signals were picked up in Perth and Darwin.

(4) The list referred to above in answer to question (2) includes all material of which Australian Archives is aware. Definitive statements as to the availability of all records or the possible existence of hitherto unseen records cannot be made. The primary reason for this is that the exact location of every record possibly relating to the loss of Sydney is not known. Information on the loss of HMAS Sydney is contained in the Official History of Australia in the War 1939-1945 as well as a number of other publications.

(3) Is the Minister going to honour the terms of the 1988 Cook/Groom agreement regarding compensation to the operator.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The operator of the limestone quarry at Ida Bay in the Tasmanian World Heritage Area (TWHA) has given a conditional agreement not to extend his operations beyond the existing quarry (consistent with the acceptable limits set by the Cook/Groom Agreement) pending review of a draft Environmental Management Plan.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 28 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: Did the Government, through our embassies and high commissions, facilitate in any way the recent visits by the Co-Chairman of the World Jewish Congress (WJC), Mr Isi Leibler, to China, Hong Kong, Singapore, Thailand, the Philippines and Japan; if so, what was the assistance given to Mr Leibler and the WJC delegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Mr Isi Leibler, a prominent member of the Australian Jewish community and currently Co-Chairman of the World Jewish Congress Governing Board and President of the World Jewish Congress Asia Pacific Region, visited New Delhi, Singapore, Bangkok, Tokyo and Seoul between 19 and 29 November 1991 in order to encourage support for the rescission of United Nations General Assembly (UNGA) Resolution 3379 of 1975, which equated Zionism with racism.

In accordance with Australia's policy of strongly supporting efforts to rescind Resolution 3379, I wrote to several leading political figures in countries on Mr Leibler's itinerary requesting them to meet with Mr Leibler to discuss the issue. Our posts in the region helped to arrange appointments for Mr Leibler and assisted him during his visit. Heads of Mission accompanied Mr Leibler on his more important calls.

I understand that in October Mr Leibler visited Beijing and Hong Kong. On those occasions Mr Leibler did not request assistance from me, our Embassy in Beijing or our Consulate-General in Hong Kong, and the Ambassador and Consul-General did not accompany him on his calls.

Independently of Mr Leibler's visits, the Government lobbied vigorously for rescission of Resolution 3379 and joined more than 80 other nations on 16 December in co-sponsoring a rescission motion in the UN General Assembly. The Government subsequently welcomed the Assembly's overwhelming adoption of the rescission motion, with 111 votes in favour out of the 149 votes cast. It will be recalled that in 1986 the Australian Parliament was the first in the world to pass a resolution calling for the overturning of Resolution 3379.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, upon notice, on 28 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the United Nations Conference on the Environment and Development to be held in Rio de Janeiro in 1992, which has as one of its major goals agreement on an international convention to protect biological diversity:

(1) Did officers of the department and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy, who went to Nairobi for discussions on the conference, go without any briefing from the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) about the progress in Australia on a national strategy to protect biodiversity.
(2) Was it more than a month after the officers returned to Australia before they became aware of the formal document prepared by DASETT on this matter.

(3) What action can be taken to ensure that there is no repetition of this ludicrous situation where one arm of the Federal bureaucracy refuses to share its information with another section which is responsible for putting Australia's views at an international forum.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I assume that Senator Panizza is referring to the meeting of the Intergovernmental Negotiating Committee for a Convention on Biological Diversity, which was held in Nairobi from 23 September -2 October 1991.

The delegation to the Biodiversity Convention negotiations in Nairobi, including officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade (DFAT) and the Department of Primary Industries and Energy (DPIE), was fully aware of the stage which development of a draft National Strategy had reached. Indeed, the officer of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (DASETT) who has attended a number of negotiating sessions for the Biodiversity Convention, is also the DASETT officer directly responsible for coordinating the development of the draft National Strategy—certainly providing an integral link between national and international biodiversity issues.
The DASETT officer was available at all times before, during and after the Nairobi session to answer any questions by delegation members arising from the development of the draft Strategy.

(2) An incomplete preliminary draft of the National Strategy was provided to relevant Commonwealth Departments in November. The draft was not prepared by DASETT, but by the Biological Advisory Committee, a body set up early this year by the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to develop the National Strategy. DASETT is not a member of that Committee, providing it only with secretariat services. The draft Strategy is one of a number of working drafts of the Committee and has been provided to relevant agencies to give them an idea of the proposed scope and content of the Strategy.

(3) It is incorrect to suggest that DFAT or DPIE have been denied information which may be crucial to Australia's participation in the Biodiversity Convention negotiations. Members of the Australian delegation carry the same brief, jointly prepared and cleared by relevant Commonwealth Departments in line with a number of Government decisions on Australia's negotiating position. Preparation of the National Strategy and Australia's position for the international Convention are fully coordinated. There is and will continue to be full consultation between interested Departments and ample opportunity for thinking on the National Strategy, as it develops, to be taken account of in Australia's negotiating position on the Biodiversity Convention.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 28 November 1991:

PARA.TAB: What is the procedure with which a Senator is obliged to comply in order to qualify for a Parliamentary Pension in the event of illness or injury preventing him or her from continuing in the role of an elected Member of Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: Sections 17 and 18A of the Parliamentary Contributory Superannuation Act 1948 (the Act) contain the conditions under which a Parliamentary Pension may be granted on grounds of invalidity.
Senators with sufficient service will, on voluntary retirement, receive a pension at the rate applicable to their length of service regardless of whether the retirement is due to invalidity.

Senators with insufficient qualifying service to receive a pension on voluntary retirement may qualify for a pension if they are deemed by the Parliamentary Retiring Allowances Trust (the Trust) to have involuntarily retired with eight or more years of service. The Trust may deem that a Senator has retired involuntarily with eight years or more of service, as appropriate, if the Senator satisfies the Trust that resignation or failure to stand at an election was bona fide on account of ill-health.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security,upon notice, on 2 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) With reference to the particular needs of children with coeliac disease and the considerable extra demands placed on their parents' time and financial resources because of the supervision and maintenance of a gluten-free diet, what steps are being taken to review the current guidelines relating to eligibility for the Child Disability Allowance and to ensure that all coeliac children are entitled to the allowance.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: The Social Security Act provides the legislative basis for qualification for child disability allowance. The main requirements are that the child has a physical, intellectual or psychiatric disability and needs substantially more care and attention than a child of the same age without a disability.

My Department has recently reviewed the guidelines concerning the medical assessment of children with coeliac disease. As a result no distinction will be made for child disability allowance eligibility purposes between children who have a mild reaction to gluten and those who present a severe reaction.

While these children are recognised as having a disability, as with all claims for child disability allowance, it needs to be established that the disabled child needs substantially more care and attention than a child of the same age who does not have a disability. This assessment is made on an individual basis. To assist in determining eligibility, carers of children with coeliac disease are encouraged to give a detailed account of the level of care and attention provided to the child.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs, upon notice, on 3 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Ombudsman's recent statement of concern regarding the increased number of complaints about the Federal Police:
(1) Will an inquiry be instituted into the training and supervision of police, especially in situations of conflict.

(2) Will a detailed response be sought from the Ombudsman about a range of incidents at the AIDEX exhibition, reported to him in a number of statutory declarations alleging intimidation, harassment and unnecessary force.
(3) Will the Minister report to the Senator on the outcome of that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. AFP members are comprehensively trained in all areas of policing, including crowd control, and are well supervised at all times. The training methods used and practices taught are similar to those of equivalent police forces throughout the world and are suitable to the AFP's requirements, training of AFP members is subject to ongoing review and adjustment where necessary including after major incidents, such as the keeping of the peace at the AIDEX exhibition.

(2) and (3) The response from the Ombudsman to individual complaints will, of course, be a private matter in each case. The Ombudsman is able, nevertheless, to report publicly on general issues arising from his assessment of the investigation of complaints. If the Ombudsman makes such a report I will seek to have that report made available to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories, upon notice, on 2 December 1991:

(3) Did the Member for Brand (Ms Wendy Fatin) play a role in arranging this appointment.
(4) Was the purpose of this meeting to discuss the proposed interim listing of Port Kennedy, Hepburn Heights and Leda on the Register of the National Estate.
(5) Were any other proposed listings discussed with Ms Sullivan at that meeting; if so, which ones.
(6) Did the Australian Heritage Commission subsequently discuss the interim listing of Leda, Hepburn Heights and Port Kennedy at its meeting on 21 November 1991.
(7) What decisions did the Australian Heritage Commission make in respect to the listing of Port Kennedy, Leda and Hepburn Heights.
(8) Is it appropriate for a State Government to interfere so blatantly in the operations of the Australian Heritage Commission.

(9) Is it of concern that the Australian Heritage Commission may have lost credibility with the public by allowing itself to be pressured by developers into reversing its previous decision to place Port Kennedy on the interim list.

(10) Will an assurance be given that the advice of the Australian Heritage Commission will be sought if any attempt is made by the developers to obtain overseas finance for proposed developments within the nominated area at Port Kennedy.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment and Territories has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Representatives of the Western Australian Government met the Executive Director of the Australian Heritage Commission and other staff on Tuesday 19 November 1991.
(2) Yes
(3) I am not aware of any involvement of the Hon Wendy Fatin in arranging the meeting.
(4) Yes. The significance of these areas was discussed in the context of remnant natural areas in the Perth metropolitan area and regional planning for the growth of the city.
(5) In the context of Hepburn Heights, the significance of the adjacent Pinnaroo Valley Park was discussed.
(6) At its meeting on 21 November 1991, the Commission discussed the listing of the Port Kennedy area in the Register of the National Estate.
(7) The Commission decided to defer a final decision on the listing of the Port Kennedy area to its next meeting, on 9-13 February 1992.

This procedure provides a final check on the effects that recent changes may have had on places so that any necessary amendments can be made prior to publication. The Commission has deferred consideration of nominations and the listing of places on several occasions following requests, based on sound reasons, from State and Territory governments.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 3 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Where are the archival records of the former State Bank of Victoria currently held.
(2) Is it correct that the records are no longer under the jurisdiction of the Australian Archives and that they are solely owned and controlled by the Commonwealth Bank.

(3) What constraints are there upon the Commonwealth Bank to ensure that the records are properly maintained and that the residents of Victoria have access to the records not 'closed' under the Public Records Act.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Victoria.

(2) Yes. When the Commonwealth Bank acquired the State Bank of Victoria, the records, as part of the property of the State Bank of Victoria, were transferred to the new owner, the Commonwealth Bank. On 2 April 1991, when section 27H of the Commonwealth Bank Restructuring Act 1990 came into operation, the records of the Commonwealth Bank both before and after that date were exempted from the provisions of the Archives Act. This means that the State Bank of Victoria records, together with other Commonwealth Bank records have been removed from the operation of the Archives Act.

(3) As the Commonwealth Bank is no longer subject to any public archives legislation, provision for the records is within the Bank's control. While there are no legislative provisions affecting the former State Bank of Victoria archives now maintained by the Commonwealth Bank, the Bank has advised that it has given assurances that:
it has no plans to transfer the archives to Sydney; and
the archives will be staffed at a level sufficient to maintain them in good order and to continue to respond to both professional and private enquiries in an efficient manner.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources, upon notice, on 3 December 1991:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(2) The NAP was introduced in 1987 to stimulate an expansion in the timber resource base for the forest products industries through the provision of grants to the States and the private sector for the establishment of commercial hardwood plantations and for related applied research projects.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services, upon notice, on 5 December 1991:

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Health, Housing and Community Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Bilateral agreements between the Commonwealth and the States and Territories form the basis of the Building Better Cities (BBC) Program. Priorities have been addressed in the agreements which include program objectives and criteria for the selection of proposals. Proposals, or Area Strategies, developed by the State or Territory are then considered against the criteria, and those selected are jointly agreed to by the Commonwealth and the relevant State or Territory at ministerial level.

(2) The State and Territory Governments have responsibility for proposing and implementing Area Strategies. The program stresses an area focus and cooperation between all three levels of government is fundamental to achieving this. Hence there is a clear role for local government within the program and the agreements stipulate that States and Territories are to make arrangements for appropriate consultations with local government in the development and implementation of the program. The Commonwealth has stressed the importance of this as part of the process.

(3) and (4) The BBC Program is focused on selected strategic areas for which `area strategies' have been developed. States have nominated proposals including the areas in which they are located. Strategies within areas place an emphasis on integrated initiatives which can demonstrate improvements and innovations for both planning and development.

This approach enables the formulation of comprehensive packages of projects to address identified issues but, at the same time, allows individual projects within an Area Strategy to focus on one or more activities such as public transport, urban renewal, public housing, family support services, institutional reform, and recreation facilities. The Area Strategies agreed to date have a strong focus on public transport and urban renewal. These and related initiatives will have a significant impact on improving the economic efficiency of those cities.

Reflecting the integrated approach of the program while some area strategies involve discrete central business district, outer suburbs etc, others - such as `corridor' areas - may take in a number of these. Additionally, of those already agreed to, the provincial cities of Geelong and Launceston are included.
Agreements have now been signed with Queensland, Tasmania and Victoria. The 1991-92 Area Strategies agreed to date, and key elements of these, include:
Brisbane-Gold Coast railway, involving a 46km track extension from Beenleigh to Robina plus 5 new railway stations and 4 integrated public transport interchanges
Two urban consolidation projects demonstrating integrated, higher density housing
Construction of public housing units and joint venture properties for integration of low-cost housing into general residential fabric.
Consolidation of urban renewal around public transport networks and expansion of park-ride services and interchanges.
Residential enhancement program, providing improved public/private housing mix and refurbishment of public housing
Reduced concentration of institutional services in the area and provision of more accessible and appropriate community and mental health services
Pilot crime reduction program, security strategy and associated environmental improvements.
Improved transport services to link central business district using dedicated electric bus fleet and development of light rail system.
Renewal of 300ha inner city area to provide better choice of housing and access to jobs and community services, incorporating improved public/private housing mix
Development of derelict land including river frontages.
Upgrade of the Geelong-Werribee-Melbourne rail link
Provision of infrastructure work for Werribee Biotechnology Precinct allowing access for specialised industry
Redevelopment of public housing in Norlane to provide improved public/private housing mix, improved housing choice and improved environment.
Provision of a light rail system from Bundoora to Mill Park
Urban consolidation providing higher densities using Australian Model Code for Residential Development (AMCORD) principles, better land use and greater choice of housing
Public housing projects including provision of residential units and support for people with intellectual disabilities.
Implementation of institutional reform consistent with Commonwealth State Disability Agreement providing better psychiatric treatment and care, integrated with mainstream health services.
Construction of rail stations and expanded modal interchange facilities, enhanced pedestrian access and electrification development.
Redevelopment of major land sites to provide mixed tenancy through more affordable housing and greater housing choice
Revitalisation of ageing public housing estates including provision of special-purpose elderly persons units and terrace style housing
Urban consolidation and redevelopment of blighted and under utilised land to enable better land use and greater efficiencies in urban services.
Urban consolidation including redevelopment of disused urban areas and industrial sites
Provision of more appropriate accommodation and services for people with intellectual disabilities and for frail aged people
Preservation of important heritage buildings in the Sullivans Cove area.
Assessment and development of 16ha of underutilised railway land adjacent to the North Esk River
Co-ordinated plan for recreational and cultural facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Commonwealth Government considering the possibility of transferring all responsibility for the administration of funding for the Youth Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (YSAAP) to the States.
(2) Would such changes result in a loss of control by the Commonwealth over the way in which YSAAP funds are spent by the States.

(3) Would such modification of YSAAP Special Purpose Payments, which are currently tied to State funding on a dollar-for-dollar basis, allow States to drastically cut funding for youth accommodation programs.
(4) Would the entire responsibility for determining types and levels of youth accommodation services be effectively in the hands of individual State Governments under such a scheme.
(5) Would this result in inconsistencies between the youth accommodation policies and programs pursued by different States.
(6) Would such changes mean that the States would no longer be accountable for the way in which Commonwealth funds for YSAAP are spent by them.
(7) Would a plan to devolve responsibility for youth accommodation entirely upon individual State governments be inconsistent with any national strategy to address youth homelessness.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1)-(7) The Special Premiers' Conference of October 1990 established a number of functional reviews with the aim of achieving greater efficiencies and flexibility in service delivery. A functional review of the Supported Accommodation Assistance Program (SAAP), which incorporates supported accommodation assistance for youth, was established as part of this process and completed at the end of August 1991. The SAAP functional review report was considered by a meeting of Commonwealth, State and Territory Health and Welfare Ministers on 6 September. Ministers agreed that, in recognition of the joint national interest in homelessness and domestic violence, involvement of both the Commonwealth and the States is required to address the complex causes of homelessness and domestic violence and provide opportunities for movement towards independence.

The Commonwealth's view is that SAAP should be retained as a joint Commonwealth/State program with the Commonwealth continuing to be closely involved in planning, needs assessment, priority setting and evaluation.
Under these arrangements the States and Territories would continue to be required to observe normal accountability requirements in both financial and client outcome terms.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to reports in the `Australian', titled 'Call for Clampdown on Malaria' by Anne Connolly on Monday, 9 December 1991, which states that the incidence of malaria in Australia has increased by 64 per cent over ten years, with most cases imported from the South Pacific, New Guinea and the Solomon Islands, in view of the increasing popularity of this area to Australian tourists and, in particular, its proximity to the State of Queensland:
(1) What safeguards are there to warn travellers to these areas of the high risk and dangers associated with contracting malaria.
(2) What are the accepted medical procedures to be undertaken by travellers to malaria-infested areas.
(3) Is there any existing legislation to ensure that travellers to high risk areas are inoculated against malaria, as is the case for those visiting areas infected with typhoid.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Travel health information is available from a variety of sources. The Department of Health, Housing and Community Service's publication `Health Information for International Health' (third edition published in October 1991) contains a comprehensive chapter on malaria. It is produced as a reference for medical practitioners who may need to advise intending travellers on health care matters and is available from all Commonwealth Government bookshops. The Department also provides a free, national, telephone advisory service for medical practitioners. Travel health advice is provided on a commercial basis from a number of sources, including the Australian Government Health Service (all States), the Traveller's Medical Vaccination Centre clinics (most States) and the Medical Advisory Service for Travellers Abroad (based in Sydney).
(2) Antimalarial measures can be broadly divided into 2 aspects:
a.personal protection - includes the use of repellents, full-coverage clothing, bed-nets and avoidance of malarious areas.

b.chemoprophylaxis - no one medication is completely safe and completely effective against malaria. Selection of appropriate chemoprophylaxis is best left to an attending medical practitioner who has details of the person's proposed travel, medical history and current health.
(3) There is no legislation as described. As yet no vaccines for malaria are commercially available, however, research into this important area is continuing.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Australian Defence Force, Defence Science and Technology Organisation or Department of Defence conducted scientific, medical or other types of experimentation involving the use of animals; if so (a) when were such tests conducted; (b) where were such tests conducted; and (c) what types and numbers of animals were involved.
(2) Please detail the type of experimentation conducted and state the purpose of such experimentation.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. Animals are used in two areas in Defence laboratories. The Army uses a small number of animals in their medical research and DSTO infrequently uses small animals in their program of research.
(a) Both Army and DSTO have ongoing programs of research that use animals. These programs have been in existence for several decades.
(b) The Army Malaria Research Unit and the Materials Research Laboratory.
(c) The Army keeps about 80 monkeys and a small number of rodents, and MRL uses about 17 rats and 150 guinea pigs per year in its research.

(2) In all experiments, protocols are monitored in advance by an independent Ethics Committee in accordance with The Australian Code of Practice for the Care and Use of Animals for Scientific Purposes. The facilities and scientists are registered, accountable and report as required by the various State Prevention of Cruelty to Animals Acts.

MRL uses animals for the provision of fresh animal tissue, which is obtained by humane methods. Whole anaesthetised animals have been used occasionally to study toxic effects on the whole body. The tissue preparations are used in pharmacological research studies undertaken to investigate protective treatment of poisoning by chemical agents. The purpose of this experimentation is to improve the therapeutic and preventive treatments for chemical agent poisoning that are available to Australian Service personnel.
The Army's program is concerned with malaria research. In particular, in the provision of malaria counter measures to protect Australian Defence Force personnel when deployed to malarious areas.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposals Gazette No. PD 46 of 27 November 1991, purchasing reference number 21/93443S-l:
(1) Was $500,000 paid by Navy to the National Analytical Laboratories of Ferntree Gully, Victoria for performing Urine Analytical services.
(2) What was the nature and purpose of such services.
(3) What were the terms of the contract.
(4) Over what period was the contract in operation.
(5) Was the service used to test for the use of drugs; if so, what were the results.
(6) How many Navy personnel have been subjected to these tests.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No, but a Standing Offer (PN8621) has been arranged with National Analytical Laboratories (NAL) by Navy for the supply of urine analytical services. To date, the sum paid to NAL is $13,200 for the supply of drug screening kits including initial screening of each specimen for amphetamines, cocaine, cannabinoids, opiates and methadone.
The estimated value of $500,000 was notified in the Commonwealth Purchasing and Disposals Gazette in error. A more likely outcome for the Standing Offer is the order of $40,000.

(2) Under the Standing Offer, NAL has undertaken to supply urine analysis kits to the Navy, including initial screening, and to assay specimens showing positive on initial screen by Gas Chromatography Mass Spectrometry.

These services have been obtained to assist in the maintenance of Naval discipline and Naval policy in relation to drug use. Urine samples are taken from Naval personnel in the following circumstances:
(a) under the provisions of the Defence Force Discipline Act relating to drug use (Sections 59(2) and 59(3)) and the collection of specimens for analysis (Section 101Q); and

(b) under Naval policy, contained in Defence Instruction (Navy) 13-1, which prohibits Naval members' involvement with illegal drugs for reasons related to the safety and security risks potentially associated with illegal drug involvement, and the community's expectation that the Navy will maintain a high standard of responsibility and readiness to perform its duties.

Navy's urinanalysis program under this policy does not extend to all members of the Navy. Urinanalysis is only carried out where a member has previously been found to be involved with drugs but has been retained by the Navy, or where a member voluntarily seeks assistance from Navy to overcome drug involvement.

(3) In broad outline, the terms of the Standing Offer are for NAL to provide a supply of kits for initial screening (400 supplied so far). These kits are to be replaced from time to time by NAL. Payment for these kits (and initial screen) occurs on supply of the kits. Payment for gas chromatography mass spectrometry occurs on the basis of monthly accounts submitted by NAL.
(4) The period of the Standing Offer is from 21 October 1991 to 20 October 1992.

(5) NAL's services have been used to test for drugs as outlined above. To date, only one specimen has returned a positive test result, which was confirmed by gas chromatography mass spectrometry to be positive for cocaine.

(6) Testing of Navy personnel has been conducted over a number of years, but no central records have been maintained of the number of tests performed. Since the arrangement of the Standing Offer with NAL, 17 specimens have been tested for amphetamines, cocaine, cannabinoids, opiates and methadone. Only one specimen has returned a positive test result as described above.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Navy: Automated Manpower and Personnel System

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 10 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) What is the current state of the Royal Australian Navy's Automated Manpower and Personnel System.
(2) What is the purpose of the system.
(3) What was the estimated cost of the system; was it under $10 million.
(4) What does the estimated cost include.
(5) Did it include the cost of purchasing software, hardware and communication networks.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Royal Australian Navy's Automated Manpower and Personnel System (RANAMPS) was planned to be Navy's unique automated personnel system. It was designed as a fully distributed database system using state of the art technology implemented Australia wide in ships and establishments. The logical model was completed in July 1991 but was overtaken by the Services Manpower and Pay Project (SMPP) in August 1991.

SMPP is an approved tri-Service project which is planned to provide much the same functionality as RANAMPS but in a more corporately consistent manner across the Department and in line with the latest Departmental and ADF strategy. Further development of RANAMPS was therefore suspended in November 1991 and the development staff and the data model transferred to SMPP for incorporation in that project.

(2) RANAMPS was designed to automate the majority of personnel functions at all levels of management, although the focus was at ship and establishment level where the great majority of RAN personnel data and management processes are located.

Its purpose was to make accurate, consistent data regarding Permanent Naval Force and Reserve forces available to all levels of management but especially corporate management where a consistent overview of Navy is essential.

(3) The estimated cost of the fully functional and fully networked RANAMPS system comprising over 950 workstations was about $45 million (March 1991). The latest costing (January 1992) was around $25 million and reflects the rapidly decreasing cost of low end computers, software and networking products.
(4) The cost includes the purchase of hardware, software, basic networking of ships and establishments, and the provision of user and system manager training.
(5) The cost includes the internal ship and establishment networks. It does not include the Wide Area Network. This already exists and is controlled by Army.
