Quotations were to be submitted by 1400 Monday 18 November 1991. Four firms responded. Hollywood Repatriation Hospital was awarded the laundry component of that contract in accordance with paragraph 7 of `Basis for Quotation' instructions. The tender for dry cleaning services was awarded to Rockingham Laundry and Dry Cleaning.

(2) The Defence Contracting Office in Perth was contacted prior to accepting tenders to confirm that acceptance of bids from Hollywood Repatriation Hospital was within Commonwealth Purchasing Guidelines.
It is confirmed that the tendering process was conducted in open competition; no advantage or bias was shown to any tenderer; nor was any tenderer pricing information available to other tenderers.

Hollywood Repatriation Hospital have been awarded the laundry contract on a three month trial basis subject to review. It is of note that Hollywood Repatriation Hospital have serviced a number of Federal Government departments and agencies notably:
Australian Government Analytical Laboratories
Australian Customs Service
CSIRO
Department of Social Security
Department of Community Services and Health
Australian Army
Royal Australian Air Force (until 1989)
HMAS Leeuwin (until closure)
(3) The bid submitted by Hollywood Repatriation Hospital was considerably lower than that of any other tenderer.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development, upon notice, on 11 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the statement made by the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development on 7 November 1991 that in 1990 Australia raised more than 460 human rights cases in over 82 different countries (House of Representatives Hansard, 7 November 1991 p.2625):
(1) With which countries were the human rights cases raised.
(2) How many cases were raised with each country.
(3) What alleged breach of human rights was involved in each case.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: During 1990, the Australian Government made 460 human rights representations to eighty-two countries.

The number of representations made by the Government is not the same as the number of cases raised. In some instances, for example, one representation may have covered several human rights cases. Some representations also would have addressed general human rights situations, and not specific cases.

It is not the Government's practice to publicise details of the cases it has raised. To do so could be detrimental to those individuals concerned. To place such information on the public record could also call into doubt, in the minds of our interlocutors, the Government's motivations or could jeopardise the Government's on-going dialogue with some States.

It is also my view that naming the countries to which Australia has made representations is likely to be counterproductive. I can, however, provide a regional breakdown of representations, which is as follows:
Southeast Asia28
North Asia6
South Asia18
Indo-China4
South Pacific2
Western Europe52
Eastern/Central Europe19
North America7
Central America63
South America104
Middle East23
Africa134

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why are housing loans of $50,000 at 5% interest being offered to the Defence civilian Public Sector Union employees working in the Defence Signals Directorate as an incentive to make the move from Melbourne to Canberra.
(2) In a time when people do not need incentive to take a job, why does the Government feel the need to offer such hand-outs.
(3) Why have the loans been offered only to the civilian personnel and not the Defence personnel in the department.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) The Defence Signals Directorate (DSD) is relocating from Melbourne to Canberra in two waves, in the December 1991/January 1992 and December 1992/January 1993 timeframes.

The Government is keen to attract as many experienced DSD personnel as possible to relocate to the new site in Canberra in order to minimise disruption to vital intelligence collection and dissemination. Accordingly, the Government has agreed to a subsidised home loan scheme to encourage eligible Defence civilian staff working in DSD, whose positions are to be transferred to Canberra, to move from Melbourne to Canberra.

They are not being offered housing loans of $50,000 at 5% interest, but an interest subsidy approximately equal to 40% of the interest applied to a $40,000 home loan for a maximum period of ten years. The assistance is only available where the individual remains with the Defence Department in Canberra. The arrangement is based on the Australian Defence Force Home Loans Assistance Scheme (Defence Homeowner) available to ex-Service personnel.
(3) As compulsory transfer to different locations is a normal part of Service life and conditions of service, Defence Force personnel are not entitled to the DSD arrangement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Government plotted the cost benefits of the reduction in training allocations for service personnel against the increase in costs associated with the increased accident rate.
(2) Is it a false economy to be making savings in the training costs which result in an increase of costs associated with training accidents.
(3) If this information has not been collected and compiled, can the department do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence Science and Personnel has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) I am advised by the Services that there has been no increase in the accident rates for Army and Navy over the past few years. Air Force has suffered some increase in accident rate, but investigations into the accidents have shown no causal link between them and any reduction in training allocation. The Services indicate strongly that any reduction in training allocation has not been allowed to compromise safety standards during or after training.

(2) Any reduction in training costs at the expense of increased downstream accident-related costs would be a false economy, however there is no evidence of a causal link between the number of accidents and the quantum of training allocations.
(3) The Services maintain records of reportable incidents.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: What is the cost of providing those pre-May 1985 enlisted service personnel who did not revoke their entitlements to the $25,000 Defence Home Loan administered by the Department of Veterans' Affairs with the ability to use the loan to re-finance an existing home mortgage, as can be done with the new $40,000 Defence home loan.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Veterans' Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: The answer to the honourable senator's question requires some assumptions to be made, in the absence of firm data.

The Department of Defence estimates that about 36,000 current serving members enlisted before May 1985, and it is assumed that most would be eligible for assistance under the DSH Act. About 2,000 of these have revoked their DSH eligibility. No data is available as to how many of the remaining members have already taken out a DSH loan.

However, if it is assumed that half have done so, and that half of those who already are buying their home with mortgage finance would apply if the provisions were amended as indicated, the subsidy cost would be $60 million over the term of the loan, or $3.6 million in the first year. To put this figure into perspective, the current revised estimate for the subsidy cost for the whole of the DSH program in 1991-92 is $99 million.

If this facility were extended to those who enlisted pre-May 1985, who have an eligibility, but have now left the forces, the cost would be much greater. It has been estimated that there are about 250,000 eligible persons who have not applied for assistance. If only 5% were to seek to re-finance an existing mortgage, the subsidy cost would be $355 million in total, and about $22.2 million in the first year.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has the Minister called for a full departmental report into statements made in the resignation letter of 21 August 1991 of an employee of the Department of Social Security (DSS) that allege the granting of sole parent pensions to people living in de facto relationships, and the removal of documents from departmental files to conceal breaches of regulations.

(2) Were the quarterly forms for the sole parent pension of a former employee of the Premier's Department in Western Australia removed from a DSS file as alleged, and why was this person not prosecuted for an apparent false declaration.
(3) Is the funding for departmental task forces pursuing overpayments drawn from surplus staff budgets; if so, what provision is made for their continuation when no such surplus exists.

(4) What automatic computerised review systems are in place to review DSS client claims to prevent overpayments; if there is not such a system, what consideration has been given to the institution of such a system.

(5) What procedures are used by the Compliance Section of DSS to ensure that those overpayments discovered are actually recovered through those regional offices of the department to which they are referred.
(6) What percentage of the special benefit in 1989-90 and 1990-91 has actually been recovered in those instances where it has been paid to immigrants under the Family Reunion Program.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes. The former employee made seventeen specific allegations. In seven of these allegations, the client's name was provided. In seven, details of circumstances only were provided and in the absence of names and dates, there was not sufficient detail to identify the cases concerned. Three of the allegations related to internal staffing/personnel issues.
DSS files were able to be located for three of the cases identified by client name. Because of the age of the other four cases, the files have been destroyed, consistent with departmental practice.
All of the specific allegations have been fully investigated and, where files were located, none of the allegations could be substantiated.
Several of the allegations had been investigated previously with the same outcome.

(2) The confidentiality provisions of the Social Security Act prevent me from disclosing details of the case. However, I can say that a name was provided to my Department but no file could be located. It is normal departmental practice, consistent with destruction guidelines, to destroy files twelve months after all action has been completed. A staff member who can recall the case has given an account which does not support the allegations.

(3) No. Processing of overpayments is the day to day responsibility of regional offices and funds are provided accordingly. Sometimes, build-ups of work are dealt with by re-allocating staff to the task from existing resources.
(4) Computerised systems are used by my Department to prevent incorrect payment and detect it where it occurs. The main systems are:
the Accelerated Claimant Matching System (to identify possible incorrect claims before payment commences).
the National Selective Review System (to identify cases for review where there is believed to be a higher than average likelihood of incorrect payment); and
the Data Matching Program (primarily to identify undisclosed income and multiple payments across Agencies),

(5) The Overpayment Review System is used to monitor the processing of overpayment cases. Cases identified by compliance projects which are undertaken outside the regional offices are recorded automatically on the Overpayment Review System. The progress of each case can then be monitored in the regional offices, area offices and in the national administration.

(6) Cumulative figures on recovery of debts according to the year in which they were raised are not available. In respect of Job Search Allowance, Newstart and Special Benefit paid to migrants with an assurance of support, in 1989-90 debts of $5.02m were raised and $0.42m was recovered. I refer the honourable senator to my responses to the Senate on 11 November and 13 November concerning assurance of support debts for 1990-91.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 12 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Has Aerospace Technologies of Australia been given a 99 year lease on the Avalon Airfield, situated near Geelong in Victoria, for the sum of $70 million.
(2) Is this an adequate amount, considering the potential of the site and that it also `targeted' as a second international terminal to Tullamarine in Melbourne.

(3) Is this sale an example of `get rich quick' incentives which lack insight; an insight upon which the future is dependent, especially in view of current technology, the economy and environmental problems, and are there comparisons between the poor trade for Avalon and the arms trade called AIDEX.

(4) Could the need to address `econological' (both economic and ecological) threats to our way of life, in the long term, pay off in terms of tourism, the selling of relevant technology (ecological management) and maintaining a stable environment.
(5) Might the development of alternative technologies to facilitate ecological management be a far better long term proposition than developing technology to aid in human destruction.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, in July 1990.
(2) Yes, particularly as prospective development of Avalon Airport on a commercial basis is very much a long term undertaking.
(4) and (5) I fail to see the connection to the prime subject of the question.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Civil Aviation Authority: ADF Personnel Redundancies

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industrial Relations, upon notice, on 13 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to a meeting held between the RSL, AFFA, representatives of ex-ADF personnel employed by the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) and officers of the Department of Industrial Relations on 26 November 1991 during which current departmental policies on redundancy which adversely affect ex-ADF personnel who continued in Commonwealth employment were discussed, and the senior department officer gave an undertaking to review these policies urgently:
(1) Will the Minister ensure that this review is carried out urgently, as any delay will adversely affect ex-defence employees of the Commonwealth now facing redundancy.

(2) Since the inequities in the Commonwealth's policies on redundancy insofar as they affect ex-ADF personnel were first raised with the CAA as early as July 1991, and it has taken until 26 November 1991 for the need for a review to be accepted by the department, will the Minister ensure that any revised policy will be backdated to 11 November 1991, that is, the date when the first redundancies occurred in the CAA.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Existing policy is that where prior service has attracted a retirement benefit (whether from the ADF or other Commonwealth employment), that service should not be counted for the purpose of redundancy payments in subsequent Commonwealth employment. The review mentioned by the honourable senator has been completed, and the representations made on behalf of the ex-ADF employees in the Civil Aviation Authority have been replied to.
(2) Since there was no change to the existing policy, this part of the question is not applicable.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: National Air and Space Museum of Australia

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 18 December l991:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the Minister's statements at the Senate Estimates Committee B Hearing on 11 September 1991, (Estimates Committee B Hansard, pp204-5) in which the Minister appeared to rule out the use of either Point Cook or Laverton Air Base as a site for the National Air and Space Museum of Australia (NASMA):

(1) Do these statements, viz, `I would not rule out Avalon myself as an alternative site for NASMA' and `we are not keeping open a several hundred hectare site (Laverton/Point Cook) simply for the purpose of the NASMA museum', prejudge the issue and pre-empt the consideration of the Consultative Committee on the Future Use of the Defence Property RAAF Laverton and Point Cook which is required to consider all alternative uses of the facilities.
(2) Does the Minister still support the terms of reference which require the Consultative Committee to `ensure continued economic, employment, social and community benefits for the Werribee area'.

(3) Do the terms of reference require the development of a co-ordinated plan which makes provision for industrial, residential, aviation, NASMA, educational and recreational uses as well as community services with the aim of increasing employment opportunities and access to essential services.
(4) Is this approach preferable to a `sell-off' to one or more buyers who are then at liberty to use the land and facilities for their own purposes, with no regard to community needs.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) No. The establishment of the Consultative Committee demonstrates the Government's concern that all interested parties are given the opportunity to make an input into decisions on the future of the Laverton and Point Cook bases. Although I made it quite clear that we would not be keeping an airfield open simply for the purposes of a museum, I did not rule out any site. If it appears in the best interests of all concerned that the NASMA should go to Laverton or Point Cook then I expect the Committee will make a recommendation to that effect. Until all options have been examined it would be premature to limit future potential uses of the land or facilities of either base.

(2) This does not appear amongst the terms of reference of the Committee, which is a consultative committee only, established to consider and make recommendations to the Commonwealth and State Governments, the Western Region Commission and the City of Werribee on regional economic and social matters. The Committee is to have regard to the Government's stated desire to ensure, as far as possible, that local communities are not disadvantaged as a result of the closure or relocation of Defence activities.

(3) No. The terms of reference do require the Committee to make recommendations on, among other things, desirable future balance between residential, industrial and recreational use of land no longer required for Defence purposes, and the future regulatory and rezoning requirements for such land, however the Committee is not limited in the range of future uses it can consider, nor required to make recommendations fully covering the range of activities in the honourable senator's question. The terms of reference do not rule out such an approach.

(4) The establishment of the Consultative Committee ensures that the Commonwealth Government will be able to make the best possible decisions, based on information available to it from all levels of Government and from community involvement in the consultative process.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Finance, upon notice, on 18 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: How many staff hours have been spent to date, by the department on analysing the Hewson Tax Package, broken down into the following aspects (a) hours spent during normal working time; (b) hours spent outside normal working time where penalty rates would apply; and (c) the total cost in dollars.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Finance has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: It is the responsibility of the Department of Finance to provide advice and analysis to government on resource allocation proposals. This applies to proposals from any source. Thus work on the "Fightback" proposal was dealt with as a part of the Department's on-going function. No records were kept of all the work done on the package and the bulk of the work was done by senior officers who are not eligible for overtime or other penalty payments. Where overtime was required it involved 16.25 hours at a total cost of $602.27.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 19 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: What is the legislative basis by which officers of the Department of Social Security are able to make decisions as to whether or not beneficiaries are eligible for concessionary pharmaceutical benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Pharmaceutical benefits cards are issued under Part VII of the National Health Act 1953. Part VII provides for automatic entitlement to a card where a person falls into any of several defined categories. These categories include pensioners who are not eligible for a pensioner health benefit card which has a more stringent means test.

Under the legislation, there is no requirement for a decision as such. All that is required is for a departmental officer to identify that a person is entitled to a pharmaceutical benefits card because of the type of social security payment he or she receives and a card can be issued.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services, upon notice, on 19 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why are there no written guidelines specifying the appropriate use of fee relief monies which are paid in advance to both private and CSP centres.
(2) Have any, and if so which, interest groups or child-care organisations expressed concern to Government officials over lack of guidelines.
(3) Are there any restrictions placed on fee relief use in either both the private and community-based sector; if so, what are they.

(4) How many centres, in which States, did not receive the advance quarterly fee relief funding in the first week of each quarter for the 1991 calendar year, of those that did not receive their full advancement for the quarter in the first week, how many were private and how many were community-based.
(5) Why has the department introduced the requirement that services must wait until week six before notifying the department of the need for an additional advance in that quarter.
(6) How many centres, by State, required additional fee relief advances, in which quarters were they required and how many days were taken to process these applications for additional advances.
(7) Why does the Government continue to refer to private child-care centres as commercial, even though it has been requested on a number of occasions to use the term private.

(8) Have any, and what number and types of, complaints been received regarding the recent training sessions for the revised administrative procedures; if so, have any, and what steps, been taken to correct these complaints.
(9) How many trainers were employed for the purpose of conducting training sessions, and at what cost.
(10) How many seminars were conducted in each State: (a) at what cost; (b) what were the rules of attendance; and (c) how many centres were represented and by how many service providers.
(11) On how many occasions was a training session not attended by representatives from both the private and community-based centres.
(12) Is there an official policy to segregate the two segments; if so, on what basis.

(13) As part of the alleged improved accountability requirements, is the department going to ensure that parents who pay a fee for the full-time service of a centre are entitled to access the centre for all hours of operation.
(14) In how many services are the weekly hours of operation for full-time care not the hours that full-time parents are able to access.
(15) Will the department take steps to ensure that parents may access either private or community-based centres for the full hours of operation.
(16) Why is the department forwarding fee relief claims to community-based centres when the forms do not have to be returned until 1 April 1992.
(17) Why was a similar time lag not extended to private centres.
(18) Why is the department requesting community centres to report their monthly utilisation rates.
(19) What is the current proportion of sole pensioners who are exempted from the requirement to seek child maintenance payments.
(20) What are the categories for exemption and what proportion of the total fall into each category.
(21) What were the estimated and actual savings achieved in the 1990-91 financial year.
(22) What were the major factors responsible for the shortfall.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) The use of fee relief funds advanced by the Commonwealth Government to child care service operators under Section 12A of the Child Care Act 1972 is specified in the formal Agreement between service operators and the Commonwealth Government.
Section 2(3) of the agreement entered into by the operators of community child care centres and section 3(1) of the agreement entered into by the operators of private child care centres states:

"The Operator shall use all monies granted to it under section 12A for the sole purpose of enabling the Operator to allow fee relief in respect of a child or children identified in accordance with the Guidelines as a child or children in economic need to whom child care is provided by the operator."

(2) The Australian Federation of Child Care Associations and the Child Care Centres Association of Victoria (CCCAV) have suggested that fee relief advances be paid into a separate special account for easier accountability of fee relief funds.

(3) See Question 1. Fee relief funds are paid into an account nominated by the service operator at the commencement of each quarter and acquitted at the end of each quarter. Services must demonstrate to the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services that the funds have been used for fee relief purposes.
(4) The reasons an advance may be made after the first week of the quarter include:
services commencing or being approved to commence after the beginning of a quarter;
services not submitting a claim;
overdue accountability documentation;
uncorrected errors in a previous claim; and
services having funds on hand from a previous quarter.

ANSWER.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 169]

PARA.TAB: (5) Requests for additional advances can be made at any time. Services are, of course, required to substantiate their claim before any further payment is made.

(6) An estimate of the number of centres requiring additional advances in 1991 is set out in the following table. Payments would generally have been received by services within 5 days of the receipt of the claim by the Department of Health, Housing and Community Services.

ANSWER.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 169]

PARA.TAB: (7) Both terms are used. There is no single term which describes all child care centres. These centres include non-profit services (e.g. community based services, TAFE and hospital based services), the for-profit services and employer-sponsored services. The term commercial services is sometimes used to describe the for-profit services. The term private is not sufficient to describe only the for-profit services. Both non-profit and employer-sponsored services can be privately operated.

(8) A small number of complaints were received about the proposed administrative changes to the fee relief system and their implementation on 1 January 1992. The majority of the suggestions made have been incorporated into the revised procedures.
(9) No trainers were employed for the purpose of conducting training sessions. Training was conducted by Departmental staff responsible for administration of the Program.

ANSWER.PARA: [THE TABLE IS OMITTED FROM THE DATABASE, SEE HARDCOPY PAGE 170]

PARA.TAB: (10)(b) In all but one State there were no set rules for attendance and services were given a variety of times and sessions from which to choose. Initially, in Victoria each service was limited to sending one representative.

(11) Two States, Victoria and South Australia, divided their private and community based sector services for training. This decision was based on the fact that the system used by the private sector services was only slightly modified, therefore they needed less training than the community based sector.
All other States conducted joint sessions.
(14) The Department is not aware of how many services, if any, do not allow parents seeking full-time care, access to the total hours for which the service operates.
(16) Fee relief claim forms must be completed progressively throughout the quarter to which they apply. The claim forms to be returned on 1 April 1992 apply to the period 1 January to 31 March 1992.
(17) Fee Relief Claim forms for the January/ March Quarter were sent to all centres at the same time in each state.

(18) The decision to request a monthly utilisation report from community child care centres in Victoria was taken by the Department in response to concern about the effects of the recession on the utilisation of some centres in that State.
(19)(20)(21)(22) These questions relate to the Child Support Agency, which is the responsibility of the Minister for Social Security.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Shipping and Aviation, upon notice, on 23 December 1991:

PARA.TAB: (1) As at 19 December 1991, and as at the last day of each of the three preceding months, how much was owed to the Civil Aviation Authority by each of the domestic airlines for air navigation charges.
(2) What was the peak indebtedness of each of the domestic airlines to the Civil Aviation Authority for the period 30 September to 19 December 1991.
(3) On what payment terms does the Civil Aviation Authority normally levy air navigation charges.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) and (2) These are commercial matters between the airlines and the Civil Aviation Authority. The Authority has advised that it does, however, treat all airlines equally in billing and debt recovery matters.

(3) Early each month a statement is issued to operators, by the Civil Aviation Authority, covering flights that occurred during the preceding month. ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Overview Audit Strategies for Selected Projects

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the consultancy services listed at Appendix L of the Defence Annual Report 1990-91 will the Minister table the report by Coopers and Lybrand entitled Develop audit strategies for the Submarine, ANZAC ship and Jindalee projects and in relation to this report: (a) what were the terms of the reference; (b) when was the report commissioned; (c) what were the main recommendations; and (d) how many of these recommendations have been implemented.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: The report referred to in the question is titled "Overview Audit Strategies for Selected Projects". For commercial reasons, I am not prepared to table the report but I am happy to provide access to the report for the Senator, at a convenient time.

PARA.TAB: (a) (1) The general terms of reference were:

(i) determine the current achieved stage in the life cycle of the Submarine, ANZAC Ship and Jindalee Over-the-Horizon Radar projects, so as to form an opinion on areas of risk and associated major reporting milestones; and
(ii) development of an overview audit strategy for each of these projects for the years 1990-94 as appropriate, in accordance with the Defence Audit Manual Volume 3, Capital Acquisitions.
(2) The specific terms of reference were:
(i) develop an audit strategy for the ongoing audit of the identified projects covering the period 1990-94 (three years);

(ii) ensure that audits can be undertaken on a range of issues which cover both compliance with financial probity/regulatory matters and areas of sensitivity/risk. Account is to be taken of any major or significant project milestones, in the timing of audit for each of the identified projects;
(iii) take account of any previous audit of the identified projects, as well as relevant issues Audit or General Investigations and Review Branches of the Inspector General's Division;

(iv) ensure that there is an appropriate transfer to Management Audit Branch to permit the strategy to be implemented; and (v) provide a detailed briefing for the Liaison Officer and other Defence officers as necessary, on the outcome of the consultancy, followed by a report to the Inspector General.
(b) The report was commissioned on 4 September 1990.
(c) (1) The report recommended for each project, based on an indicative timetable: (i) preliminary survey of the control mechanisms and management information system for each auditable activity;
(ii) a detailed control evaluation to evaluate the adequacy of the control mechanisms and management information systems for each auditable activity; and

(iii) the performance of compliance tests designed to confirm the consistent and proper operation of the control mechanisms and the management information systems for project management, financial management, contract administration, configuration management, integrated logistic support, Australian industry involvement and project computing and computer applications.
(d) Audit programs based on the recommendations have commenced and will continue in accordance with timetables agreed with the respective project offices.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the consultancy services listed at Appendix L of the Defence Annual Report 1990-91:
(1) Will the Minister table the report by Mr A Kiln entitled Historical Research into WWII SIGINT activities, if not, why not.
(2) Why was this report commissioned and who will have access to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The document to be prepared by the consultant will be a highly classified history of Australia's Sigint activities during WWII and, as such, it would not be appropriate that it be tabled.

(2) The history was commissioned to document details of Australia's Sigint activities during WWII. It is being prepared primarily for use as an internal DSD document but it will also be made available to those outside DSD who have appropriate clearance and a "need-to-know".

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: North West Cape Naval Communications Station

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the consultancy services listed at Appendix L of the Defence Annual Report 1990-91:
(1) Will the Minister table the consultant's report by BHP Aerospace entitled "Report on Contractor Management Options at NAVCOMMSTA"; if not, why not.
(2) How many civilian contractors did the report anticipate would be needed to replace the functions of United States and Australian servicemen currently at North West Cape.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) & (2) I believe it would be neither sensible nor proper to release the consultant's report by BHP Aerospace at this time. The report contains information that would be prejudicial to the competitive processes involved in the selection of a suitable contractor. The tender for North West Cape is due for release in the next few months.

This report contains information of a sensitive commercial-in-confidence nature and, in any event, is only one of a number of preliminary internal planning documents used to provide guidance on the likely costs and benefits of the various management options for the Naval Communications Station at North West Cape.

I said in my Parliamentary Statement to the Senate last November that Australia and the United States are now agreed that a civilian contractor will be selected to manage the Station. However, many points of detail remain to be worked out in the ongoing discussions between Royal Australian and United States Navy officials.

The release of the report at this stage of the transition process for North West Cape would detract from the Government's intention to provide for fair and open competition in the selection of a civilian contractor for the management of this important defence facility.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister of Defence, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: With reference to the consultancy services listed at Appendix L of the Defence Annual Report 1990-91:
(1) Why were two consultants commissioned to study the marine ecology of Jervis Bay.
(2) What were the terms of reference for the studies produced by: (a) the CSIRO Division of Fisheries Research; and (b) the NSW Department of Agriculture and Fisheries.
(3) Did the findings of the two reports differ; if so, how.
(4) What action has the Department taken following receipt of these two reports.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Marine Ecology Studies of Jervis Bay were commissioned to fulfil two important objectives, firstly to provide the baseline marine ecology research required for the preparation of an Environmental Impact Statement for the relocation of Naval Facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay and secondly to provide sufficiently detailed data upon which to base a management plan to address impacts on the marine environment.

Two consultants were chosen for the studies on the basis of the expertise required to address the full range of habitat components identified for the studies. The contractors are the NSW Department of Agriculture and Fisheries who have been retained to study fish in a number of habitats and the CSIRO Division of Fisheries who studied other major components of the marine ecology of Jervis Bay. The studies undertaken by each consultant were:
NSW Department of Agriculture and Fisheries
Fish and Macroinvertebrates associated with Creeks and Seagrass Beds.
Fish Associated with Natural Rocky Reefs and with Artificial Structures
Mollusc Studies
Commercial and Recreational Fisheries of Jervis Bay
CSIRO
Floral Communities of Jervis Bay
Epifauna of Jervis Bay
lnfauna of Jervis Bay
Water quality of Jervis Bay
Water Circulation of Jervis Bay
(2) The terms of reference for both study participants were similar and can be summarised in the following six points:
Study Objectives
1. describe the existing marine environment of Jervis Bay;
2. establish a biological baseline against which future changes can be measured;
3. describe selected ecological processes thought to important and potentially affected by development proposals;
4. evaluate the success of replanted seagrass in dredged areas; (CSIRO only)
5. derive and evaluate a cost effective plan for the permanent biological monitoring of the Bay; and
6. assist with the engineering design of developments to minimise impacts.
Study design was based on a concept of valued ecosystem components for Jervis Bay. They are:
The recreational amenity
The commercial fisheries resource
Vegetated habitats
Faunal communities, and
Protected species

(3) There are a number of interim reports from these studies, however the final reports are still in preparation and will be available early this year. The reports from the two consultants differ markedly as they cover separate subjects. The emphasis of the NSW A & F reports is on fish and related issues while the CSIRO reports have dealt with a range of issues according to their study briefs.

(4) The Jervis Bay Marine Ecology Studies were commissioned to provide baseline data for the management of marine ecology impacts in Jervis Bay. Data from the studies was initially used in the preparation of a preliminary draft Environmental Impact Statement in 1989 for the then proposal to relocate Naval Facilities from Sydney to Jervis Bay:

Upon completion of the studies and the presentation of final reports it is intended that the data will be used in an overall Environmental Management plan for the marine environments of Jervis Bay. Recognising that the results of these studies have significant scientific value and community interest, it is intended that the results will subsequently be made public.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Australian Survey Corps (ASC) regularly produce digital and paper maps for the Australian Defence Force (ADF); if so, what is the time interval between each production.
(2) Are these maps of a general nature and of similar scales and details to maps which are normally available to members of the public; if not, what special mapping requirements does the ADF have.
(3) Is the information gathered by the ASC available to the general public; if not, why not.

(4) Does the ASC undertake mapping in conjunction or consultation with other Commonwealth and State mapping authorities; if not, why not. Can the mapping requirements of the ADF be met by civilian sources; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) The Royal Australian Survey Corps (RA Svy) does regularly produce digital and paper maps for the Australian Defence Force (ADF). Approximately 100 new maps of Northern Australia are produced each year in accordance with Defence priorities and revision is conducted as required by the ADF.

(2) The maps produced are classified as "topographic" and meet the ADF requirement for content, detail and accuracy. The map scale of the majority of maps produced is 1:50 000. This is the scale required by the Army. Essentially the general nature of the maps is similar to those available to the public, however the scale is tailored to meet military requirements.

(3) Digital data and associated maps produced by RA Svy are available to the general public. RA Svy use the Australian Land Information Group (AUSLIG) and State mapping authorities as points of contact for such release.

(4) RA Svy does undertake mapping in consultation and conjunction with other Commonwealth and State Mapping Agencies. RA Svy consults regularly with the Australia Land Information Group (AUSLIG) regarding 1:100 000 and 1:250 000 scale maps for determination of priority areas. RA Svy provides 1:50 000 scale information to AUSLIG for their 1:100 000 and 1:250 000 scale map revision programs. RA Svy consults formally through the Inter-Governmental Advisory Committee on Surveying and Mapping and on a day to day basis with State mapping authorities with regard to the larger scale maps. RA Svy contributes to the civilian mapping sector through the provision of data to the National Geodetic Data Base, revision of the National Topographic Mapping Series, undertaking research and development which can be transferred to the civilian community and as a Global Positioning System information service.

(5) The mapping requirements of the ADF cannot be fully met by civilian sources. However reliance on civilian produced maps of Australia is increasing. RA Svy no longer produces 1:100 000 scale and 1:250 000 scale topographic maps and it is proposed to rationalise the production of air charts between the military and civilian sources. The ADF relies primarily on military map exchange agreements managed by RA Svy to meet its offshore map requirements.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the chemical strontium oxalate have any military functions; if so, what are these functions.

(2) If strontium oxalate has military functions, is the export of this chemical in any way covered by: (a) the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations; (b) the Australian Controls on the Export of Technology with Civil and Military Applications; or (c) any other export controls; if not, why not.

(3) With regard to the sale of strontium oxalate by the Australian company Alpha Chemicals to Armscor of South Africa: (a) was an end-user and non-transfer certificate provided; if so, when and to whom was the certificate provided; (b) what did this certificate say with regard to the stated end-use of the chemical; (c) was the sale considered by the Standing Interdepartmental Committee on Defence Exports (SIDCDE); if not, why not; (d) was the sale considered by any agency within the department; if so, which agency and when; if not, why not; and (e) if the department was not involved in assessing the application to export strontium oxalate to South Africa, what Government agencies were responsible for processing the sale.

(4) What is the current Government policy with reference to the sale of: (a) defence equipment; and (b) dual-use technology items as defined by the guidelines on Australian defence exports with regard to South Africa.

(5) If strontium oxalate is not covered by any of the export controls outlined in paragraph (3), what authority does SIDCDE have to review this export application; is the capacity of SIDCDE to review export applications in any way influenced by the identity of the purchaser of the export item, in particular if the purchaser is Armscor of South Africa.
(6) Is the Armscor corporation of South Africa involved in any activities which would call for the non-military related use of strontium oxalate.
(7) What ability does Customs have to: (a) assess whether or not an export may have a defence-related purpose; and (b) to refer an application for export to SIDCDE.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes, strontium oxalate is used in tracer ammunition as a colouring agent.
(b) No;
(c) No;

The export of strontium oxalate is not controlled as the material is basically a commercial chemical not specially designed or adapted for military purposes and, moreover, is not considered to be an active ingredient of propellent mixtures for tracer ammunition. It is also not considered to be dual-use technology, a chemical weapons precursor or useful in the development of nuclear weapons.
(b) Not applicable;

(c) No, as it is not controlled under Regulation 13B of the Customs (Prohibited Exports) Regulations. Had the item been controlled, it would still not have been considered by the SIDCDE as the sale in question occurred in 1984, four years prior to the establishment of SIDCDE.
(d) No, as it is not a controlled item.

(e) As strontium oxalate is not a substance controlled under any Prohibited Exports Regulations, the Australian Customs Service would be the only Government agency likely to have knowledge of its export.

(4) (a) There is an embargo on the sales of defence and related equipment, controlled under Regulation 13B to South Africa, in accordance with the United Nations Security Council embargo on arms sales to that destination.

(b) With the exception of the sale of computer hardware, which is controlled by the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade, South Africa is treated in the same manner as other non-COCOM countries seeking dual-use goods and technology.

(5) The prohibited exports regulations refer to goods and not, in the first instance, end users. The SIDCDE is only authorised to consider export applications of controlled goods. As strontium oxalate is not controlled under any export regulations, there is no requirement for the exporter to lodge an export application.
(6) I am not aware of the range of activities of Armscor that calls upon the use of strontium oxalate in its products.

(7) (a)&(b) Defence has provided the Australian Customs Service with information that identifies controlled goods. This enables the Service to check that appropriate permits have been granted before allowing the export to proceed.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 7 January 1992:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Commonwealth regularly publish paper maps; if so, what organisations and bodies receive regular updated copies of these maps.

(2) With reference to digital maps: (a) are they publicly available; (b) is a historical register maintained; (c) how are such maps made available to the public; and (d) is there scope for current and historical digital maps to be provided to public libraries; if not, why not.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is:

PARA.TAB: (1) Yes; The Australian National Library and State Reference Libraries.
(2) (a) Yes.
(b) Yes.
(c) Through telephone, fax and mail order and over the counter.
(d) There is scope to provide digital maps to libraries. This is not current practice, however, as the libraries do not have the computer systems to utilise the information.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 2 December 1991 (Hansard, page 3738) Senator Knowles asked me, as the Minister representing the Minister

ANSWER.PARA: for Employment, Education and Training, the following question without notice:

PARA.TAB: My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Now that the Department of Employment, Education and Training in Western Australia has admitted that the returns from the training guarantee levy have been consumed in the cost of collecting it, can the Minister advise the Senate as to how this bungling mismanagement by the Department of Employment, Education and Training has occurred and what will be the shortfall?
The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

The Australian Taxation Office (ATO) has advised that it anticipates that some $5 million will be collected for the 1990-91 year in direct payments of shortfalls and funds realised as a result of audits.

This is less than anticipated and is indicative of employers' positive response to the legislation; in other words they are in general taking training seriously and are spending the required amount on training. This was a major object of the legislation and I am very pleased that it appears already, in the very early days of the Training Guarantee, to have been achieved.

There is a possibility that the amounts collected into the Fund over the years 1990-91 to 1991-94 will not exceed essential Commonwealth administrative costs incurred by the Australian Taxation Office, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the National Training Board.

Contrary to the Senator's suggestions, this indicates the success of the Training Guarantee. The Commonwealth's administrative costs have been and continue to be essential in raising employer awareness of the Scheme and the need for increased investment in quality training. Employers have done their part by willingly responding to the new legislation as indicated by the low level of collections into the Fund thus far.
